classes.desc: Capstone course for the Sales minor, students explore building and maintaining relationships, apply selling skills, and prepare themselves for a career in professional selling.  4 seminars.

classes.name: Blockchain in Business
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: BUS 392 or CSC 101 or CSC 232 or ECON 395.
classes.desc: Blockchain technology in business, with application examples in management (including HR, marketing and accounting), operation systems (manufacturing, supply chain and other service systems), finance (including stock trading, real estate transactions and P2P payment systems) and entrepreneurship.  4 lectures.  Crosslisted as BUS/ITP 468.

classes.name: Selected Advanced Topics
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: Consent of instructor.
classes.desc: Directed group study of selected topics for advanced students.  Open to undergraduate and graduate students.  The Class Schedule will list topic selected.  Total credit limited to 8 units.  1 to 4 lectures.

classes.name: Managing and Rewarding Employee Performance
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: BUS 384 and STAT 252.
classes.desc: Managing and compensating employee performance.  Motivation theories, performance measures, evaluation and feedback systems/practices, planning for performance improvement.  Advantages and challenges of pay-for-performance systems.  Design and management of total compensation systems.  Compensation systems as a factor in employee development and organizational performance.  4 lectures.

classes.name: Independent Study in Accounting
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: BUS 322.
classes.desc: Individual investigation, research, study or survey of selected topics in accounting, auditing or taxation.  Total credit limited to 8 units, repeatable in the same term.  The Class Schedule will list topic selected.

classes.name: Leading Social Innovation in Organizations
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: Completion of GE Area A with grades of C- or better.
classes.desc: Fundamentals and practice of leading social innovation in existing and new organizations.  Emphasis on collective action tools and processes that support social initiatives with positive impact.  4 lectures.

classes.name: Management Consulting and Change Management
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: BUS 382 or BUS 387.
classes.desc: Analysis of development and trends in the field of organization change and development.  Application of behavioral and organizational science knowledge and social technology to growth and change of organizations for improving effectiveness and sustainability.  Principles of management consulting.  4 seminars.

classes.name: People Analytics
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: BUS 384 or BUS 387; and STAT 252 or equivalent.
classes.desc: Data-driven approach to human resource practices with emphasis on the strategic use of analytics to drive effective practice and support decision-making; use of appropriate data sources and techniques for testing HR-related questions; considerations for collection and use of human data.  4 lectures.

classes.name: Launching and Growing the Technology Start-Up
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: BUS 310 and consent of instructor.
classes.desc: Topics in entrepreneurial settings, focusing on technology startups.  Frameworks, analytical skills, and decision-making tools used in growing entrepreneurial businesses.  Field trip required.  4 lectures.

classes.name: Building a Startup Skill Set
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: BUS 310; BUS 418; Business majors must have declared their concentration to enroll. Recommended: BUS 436.
classes.desc: Process of evolving a startup's business model, focusing on product-market fit; go-to-market strategies; revenue streams; cost structure; partnerships; key activities; and key resources.  Exploration of a personal entrepreneurial pathway.  4 seminars.

classes.name: Negotiation
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: BUS 387.
classes.desc: Theory and practice of negotiation in a variety of professional and managerial contexts (e.g., labor relations, business acquisitions, compensation, business disputes) and in one-on-one, group, and team-based arrangements.  Includes impact of culture, ethics, dispute resolution, coalitions and use of creativity to develop integrative solutions.  4 lectures.

classes.name: Decision Support Systems
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: BUS 391, STAT 251 or equivalent; Business and Economics majors must have formally declared their concentration to enroll.
classes.desc: Modeling organizational systems and processes such as computer networks, transportation systems, manufacturing systems, retail systems, etc.  Developing computer simulation models and animation of systems to provide decision support in selecting system design alternatives.  Applying quantitative methods to model uncertainty and conduct statistical performance analysis.  4 lectures.

classes.name: Technology-Supported Collaboration
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: BUS 387 and BUS 391.
classes.desc: Collaboration from multiple perspectives, applying best practices and empirically-supported insights toward successful collaboration in organizational settings.  Theories of teams, collaboration, and the technologies to support these processes.  Application of techniques for leadership, problem solving, communications, virtual collaboration, and collaboration technologies.  4 lectures.

classes.name: User Experience Analysis and Design
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: BUS 394.
classes.desc: Fundamentals of User Experience Analysis and Design.  Best practices in mobile/web/desktop user interfaces.  Persona development.  Prototyping using software tools.  Includes theoretical and practical discussion of user experience analysis and design in business settings.  4 lectures.

classes.name: Software Testing
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: BUS 392.
classes.desc: Theory and practice of software testing, including state-of-the-art practices, design issues, staffing issues, test management issues, and other related areas.  Software testing tools utilized for applications testing, and test management.  4 lectures.

classes.name: Electronic Commerce
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: BUS 392.
classes.desc: Focus on the technology of electronic commerce, including programming, development environments and security, through a series of lectures, guest speakers, demonstrations, exercises and case studies.  Networking, client/server computing, and web/database design concepts.  Working e-commerce application required at end of course.  4 lectures.

classes.name: Business Analytics
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: BUS 393 and STAT 252.
classes.desc: Introduction to the concepts and applications of business analytics, using business case study and problem-solving approach.  Data warehouse design and implementation.  Supervised learning techniques for classification and prediction.  Unsupervised learning techniques for dimension reduction and pattern recognition.  Text analytics.  Course may be offered in classroom-based, online, or hybrid format.  4 lectures.

classes.name: Directed Topics in Information Systems
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: BUS 392.
classes.desc: Specialized Information Systems (IS) topic selected from the IS areas of current interest.  Intended for advanced IS concentration students who want to learn and acquire in-depth IS knowledge and skills.  The Class Schedule will list topic selected.  Total credit limited to 12 units.  4 lectures.

classes.name: Data Communications and Networking
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: BUS 391; Business and Economics majors must declare their concentrations in order to enroll.
classes.desc: Combines the fundamental concepts of data communications and networking with practical applications in business.  Provides a basic understanding of the technical and managerial aspects of business telecommunication.  Introduction to data communications and applications and technical fundamentals, and to network products, technologies, applications, and services.  4 lectures.

classes.name: Introduction to the Chemical Sciences
classes.pre_reqs: CR/NCPrerequisite: BCHEM/CHEM majors only.
classes.desc: Introduction to the chemistry and biochemistry disciplines.  Orientation, advising, career opportunities and introduction to the faculty.  Designed for first-year CHEM and BCHEM majors.  Credit/No Credit grading only.  1 lecture.

classes.name: World of Chemistry
classes.pre_reqs: 2020-21 or later catalog: GE Area B12020-21 or later catalog: GE Area B32019-20 or earlier catalog: GE Area B32019-20 or earlier catalog: GE Area B4Prerequisite: MATH 96; or MATH 115; or appropriate Math Placement Level.
classes.desc: The fundamentals of chemical cause and effect-structure/function relationships.  The basic principles of chemistry and their applications to solving human problems in organic materials science, biochemistry, toxicology, environmental science, agriculture, nutrition, and medicine.  Not open to students majoring in Chemistry or Biochemistry.  Not open to students with credit in CHEM 111, CHEM 124, or CHEM 127.  3 lectures, 1 laboratory.  Fulfills GE Areas B1 and B3 (GE Areas B3 and B4 for students on the 2019-20 or earlier catalogs).

classes.name: General Chemistry for Physical Science and Engineering I
classes.pre_reqs: 2020-21 or later catalog: GE Area B12020-21 or later catalog: GE Area B32019-20 or earlier catalog: GE Area B32019-20 or earlier catalog: GE Area B4Prerequisite: MATH 118 or MATH 330. Recommended: High school chemistry or equivalent.
classes.desc: Introduction to atomic theory, chemical reactions, bonding, stoichiometry, nomenclature, gas laws, thermochemistry, molecular structure, and intermolecular forces.  Intended primarily for students in engineering and/or physical sciences.  Not open to students with credit in CHEM 127.  Credit will be granted in only one of the following courses:  CHEM 110, CHEM 124, or CHEM 127.  3 lectures, 1 laboratory.  Fulfills GE Areas B1 and B3 (GE Areas B3 and B4 for students on the 2019-20 or earlier catalogs).

classes.name: General Chemistry for Physical Science and Engineering II
classes.pre_reqs: 2020-21 or later catalog: GE Area B12020-21 or later catalog: GE Area B32019-20 or earlier catalog: GE Area B32019-20 or earlier catalog: GE Area B4Prerequisite: CHEM 124, or AP Chemistry score of 5.
classes.desc: Topics include solution chemistry, thermodynamics, kinetics, equilibrium (including acids and bases), electrochemistry, and nuclear chemistry.  Not open to students with credit in CHEM 128.  3 lectures, 1 laboratory.  Fulfills GE Areas B1 and B3 (GE Areas B3 and B4 for students on the 2019-20 or earlier catalogs).

classes.name: General Chemistry for Physical Science and Engineering III
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: CHEM 125 with a grade of C- or better or consent of instructor.
classes.desc: Topics in equilibrium, kinetics, acid-base chemistry, and molecular structure, contextualized within major sub-disciplines of chemistry.  Not open to students with credit in CHEM 129.  3 lectures, 1 laboratory.

classes.name: General Chemistry for Agriculture and Life Science I
classes.pre_reqs: 2020-21 or later catalog: GE Area B12020-21 or later catalog: GE Area B32019-20 or earlier catalog: GE Area B32019-20 or earlier catalog: GE Area B4Prerequisite: MATH 118 or MATH 330. Recommended: High school chemistry or equivalent.
classes.desc: Introduction to atomic theory, chemical reactions, bonding, stoichiometry, nomenclature, gas laws, thermochemistry, molecular structure, and intermolecular forces.  Intended primarily for students in agriculture and life sciences.  Not open to students with credit in CHEM 124.  Credit will be granted in only one of the following courses:  CHEM 110, CHEM 124, or CHEM 127.  3 lectures, 1 laboratory.  Fulfills GE Areas B1 and B3 (GE Areas B3 and B4 for students on the 2019-20 or earlier catalogs).

classes.name: General Chemistry for Agriculture and Life Science II
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: CHEM 127 or AP Chemistry score of 5.
classes.desc: Continuation of CHEM 127.  Colligative properties, colloids and solutions, oxidation-reduction reactions, electrochemistry, kinetics, equilibria, and thermodynamics.  Not open to students with credit in CHEM 125.  3 lectures, 1 laboratory.

classes.name: General Chemistry for Agriculture and Life Science III
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: CHEM 128.
classes.desc: Continuation of CHEM 128.  Acid and base equilibria, buffers, transition elements, solubility, complex ions, hybrid orbital theory, molecular orbital theory, and nuclear chemistry.  Laboratory study of the chemical properties and semi-micro qualitative analysis of the representative group elements of the periodic table.  Not open to students with credit in CHEM 126.  3 lectures, 1 laboratory.

classes.name: Special Problems for Undergraduates
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: CHEM 111, CHEM 124, or CHEM 127 and consent of department chair.
classes.desc: Individual investigation, research, studies, or surveys of selected problems.  Total credit limited to 4 units, with a maximum of 2 units per quarter.

classes.name: Undergraduate Research
classes.pre_reqs: CR/NCPrerequisite: Consent of instructor.
classes.desc: Research under faculty supervision.  Credit/No Credit grading only.  Total credit limited to 10 units.

classes.name: Orientation to Biotechnology
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: Completion of a course with a BIO, BOT or MCRO prefix and a course with a CHEM prefix.
classes.desc: Introduction to the diversity of fields in biotechnology.  Applications in agriculture, nutrition, medicine and environmental problems.  1 lecture, 1 activity.  Crosslisted as BIO/CHEM 202.

classes.name: Undergraduate Seminar I
classes.pre_reqs: CR/NCPrerequisite: CHEM 126.
classes.desc: Introduction to basic scientific literature and scientific presentation skills.  Targeted advising and preparation for research and career opportunities.  Designed for second-year students majoring in Biochemistry or in Chemistry.  Credit/No Credit grading only.  1 seminar.

classes.name: Introduction to Organic Chemistry
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: CHEM 111, CHEM 124 or CHEM 127.
classes.desc: Structure, isomerism, nomenclature, fundamental reactions of major functional groups and applications of organic chemicals in agriculture, medicine, industry, and the home.  CHEM 212 accepted in lieu of CHEM 312, but not for upper division credit.  Not open to students with credit in CHEM 312, CHEM 216/316.  4 lectures, 1 laboratory.

classes.name: Organic Chemistry I
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: CHEM 126 or CHEM 129 with a grade of C- or better or consent of instructor.
classes.desc: Fundamental concepts and laboratory skills of organic chemistry.  Structure, bonding, nomenclature, isomerism, stereochemistry and physical properties of organic compounds.  Introduction to spectroscopy.  Reactions and mechanisms of alkanes, alkenes and alkyl halides.  Fundamental laboratory techniques in organic chemistry.  Not open to students with credit in CHEM 316.  4 lectures, 1 laboratory.

classes.name: Organic Chemistry II
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: CHEM 216 with a grade of C- or better or consent of instructor. Corequisite: CHEM 221 for Chemistry and Biochemistry majors; or CHEM 220 for non-Chemistry and non-Biochemistry majors.
classes.desc: Properties and reactions of carbonyl compounds, alcohols, ethers, amines and carbohydrates with an in-depth treatment of the reaction mechanisms.  Introductory concepts and applications of infrared and NMR spectroscopy.  Not open to students with credit in CHEM 317.  3 lectures.

classes.name: Organic Chemistry III
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: CHEM 217 with a grade of C- or better or consent of instructor. Corequisite: CHEM 324 for Chemistry and Biochemistry majors; or CHEM 223 for non-Chemistry and non-Biochemistry majors.
classes.desc: Properties and reactions of alkynes, heterocyclic and aromatic compounds with an in-depth treatment of the mechanisms of the reactions.  Introductory concepts and applications of ultraviolet spectroscopy and mass spectrometry.  Not open to students with credit in CHEM 318.  3 lectures.

classes.name: Organic Chemistry Laboratory For Life Sciences II
classes.pre_reqs: Corequisite: CHEM 217.
classes.desc: Laboratory experiments exploring reactions in organic chemistry, applying fundamental laboratory techniques covered in CHEM 216.  Not open to Chemistry and Biochemistry majors.  1 laboratory.

classes.name: Organic Chemistry Laboratory II
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: major in Chemistry or Biochemistry. Corequisite: CHEM 217.
classes.desc: Laboratory experiments exploring reactions in organic chemistry, applying fundamental laboratory techniques covered in CHEM 216.  2 laboratories.

classes.name: Organic Chemistry Laboratory for Life Sciences III
classes.pre_reqs: Corequisite: CHEM 218.
classes.desc: Practice in multi-step organic synthesis, enzymatic organic chemistry, biomimetic organic chemistry.  Not open to Biochemistry or Chemistry majors.  1 laboratory.

classes.name: Quantitative Analysis
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: CHEM 126 or 129.
classes.desc: Theory and application of chemical equilibrium to analytical problems.  Survey of important analytical methods with stress placed on the theory and application associated with titrimetric and spectrophotometric analysis.  3 lectures, 2 laboratories.

classes.name: Selected Topics
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: Open to undergraduate students and consent of instructor.
classes.desc: Directed group study of selected topics.  The Class Schedule will list topic selected.  Total credit limited to 8 units.  1 to 4 lectures.

classes.name: Marine Chemistry
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: CHEM 216 or CHEM 312.
classes.desc: Introduction to chemical processes in the ocean including chemical oceanography and marine chemical ecology.  3 lectures.

classes.name: Undergraduate Seminar II
classes.pre_reqs: CR/NCPrerequisite: CHEM 203 and CHEM 218.
classes.desc: Advanced exploration of more sophisticated scientific literature and scientific presentation skills.  Targeted advising and preparation for research and career opportunities.  Designed for third-year CHEM and BCHM majors.  Credit/No Credit grading only.  1 seminar.

classes.name: Genetic Engineering Technology
classes.pre_reqs: 2020-21 or later: Upper-Div GE Area B2019-20 or earlier catalog: GE Area B5, B6, or B7Prerequisite: Junior standing; completion of GE Area A with grades of C- or better; and completion of GE Areas B1 through B4, with a grade of C- or better in one course in GE Area B4 (GE Area B1 for students on the 2019-20 or earlier catalogs); and one of the following courses: CHEM 110, CHEM 124, or CHEM 127.
classes.desc: Introduction to the biology, methodology, and techniques used in genetic engineering.  Potential benefits and problems in application within agriculture, nutrition, medicine and environmental context, including the underlying ethical questions.  Not open to students with credit in CHEM 373, or to Biological Sciences, Marine Sciences, or Microbiology majors.  4 lectures.  Crosslisted as BIO/CHEM 308.  Fulfills GE Area Upper-Division B (GE Areas B5, B6, or B7 for students on the 2019-20 catalog).

classes.name: Survey of Organic Chemistry
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: CHEM 125 or CHEM 128.
classes.desc: Structure, isomerism, nomenclature, fundamental reactions of major functional groups and applications of organic chemicals in agriculture, medicine, industry, and the home.  Not open to students with credit in CHEM 212 or CHEM 216/316.  4 lectures, 1 laboratory.

classes.name: Survey of Biochemistry and Biotechnology
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: CHEM 212, CHEM 216, CHEM 312, or CHEM 316.
classes.desc: Chemistry of biomolecules including carbohydrates, proteins, fats, vitamins, enzymes and hormones.  Basic molecular biology with applications to biotechnology and genetic engineering.  Practical intermediary metabolism of prokaryotic and eukaryotic systems.  4 lectures, 1 laboratory.

classes.name: Organic Chemistry Laboratory III
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: major in Chemistry or Biochemistry. Corequisite: CHEM 218.
classes.desc: Practice in multiple step organic synthesis, column chromatography, vacuum distillation, enzymes as chemical reagents, inert atmosphere techniques, introduction to FT NMR spectroscopy and mass spectrometry, survey of organic chemical literature.  2 laboratories.

classes.name: Quantitative Analysis
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: CHEM 126 or 129.
classes.desc: Theory and application of chemical equilibrium to analytical problems.  Survey of important analytical methods with stress placed on the theory and application associated with titrimetric and spectrophotometric analysis.  3 lectures, 2 laboratories.

classes.name: Environmental Chemistry: Water Pollution
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: CHEM 126 or 129; and CHEM 212 or CHEM 312; or CHEM 216 or CHEM 316.
classes.desc: Chemical aspects of water and water pollution:  alkalinity; acid deposition, particularly relating to lake and stream acidification and forest decline; drinking water treatment and trihalomethanes; wastewater treatment; detergents, builders, and eutrophication; pesticides; other toxic organic compounds such as PCBs and dioxin; hazardous wastes; toxic elements such as Pb, Hg, Sn, Cd, and Se.  3 lectures.

classes.name: Chemical and Biological Warfare
classes.pre_reqs: 2020-21 or later: Upper-Div GE Area B2019-20 or earlier catalog: GE Area B5, B6, or B7Prerequisite: Junior standing; completion of GE Area A with grades of C- or better; CHEM course in GE Area B1 (GE Area B3 for students on the 2019-20 or earlier catalogs); BIO or MCRO course in GE Area B2; and completion of GE Area B4 with a grade of C- or better in one course (GE Area B1 for students on the 2019-20 or earlier catalogs).
classes.desc: History, development, and use of chemical and biological warfare (CBW).  Chemical and biological disarmament.  Production and destruction of CBW agents.  CBW terrorism.  Ethics of CBW.  2 lectures, 2 seminars.  Fulfills GE Area Upper-Division B (GE Areas B5, B6, or B7 for students on the 2019-20 catalog).

classes.name: Physical Chemistry I
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: CHEM 126 or CHEM 129; MATH 143; PHYS 122 or PHYS 132.
classes.desc: Basic physical chemistry for the study of chemical and biochemical systems.  Kinetic-molecular theory, gas laws, principles of thermodynamics.  3 lectures.

classes.name: Physical Chemistry II
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: CHEM 351.
classes.desc: Application of physical chemistry to chemical and biochemical systems.  Electrochemistry, kinetics, viscosity, surface and transport properties.  3 lectures.

classes.name: Physical Chemistry III
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: CHEM 352.
classes.desc: Principles and applications of quantum chemistry.  Chemical bonding and molecular structure.  Spectroscopy and diffraction.  3 lectures.

classes.name: Physical Chemistry Laboratory
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: CHEM 231/331. Corequisite: CHEM 352.
classes.desc: Experimental studies of gases, solutions, thermochemistry, chemical and phase equilibria, electrochemistry, chemical and enzyme kinetics, computational methods and applications to chemistry and biochemistry.  Applicable literature and databases.  2 laboratories.

classes.name: Physical Chemistry III Lab
classes.pre_reqs: Corequisite: CHEM 353.
classes.desc: Experimental and computational investigations of quantum chemistry, spectroscopy, symmetry and statistical chemistry.  1 laboratory.

classes.name: Biochemical Principles
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: CHEM 217 or CHEM 317; and BIO 161. Recommended: CHEM 231/331.
classes.desc: Chemistry and function of major cellular constituents:  proteins, lipids, carbohydrates, and membranes.  4 lectures, 1 laboratory.

classes.name: Metabolism
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: CHEM 371.
classes.desc: Intermediary metabolism of carbohydrates, lipids, amino acids and nucleotides, regulation and integration of metabolic pathways, bioenergetics, photosynthesis, electron transport, nitrogen fixation, biochemical function of vitamins and minerals.  4 lectures.

classes.name: Molecular Biology
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: CHEM 371.
classes.desc: Structure of nucleic acids and chromosomes.  Mechanisms and regulation of nucleic acid and protein synthesis.  Molecular biology techniques.  3 lectures.

classes.name: Chemistry of Drugs and Poisons
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: CHEM 313 or CHEM 371.
classes.desc: Introduction to pharmacology and toxicology:  history, sources, development and testing, physical and chemical properties, biochemical and physiological effects, mechanisms of action, and the therapeutic uses and toxicology of common drugs and poisons.  3 lectures.

classes.name: Special Problems for Advanced Undergraduates
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: Junior standing and consent of department chair.
classes.desc: Individual investigation, research, studies, or surveys of selected problems.  Total credit limited to 4 units, with a maximum of 3 units per quarter.  1-3 laboratories.

classes.name: Advanced Undergraduate Research
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: Consent of instructor.
classes.desc: Research under faculty supervision.  Total credit limited to 10 units.  6 units may be applied to approved chemistry electives.

classes.name: Undergraduate Seminar III: Senior Project
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: CHEM 303 and CHEM 352.
classes.desc: Culminating experience with high level scientific literature and scientific presentation skills.  Targeted advising and preparation for research and career opportunities.  Designed for fourth-year CHEM and BCHM majors.  1 seminar.

classes.name: Advanced Physical Chemistry
classes.pre_reqs: Corequisite: CHEM 353.
classes.desc: Selected advanced topics in physical chemistry, which may include statistical mechanics, computational chemistry, nonequilibrium thermodynamics, lasers in chemistry, solid-state and/or advanced spectroscopy.  Total credit limited to 6 units.  3 lectures.

classes.name: Advanced Organic Chemistry - Mechanisms
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: CHEM 218 or CHEM 318.
classes.desc: A mechanistic study of organic reactions; correlation of structure with reactivity; reaction intermediates and species involved in reactions; methods of probing reaction mechanisms.  3 lectures.

classes.name: Neurochemistry
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: BIO 161 and CHEM 217.
classes.desc: Introduction to the chemistry of neurotransmission.  Emphasis on molecular makeup and function of voltage gated ion channels; receptors and enzymes involved in signal transduction; biosynthesis, storage, release, reuptake, and breakdown of major neurotransmitters.  Mechanism of action of agonists and antagonists, and their effects on the central and peripheral nervous systems.  3 lectures.

classes.name: Advanced Organic Chemistry - Synthesis
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: CHEM 218/318.
classes.desc: Modern methods of organic synthesis.  Carbon-carbon bond forming reactions, functional group transformations, protecting groups, strategies of total synthesis of natural products.  3 seminars.

classes.name: Nutritional Biochemistry
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: CHEM 371.
classes.desc: Nutritional aspects of biochemistry.  Topics include essential and energy providing nutrients, vitamins and minerals, deficiencies, degenerative and genetic diseases of metabolism, hormones and brain chemistry, other current topics.  Emphasis on current research and controversy.  3 lectures.  Formerly CHEM 528.

classes.name: Physical Biochemistry
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: CHEM 371. Recommended: CHEM 351.
classes.desc: Principles of biochemistry and physical chemistry applied to structure and function of biomacromolecules.  Emphasis on the techniques used in the study of protein/ligand binding, macromolecular structure and dynamics, and on understanding current literature.  3 lectures.

classes.name: Instrumental Analysis
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: CHEM 231/331, CHEM 354. Recommended: CHEM 353.
classes.desc: Theory, practice and method selection of modern instrumental analytical techniques, including spectroscopic, electrochemical, chromatographic and thermal methods.  Current industrial applications.  Laboratory work emphasizes optimization of experimental parameters.  3 lectures, 2 laboratories.

classes.name: Bioinformatics Applications
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: BIO 302, BIO 303, BIO 351, or CHEM 373.
classes.desc: Introduction to new problems in molecular biology and current computer applications for genetic database analyses.  Use of software for:  nucleic acid, genome and protein sequence analysis; genetic databases, database tools; industrial applications in bioinformatics; ethical and societal concerns.  3 lectures, 1 laboratory.  Crosslisted as BIO/CHEM 441.

classes.name: Polymers & Coatings I
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: CHEM 212/312 or CHEM 216/316.
classes.desc: Physical properties of polymers and coatings and their measurement.  Molecular weight averages, glass transition, thermodynamics of polymers.  Viscoelastic properties, rheology, molecular weight determination.  Thermal analysis, spectroscopic analysis, mechanical testing.  3 lectures.

classes.name: Polymers & Coatings II
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: CHEM 217/317 and CHEM 444.
classes.desc: Introduction to polymerization methods and mechanisms.  Chemistry of initiators, catalysts and inhibitors, kinetics of polymerization.  Uses of representative polymer types.  Synthesis, film formation, structure and properties of polymers commonly used in coatings and adhesives.  3 lectures.

classes.name: Surface Chemistry of Materials
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: CHEM 125 or CHEM 128; CHEM 351, MATE 380, or ME 302.
classes.desc: Surface energy.  Capillarity, solid and liquid interface, adsorption.  Surface areas of solids.  Contact angles and wetting.  Friction, lubrication and adhesion.  Relationship of surface to bulk properties of materials.  Applications.  3 lectures.  Crosslisted as CHEM/MATE 446.

classes.name: Polymers and Coatings Laboratory I
classes.pre_reqs: Corequisite: CHEM 444.
classes.desc: Experimental techniques of producing and characterizing coatings.  Polymer characterization and analysis.  Molecular weight analysis using viscometry, light scattering, and gel permeation chromatography.  Thermal analysis using differential scanning calorimetry, thermal mechanical analysis and dynamic mechanical analysis.  Polymer rheology.  Infrared, Raman and FT-NMR spectroscopy.  Atomic force microscopy.  2 laboratories.

classes.name: Polymers and Coatings Laboratory II
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: CHEM 447. Corequisite: CHEM 445.
classes.desc: Polymer synthesis using solution, suspension, bulk, emulsion techniques.  Synthesis of chain growth polymers using free radical, anionic, cationic, and other catalysts.  Synthesis of step-growth polymers.  Kinetics of polymer reactions.  Synthesis of resins used in modern coatings.  2 laboratories.

classes.name: Polymers and Coatings Internship
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: CHEM 444.
classes.desc: Selected students will spend up to 12 weeks with an approved polymers and coatings firm engaged in production or related business.  Time will be spent applying and developing production and technical skills and abilities in the polymers and coatings industry.

classes.name: Polymers and Coatings III
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: CHEM 444 or CHEM 544.
classes.desc: Formulation of modern coatings.  Raw materials including resins, solvents, pigments, and additives.  Formulation principles for solvent-borne and coatings, waterborne, powder, radiation cure and architectural coatings.  Regulatory issues; VOC's.  Coating properties, film formation, film defects, application methods, color and color acceptance.  Not open to students with credit in CHEM 550.  3 lectures.

classes.name: Polymers and Coatings Laboratory III
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: CHEM 447 or CHEM 547. Corequisite: CHEM 450. Recommended: CHEM 445 or CHEM 545; CHEM 448 or CHEM 548; CHEM 446.
classes.desc: Preparation and characterization of coatings - solvent based and waterborne.  Thermoplastic and thermosetting coatings.  Coating film preparation methods.  Applications of spectroscopy, scanning probe microscopy, thermal analysis, rheology in characterizing coatings.  VOC, long-term exposure testing.  Measurement of appearance (color, gloss).  Not open to students with credit in CHEM 551.  2 laboratories.

classes.name: Functional Polymeric Materials
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: CHEM 212 or CHEM 216 or CHEM 312 or CHEM 316; CHEM 351 or MATE 380; or graduate standing.
classes.desc: Structure-property-processing correlations of functional polymeric materials.  Additive group contribution methodologies for predicting and determining physical properties.  Semi-empirical approaches for estimating and evaluating the values of physical properties from chemical structures.  4 lectures.

classes.name: Instrumental Organic Qualitative Analysis
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: CHEM 324.
classes.desc: Separation, purification, and identification of organic molecules using chemical and instrumental methods, including nuclear magnetic resonance, infrared and ultraviolet spectroscopy and mass spectroscopy, and techniques in high resolution FT-NMR.  1 lecture, 2 laboratories.

classes.name: Undergraduate Seminar
classes.pre_reqs: Corequisite: CHEM 218 or CHEM 318 and junior standing.
classes.desc: Oral presentation of current developments in chemistry based on current literature.  Searching for, organizing and presenting developments from current literature in chemistry and biochemistry.  Preparation for employment and for independent work, including senior project, in chemistry and biochemistry.  2 seminars.

classes.name: Senior Project Report
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: Consent of instructor.
classes.desc: Completion of a senior project report under faculty supervision.  Minimum 30 hours time commitment.

classes.name: Honors Research
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: Junior standing and consent of instructor.
classes.desc: Advanced laboratory research.  Results are presented in a poster session or other public forum.  Total credit limited to 2 units with a maximum of 1 unit per quarter.  1 laboratory.

classes.name: College Teaching Practicum
classes.pre_reqs: CR/NCPrerequisite: Junior standing, CHEM 231/331 (or permission of instructor), evidence of satisfactory preparation in chemistry; department chair approval required.
classes.desc: Teaching assignment in an undergraduate college classroom.  Includes teaching and related activities under the direction of a permanent faculty member in the Department of Chemistry and Biochemistry.  Total credit limited to 4 units.

classes.name: Learning Assistant Seminar
classes.pre_reqs: CR/NCPrerequisite: Junior standing and consent of instructor.
classes.desc: Pedagogical instruction and introduction to education research for Chemistry Learning Assistants.  Effective questioning, the effect of explanatory knowledge on student learning, student misconceptions in chemistry, collaborative problem solving techniques in chemistry, studio curriculum development, content in the general chemistry curriculum.  Total credit limited to 4 units.  Credit/No Credit grading only.  2 seminars.

classes.name: Selected Advanced Topics
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: CHEM 351, CHEM 217 or CHEM 317.
classes.desc: Directed group study of selected topics for advanced students.  Open to undergraduate and graduate students.  The Class Schedule will list topic selected.  Total credit limited to 8 units.  1 to 4 lectures.

classes.name: Selected Advanced Laboratory
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: Consent of instructor.
classes.desc: Directed group laboratory study of selected topics for advanced students.  Open to undergraduate and graduate students.  The Class Schedule will list topic selected.  Total credit limited to 8 units.  1 to 4 laboratories.

classes.name: Protein Techniques Laboratory
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: CHEM 371.
classes.desc: Experiments in protein purification and analysis from recombinant sources.  Ion-exchange and affinity chromatography, electrophoresis and blotting.  UV, chemical, immune, and fluorescent detection.  Enzyme kinetic analysis.  1 lecture, 2 laboratories.

classes.name: Molecular Biology Laboratory
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: BIO 161, and grade of C- or better in BIO 351 or CHEM 373 or consent of instructor.
classes.desc: Introduction to techniques used in molecular biology and biotechnology; DNA extraction, characterization, cloning, Southern blotting, reverse transcription, polymerase chain reaction, and sequencing analysis.  1 lecture, 2 laboratories.  Crosslisted as BIO/CHEM 475.

classes.name: Gene Expression Laboratory
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: BIO/CHEM 475 with a grade of C- or better or consent of instructor; CHEM 313 or CHEM 371, or graduate standing in Biological Sciences.
classes.desc: Heterologous gene expression of a recombinant protein in a microbial system:  gene cloning, construction of expression plasmid, DNA sequence analysis, transformation of microbial host, selection and analysis of transformed host cells, expression and purification of recombinant protein.  1 lecture, 2 laboratories.  Crosslisted as BIO/CHEM 476.

classes.name: Biochemical Pharmacology
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: CHEM 218 or CHEM 318.
classes.desc: Consideration of current selected topics in pharmacology and drug targeting.  3 lectures.

classes.name: Inorganic Chemistry
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: CHEM 352 and CHEM 231/331.
classes.desc: A systematic study of chemical and physical properties of inorganic compounds based on periodic groupings with emphasis on chemical bonding and structure.  Topics will include coordination chemistry and kinetics, organometallic chemistry, advanced acid-base relationships and bonding theories plus other selected topics.  3 lectures.

classes.name: Inorganic Chemistry Laboratory
classes.pre_reqs: Corequisite: CHEM 481.
classes.desc: Laboratory techniques in inorganic chemistry.  Synthetic and analytic techniques as applied to inorganic and organometallic chemistry.  2 laboratories.

classes.name: Cooperative Education Experience
classes.pre_reqs: CR/NCPrerequisite: Sophomore standing and consent of instructor.
classes.desc: Part-time work experience in business, industry, government, and other areas of student career interest.  Positions are paid and usually require relocation and registration in course for two consecutive quarters.  Formal report and evaluation by work supervisor required.  2 units only applicable to approved chemistry electives.  Major credit limited to 4 units; total credit limited to 12 units.  Credit/No Credit grading only.

classes.name: Cooperative Education Experience
classes.pre_reqs: CR/NCPrerequisite: Sophomore standing and consent of instructor.
classes.desc: Full-time work experience in business, industry, government, and other areas of student career interest.  Positions are paid and usually require relocation and registration in course for two consecutive quarters.  Formal report and evaluation by work supervisor required.  2 units only applicable to approved chemistry electives.  Major credit limited to 4 units; total credit limited to 24 units.  Credit/No Credit grading only.

classes.name: Special Problems for Graduate Students
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: Graduate standing and consent of department chair.
classes.desc: Individual investigation, research, studies, or surveys of selected problems.  Total credit limited to 6 units, with a maximum of 3 units per quarter.

classes.name: Polymer Physical Chemistry and Analysis
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: CHEM 212/312 or CHEM 216/316 or equivalent; CHEM 351 or equivalent.
classes.desc: Physical properties of polymers and coatings and their measurement; molecular weight averages, glass transition, thermodynamics of polymers, viscoelastic properties, rheology; molecular weight determination, thermal analysis, spectroscopic analysis, mechanical testing, atomic force microscopy.  Special individual project.  Not open to students with credit in CHEM 444.  3 lectures.

classes.name: Polymer Synthesis and Mechanisms
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: CHEM 544.
classes.desc: Polymerization methods and mechanisms; chemistry of initiators, catalysts and inhibitors; use of representative types; synthesis, structure and properties of polymers commonly used in coatings and adhesives.  Special individual project.  Not open to students with credit in CHEM 445.  3 lectures.

classes.name: Polymer Characterization and Analysis Laboratory
classes.pre_reqs: Corequisite: CHEM 544.
classes.desc: Polymer characterization and analysis.  Molecular weight analysis using viscometry, light scattering, and gel permeation chromatography.  Thermal analysis using differential scanning calorimetry, thermal mechanical analysis and dynamic mechanical analysis.  Polymer rheology.  Infrared, Raman and FT-NMR spectroscopy.  Atomic force microscopy.  Special individual project.  Not open to students with credit in CHEM 447.  2 laboratories.

classes.name: Polymer Synthesis Laboratory
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: CHEM 547. Corequisite: CHEM 545.
classes.desc: Polymer synthesis using solution, suspension, bulk, emulsion techniques.  Synthesis of chain growth polymers using free radical, anionic, cationic, and other catalysts.  Synthesis of step-growth polymers.  Kinetics of polymer reactions.  Synthesis of resins used in modern coatings.  Special individual project.  Not open to students with credit in CHEM 448.  2 laboratories.

classes.name: Coatings Formulation Principles
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: CHEM 444 or CHEM 544.
classes.desc: Formulation of modern coatings.  Raw materials including resins, solvents, pigments, and additives.  Formulation principles for solvent-borne and high solids coatings, water-borne coatings, powder coatings, radiation cure coatings and architectural coatings.  Regulatory issues; VOC's.  Coating properties, film formation, film defects, application methods, color and color acceptance.  Special individual project.  3 lectures.

classes.name: Coatings Formulation Laboratory
classes.pre_reqs: Corequisite: CHEM 550.
classes.desc: Laboratory formulation of modern coatings.  Formation of pigment dispersions.  Formulation of solvent-borne and high solids coatings, water-borne coatings, powder coatings, radiation cure coatings and architectural coatings.  VOC measurements.  Measurement of coating properties, film formation, film defects, application methods, color and color acceptance, hiding, gloss.  Accelerated weathering.  Special individual project.  2 laboratories.

classes.name: Selected Advanced Topics
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: Graduate standing or consent of instructor.
classes.desc: Directed group study of selected topics for graduate students.  Open to undergraduate and graduate students.  The Schedule of Classes will list title selected.  Total credit limited to 8 units.  1-4 lectures.

classes.name: Selected Advanced Laboratory
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: Graduate standing or consent of instructor.
classes.desc: Directed group laboratory study of selected topics for advanced students.  Open to undergraduate and graduate students.  The Class Schedule will list topic selected.  Total credit limited to 8 units.  1 to 4 laboratories.

classes.name: Graduate Seminar in Polymers and Coatings
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: Graduate standing in the Polymers and Coatings program or consent of instructor.
classes.desc: Problems and topics in polymers and coatings selected according to the interest and needs of the students enrolled.  Total credit limited to 3 units.  1 seminar.

classes.name: Graduate Project
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: CHEM 545, CHEM 547, CHEM 548, CHEM 550, CHEM 551.
classes.desc: Supervised industrial graduate internship in polymers and coatings science.  Provides students with industrial research experience.  Requires approval of graduate advisor.  Students engage in industrial research and development at an approved industry, make regular reports back to graduate advisor, and present formal report and seminar on work each quarter.  Total credit limited to 9 units.

classes.name: Graduate Thesis
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: CHEM 545, CHEM 547, CHEM 548, CHEM 550, CHEM 551.
classes.desc: Directed graduate research in specialized advanced topics related to polymers and coatings science, leading to a graduate thesis of suitable quality.  Requires approval of graduate advisor.  Students are expected to work independently and report weekly to faculty advisor.  Total credit limited to 9 units.

classes.name: Orientation to the Child Development Major
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: CD majors only.
classes.desc: Introduction to the child development major, self-assessments, career opportunities, university and community resources, and the program at Cal Poly.  Course may be offered in classroom-based or online format.  2 lectures.

classes.name: Observing and Interacting with Children
classes.desc: Observation methods and guidance techniques for adults working with children in family, community, and educational settings. 3 lectures, 1 activity.

classes.name: Special Problems
classes.desc: Supervised investigation, including a written report, of a topic chosen with prior approval of instructor. Total credit limited to 6 units, with a maximum of 4 units per quarter.

classes.name: Children's Learning and Development in Educational Settings
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: Sophomore standing; PSY 201 or PSY 202 or admission to the university with the intent to enter the MSTEP Program.
classes.desc: Study of theories and research about the development and learning of children and young adolescents within diverse backgrounds, and application to teaching in public school settings.  Observations/interactions with children in school settings.  3 lectures, 1 activity.  Participation in public schools requires mandated fingerprint clearance.  Crosslisted as CD/EDUC 207.

classes.name: Preschool Laboratory
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: CD 131 and CD/PSY 256.
classes.desc: Preliminary teaching experience with children in a preschool laboratory setting.  Participant planning, execution and evaluation of age-appropriate activities.  Observation is used as the basis for planning for the development of the whole child.  2 lecture, 2 laboratories.

classes.name: Family Psychology
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: PSY 201 or PSY 202.
classes.desc: Introduction to research and theory on family relationships and behavior across the lifespan.  Contextual influences, diversity of family forms, and topics such as love, mate selection, marital quality, parenting, gender, household work, divorce, and remarriage.  4 lectures.  Crosslisted as CD/PSY 254.

classes.name: Developmental Psychology
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: PSY 201 or PSY 202.
classes.desc: Introduction to the scientific study of development with emphasis on the lifespan, from infancy to old age.  Basic research and concepts in understanding social, emotional, cognitive, contextual, and diversity influences on development.  4 lectures.  Crosslisted as CD/PSY 256.

classes.name: Selected Topics
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: Open to undergraduate students and consent of instructor.
classes.desc: Directed group study of selected topics.  The Class Schedule will list topic selected.  Total credit limited to 8 units.  1 to 4 lectures.

classes.name: Developmental Science Technology Lab
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: CD 102 and CD/PSY 256. Co-requisite: Any 300-400 level CD course.
classes.desc: Technology applications (e.g., websites, film, podcasts, blogs) as they relate to communication of research and theory in developmental science.  Digital tools used by developmental researchers and professionals when working with children, youth, and families.  2 laboratories.

classes.name: Infant and Toddler Development
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: CD/PSY 256.
classes.desc: Human development from conception through the second year of life.  Examination of theory and research in multiple domains of development.  Consideration of environments and activities which enhance the emerging capabilities of infants and toddlers.  4 lectures.

classes.name: Early and Middle Childhood Development
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: CD/PSY 256 or CD/EDUC 207.
classes.desc: In-depth study of theory and research on development in early and middle childhood, especially within physical, cognitive, social, and emotional domains.  Consideration of case studies and current practices in light of theoretical perspectives and current research.  4 lectures.

classes.name: Adolescence
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: CD/PSY 256 or CD/EDUC 207.
classes.desc: Psychological analysis of the years from prepubescence to young adulthood.  Current research on behavior and development during adolescence with emphasis on physical, affective, cognitive, sociocultural, historical, family, peer and school aspects of life during the post-child, pre-adult years.  4 lectures.  Crosslisted as CD/PSY 306.

classes.name: Research Methods in Child Development
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: PSY 256, STAT 217.
classes.desc: Introduction to research methods in child development.  Critically evaluating research literature, generating research questions, and conducting observations and interviews with children and adolescents.  3 lectures, 1 activity.

classes.name: Developmental Issues in Education
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: CD/EDUC 207 or PSY 256.
classes.desc: Current issues and research concerning how children and youth develop and learn in school.  Topics may include motivation, views of intelligence, teacher and student relations, constructivist learning environments, socioemotional learning, school climates, home-school connections.  4 lectures.

classes.name: Learning in Out-of-School Time
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: CD/PSY 256 or CD/EDUC 207.
classes.desc: How children and youth develop and learn in settings and activities outside of formal schooling, such as everyday family activities, informal learning institutions (e.g., museums), nature, and organized extracurricular activities.  Research findings and theoretical perspectives on how activity in such settings supports development and learning.  4 lectures.

classes.name: Behavioral Disorders in Childhood
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: PSY 201 or PSY 202; CD/PSY 256 or CD 305; and junior standing.
classes.desc: Applications of psychological principles to childhood behavioral disorders.  Aggression, delinquency, stress reactions, motivational, perceptual-attentional deficiencies, psychoses, anxiety disorders, biological dysfunctions, and social, emotional and intellectual disabilities.  4 seminars.  Crosslisted as CD/PSY 356.  Formerly CD 456.

classes.name: Special Problems for Advanced Undergraduates
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: Junior standing.
classes.desc: Supervised investigation, including a written report, of a topic chosen with prior approval of instructor.  Total credit limited to 6 units, with a maximum of 4 units per quarter.

classes.name: Children, Adolescents & Technology
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: CD 329; and two of the following: CD 304, 305, or CD 306.
classes.desc: Examination of research and theory on how use of digital technologies (e.g., electronic toys, television, video games, virtual reality, educational technologies, assistive technologies, social media) relates to children's and adolescents' development across domains.  4 lectures.  Formerly CD 413.

classes.name: Interpersonal Relationships in Childhood and Adolescence
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: CD 304, CD 305 or CD 306; or CD/PSY 256 and PSY 305.
classes.desc: Current theories and research on the development of interpersonal relationships in childhood and adolescence.  Topics may include parent-child relationships, peer relationships in childhood, intimate relationships in adolescence.  The Class Schedule will list topic selected.  Total credit limited to 8 units.  4 lectures.  Crosslisted as CD/PSY 417.

classes.name: Children's Development in Diverse Cultures
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: Two of the following: CD 304, CD 305, CD 306; junior standing or consent of instructor.
classes.desc: Examination of research on child and adolescent development in diverse families and community settings.  Topics include close examination of cultural communities in different countries (cross-cultural) and in the United States (multicultural) using sociocultural frameworks.  4 lectures.

classes.name: Assessing Children's Development and Environments
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: CD 304 or CD 305 or PSY 419 or PSY 420 or PSY 421; and CD 329 or PSY 329.
classes.desc: Current developmental and environmental assessments used in care and educational settings and in prevention programs and research.  Practice using, creating, and evaluating child assessments.  3 lectures, 1 activity.  Crosslisted as CD/PSY 431.

classes.name: Research Internship
classes.pre_reqs: CR/NCPrerequisite: CD 230 and CD 329.
classes.desc: Faculty-supervised research experience on various topics related to child and adolescent development.  Student apprenticeship with a department faculty member engaging in a research project.  Credit/No Credit grading only.  Formerly CD 333.

classes.name: Advanced Research Internship
classes.pre_reqs: CR/NCPrerequisite: CD 333 or CD 448.
classes.desc: Faculty-supervised research experience on various topics related to child and adolescent development.  Student apprenticeship with a department faculty member to conduct aspects of a research project.  Credit/No Credit grading only.  Formerly CD 433.

classes.name: Perspectives on Child and Adolescent Development
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: CD 304, CD 305, CD 306, CD 329 and senior standing.
classes.desc: Advanced study of theoretical perspectives and research on the development of children and adolescents and the implications for current practice and policy.  4 seminars.  Formerly CD 401.

classes.name: Supervised Fieldwork Internship
classes.pre_reqs: CR/NCPrerequisite: Psychology and Child Development majors only; CD 230, PSY 323, junior standing and consent of instructor.
classes.desc: Faculty supervised fieldwork experience.  Role of professional apprentice is experienced and analyzed by each student.  Credit/No Credit grading only.  Formerly CD 330.

classes.name: Advanced Supervised Fieldwork Internship
classes.pre_reqs: CR/NCPrerequisite: CD 330 or CD 453; and consent of instructor; Psychology and Child Development majors only.
classes.desc: Faculty-supervised preprofessional experience in a career-related setting which complements the CD 330 internship.  Such roles as master teacher, caseworker, therapeutic intern, administrative aide or program specialist are experienced and analyzed by each student.  Credit/No credit grading only.  Formerly CD 430.

classes.name: Child Abuse and Neglect
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: PSY 201 or PSY 202 and junior standing.
classes.desc: Issues in child maltreatment, including definitions and forms, causes, consequences, assessment, reporting, treatment, and prevention.  Possible links among research, intervention, and public policy will be emphasized.  4 seminars.  Crosslisted as CD/PSY 460.

classes.name: Senior Project Seminar
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: Completion of GWR and CD 329; Psychology and Child Development majors only.
classes.desc: Senior project expectations and skills.  Students work alone or in groups to identify appropriate topics, methods and content for the senior project; to be presented in a series of progress reports.  Begin literature reviews for completion in CD 462.  2 seminars.

classes.name: Senior Project
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: CD 461.
classes.desc: Completion of a project under faculty supervision.

classes.name: Selected Advanced Topics
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: Consent of instructor.
classes.desc: Directed group study of selected topics for advanced students.  Open to undergraduate and graduate students.  The Class Schedule will list topic selected.  Total credit limited to 8 units.  1 to 4 lectures.

classes.name: Elementary Mandarin Chinese I
classes.desc: Beginning Mandarin Chinese. Class practice and assigned outside work in pronunciation, sentence structure, reading, writing and introduction to Chinese culture. Not open to students with credit in CHIN 141. 3 lectures, 1 activity.

classes.name: Elementary Mandarin Chinese II
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: CHIN 101, CHIN 141, or appropriate score on placement exam or consent of instructor.
classes.desc: Class practice and assigned outside work in pronunciation, sentence structure, reading, writing and introduction to Chinese culture.  Not open to students with credit in CHIN 142.  3 lectures, 1 activity.

classes.name: Elementary Mandarin Chinese III
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: CHIN 102, CHIN 142, or appropriate score on placement exam or consent of instructor.
classes.desc: Class practice and assigned outside work in pronunciation, sentence structure, reading, writing and introduction to Chinese culture.  Not open to students with credit in CHIN 143.  3 lectures, 1 activity.

classes.name: Elementary Mandarin Chinese I Study Abroad
classes.pre_reqs: 2020-21 or later catalog: GE Area C22019-20 or earlier: GE Area C1 or C22019-20 or earlier: GE Area C1 or C22019-20 or earlier catalog: GE Area C5Prerequisite: Acceptance into the Cal Poly Global Program.
classes.desc: Beginning Mandarin Chinese.  Class practice and assigned outside work in pronunciation, sentence structure, reading, writing, and conversation.  Language taught in its intercultural context at a Cal Poly Global Program study center.  Not open to students with credit in CHIN 101.  3 lectures, 1 activity.  Fulfills GE Area C2 (GE Area C1, C2, or C5 for students on the 2019-20 or earlier catalogs).

classes.name: Elementary Mandarin Chinese II Study Abroad
classes.pre_reqs: 2020-21 or later catalog: GE Area C22019-20 or earlier: GE Area C1 or C22019-20 or earlier: GE Area C1 or C22019-20 or earlier catalog: GE Area C5Prerequisite: CHIN 101, CHIN 141, or appropriate score on placement exam; and acceptance into the Cal Poly Global Program.
classes.desc: Class practice and assigned outside work in pronunciation, sentence structure, reading, writing, and conversation.  Language taught in its intercultural context at a Cal Poly Global Program study center.  Not open to students with credit in CHIN 102.  3 lectures, 1 activity.  Fulfills GE Area C2 (GE Area C1, C2, or C5 for students on the 2019-20 or earlier catalogs).

classes.name: Elementary Mandarin Chinese III Study Abroad
classes.pre_reqs: 2020-21 or later catalog: GE Area C22019-20 or earlier: GE Area C1 or C22019-20 or earlier: GE Area C1 or C22019-20 or earlier catalog: GE Area C5Prerequisite: CHIN 102, CHIN 142, or appropriate score on placement exam; and acceptance into the Cal Poly Global Program.
classes.desc: Class practice and assigned outside work in pronunciation, sentence structure, reading, writing, and conversation.  Language taught in its intercultural context at a Cal Poly Global Program study center.  Not open to students with credit in CHIN 103.  3 lectures, 1 activity.  Fulfills GE Area C2 (GE Area C1, C2, or C5 for students on the 2019-20 or earlier catalogs).

classes.name: Intermediate Mandarin Chinese I
classes.pre_reqs: 2019-20 or earlier catalog: GE Area C5Prerequisite: CHIN 103, CHIN 143, or appropriate score on placement exam or consent of instructor.
classes.desc: Development of presentational, interpersonal, and interpretive intermediate-level language skills in Mandarin Chinese within an intercultural context.  Not open to students with credit in CHIN 241.  3 lectures, 1 activity.  Fulfills GE Electives - Area C (GE Area C5 for students on the 2019-20 or earlier catalogs).

classes.name: Intermediate Mandarin Chinese II
classes.pre_reqs: 2019-20 or earlier catalog: GE Area C5Prerequisite: CHIN 201, CHIN 241, or appropriate score on placement exam or consent of instructor.
classes.desc: Development of presentational, interpersonal, and interpretive intermediate-level language skills in Mandarin Chinese within an intercultural context.  Not open to students with credit in CHIN 242.  3 lectures, 1 activity.  Fulfills GE Electives - Area C (GE Area C5 for students on the 2019-20 or earlier catalogs).

classes.name: Intermediate Mandarin Chinese III
classes.pre_reqs: 2019-20 or earlier catalog: GE Area C5Prerequisite: CHIN 202, CHIN 242, or appropriate score on placement exam or consent of instructor.
classes.desc: Development of presentational, interpersonal, and interpretive intermediate-level language skills in Mandarin Chinese within an intercultural context.  Not open to students with credit in CHIN 243.  3 lectures, 1 activity.  Fulfills GE Electives - Area C (GE Area C5 for students on the 2019-20 or earlier catalogs).

classes.name: Intermediate Mandarin Chinese I Study Abroad
classes.pre_reqs: 2020-21 or later catalog: GE Area C22019-20 or earlier: GE Area C1 or C22019-20 or earlier: GE Area C1 or C22019-20 or earlier catalog: GE Area C5Prerequisite: CHIN 103, CHIN 143, or appropriate score on placement exam; and acceptance into the Cal Poly Global Program.
classes.desc: Development of presentational, interpersonal, and interpretive intermediate-level language skills in Mandarin Chinese.  Language taught in its intercultural context at a Cal Poly Global Program study center.  Not open to students with credit in CHIN 201.  3 lectures, 1 activity.  Fulfills GE Area C2 (GE Area C1, C2, or C5 for students on the 2019-20 or earlier catalogs).

classes.name: Intermediate Mandarin Chinese II Study Abroad
classes.pre_reqs: 2020-21 or later catalog: GE Area C22019-20 or earlier: GE Area C1 or C22019-20 or earlier: GE Area C1 or C22019-20 or earlier catalog: GE Area C5Prerequisite: CHIN 201, CHIN 241, or appropriate score on placement exam; and acceptance into the Cal Poly Global Program.
classes.desc: Development of presentational, interpersonal, and interpretive intermediate-level language skills in Mandarin Chinese.  Language taught in its intercultural context at a Cal Poly Global Program study center.  Not open to students with credit in CHIN 202.  3 lectures, 1 activity.  Fulfills GE Area C2 (GE Area C1, C2, or C5 for students on the 2019-20 or earlier catalogs).

classes.name: Intermediate Mandarin Chinese III Study Abroad
classes.pre_reqs: 2020-21 or later catalog: GE Area C22019-20 or earlier: GE Area C1 or C22019-20 or earlier: GE Area C1 or C22019-20 or earlier catalog: GE Area C5Prerequisite: CHIN 202, CHIN 242, or appropriate score on placement exam; and acceptance into the Cal Poly Global Program.
classes.desc: Development of presentational, interpersonal, and interpretive intermediate-level language skills in Mandarin Chinese.  Language taught in its intercultural context at a Cal Poly Global Program study center.  Not open to students with credit in CHIN 203.  Fulfills GE Area C2 (GE Area C1, C2, or C5 for students on the 2019-20 or earlier catalogs).

classes.name: Basic Graphic Skills
classes.desc: Basic techniques used in graphic communication for representation of the real world on two-dimensional planes. Use of scale, drawing conventions, orthographic and isometric projections, perspective drawings. Basic design and site analysis skills. Sketching, delineation and rendering including the use of black and white and color techniques. 4 laboratories.

classes.name: Urban Design Studio I
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: CRP 201.
classes.desc: Exploring elements and principles of environmental design.  Understanding the form and character of the designed urban environment.  Introduction to problem analysis and problem solving in environmental design.  Implications of design decisions and solutions on urban context.  Assignments of object, project and system scale in an urban context.  4 laboratories.

classes.name: Urban Design Studio II
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: CRP 202 and CRP 204.
classes.desc: Applications of basic design fundamentals and skills to the design of environments through design exercises applied to planning.  Problem analysis and problem solving skills as applied to environmental design issues.  4 laboratories.

classes.name: Theories and Methods of Urban Design
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: CRP 201. Corequisite: CRP 202.
classes.desc: Definition/nature of urban design:  a typology of procedures and products.  Urban design as a field between planning, architecture, and landscape architecture.  Visual assessment and townscape movement.  Environmental perception, behavior and spatial fit.  Typo-morphology and the architecture of the city.  1 lecture, 2 activities.

classes.name: Cities: Form, Culture and Evolution
classes.desc: Historical overview of the evolution of cities - how the form and function of cities evolved among different societies from antiquity to contemporary times. Includes early cities in Mesopotamia, Central America; Greece and Rome; Renaissance, Baroque; and North and South America. 4 lectures.

classes.name: Introduction to Urban Planning
classes.desc: Understanding the issues of contemporary urban growth and change. Development of theories of urban planning and design. Introduction to zoning, planning regulations and codes, and professional practice. Relationship of environmental design disciplines, citizen groups, and individuals to urban planning. 4 lectures.

classes.name: Population, Housing and Economic Applications
classes.desc: Collection, organization, and presentation of information and data related to population, housing and employment. Analytical applications to estimate population over time, housing demand by type and income and employment by standard classification. Application of urban economic theory related to jobs and housing. 3 lectures, 1 laboratory.

classes.name: Land Use and Transportation Studies
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: CRP 212.
classes.desc: How cities and regions work.  Relationship between human activities and patterns of land use and circulation.  Spatial analysis and location theories.  Methods for conducting studies to describe, analyze, and map land uses.  Regional-scale transportation analysis, traffic impact studies, and multimodal transportation plans.  3 lectures, 1 activity.

classes.name: Planning for and with Multiple Publics
classes.pre_reqs: USCPPrerequisite: Completion of GE Area D1. Recommended: ES 112.
classes.desc: How the social/spatial relationships among racial/ethnic and gender groups are expressed in terms of human settlement patterns, civic involvement and everyday negotiations.  Ways in which segregation and marginalization are expressed in western and non-western contexts.  4 lectures.  Crosslisted as CRP/ES 215.  Fulfills USCP.

classes.name: Representing the City
classes.desc: Introduction to the understanding and the represention of the city through different analog and digital media. 1 lecture, 1 laboratory.

classes.name: Selected Topics
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: Open to undergraduate students and consent of instructor.
classes.desc: Directed group study of selected topics.  The Class Schedule will list topic selected.  Total credit limited to 8 units.  1 to 4 lectures.

classes.name: Planning Theory
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: CRP 212.
classes.desc: Theories of planning.  Role of planner in society, purpose of planning, administrative framework in which planning takes place.  Alternative approaches to planning, values, ethics in planning.  Activities aimed at exploring communicative and participatory aspects of planning theory.  3 lectures, 1 activity.

classes.name: Fiscal and Project Feasibility
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: One course in GE Area D2 (or in GE Area D3 for students on the 2019-20 or earlier catalogs).
classes.desc: Analysis of the revenue streams and costs involved in project development.  Impact analysis of costs and revenues on private and public sectors included.  Construction of pro-formas for various project types.  3 lectures, 1 laboratory.

classes.name: Reflections on Biking, Walking and the City
classes.pre_reqs: 2020-21 or later: Upper-Div GE Area D2019-20 or earlier catalog: GE Area D5Prerequisite: Junior standing; completion of GE Area A with grades of C- or better; one course in GE Area B4 with a grade of C- or better (GE Area B1 for students on the 2019-20 or earlier catalogs); and one lower-division course in GE Area D.
classes.desc: Study of the design of cities for walking and bicycling and its importance to the future of transportation and the resilience of cities.  Reflection on how bicycles and pedestrians shape the urban environment through literature, music, policy, and design practices.  4 lectures.  Fulfills GE Upper-Division D (GE Area D5 for students on the 2019-20 or earlier catalogs).

classes.name: Cities in a Global World
classes.pre_reqs: 2020-21 or later: Upper-Div GE Area D2019-20 or earlier catalog: GE Area D5Prerequisite: Junior standing; completion of GE Area A with grades of C- or better; one course in GE Area B4 with a grade of C- or better (GE Area B1 for students on the 2019-20 or earlier catalogs); and two lower-division courses in GE Area D.
classes.desc: Examination of the changes in the social and spatial organization of urban settlements in the twenty-first century caused by the urbanization and globalization processes.  Comparative analysis of the traditional and contemporary cities around the globe.  Course may be offered in classroom-based or online format.  4 lectures.  Fulfills GE Upper-Division D (GE Area D5 for students on the 2019-20 or earlier catalogs).

classes.name: Introduction to Environmental Planning
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: CRP 212.
classes.desc: Examination of the challenges that arise when human and natural systems interact and the tools planners have to manage this interaction.  Relevant principles from a variety of disciplines are used to assess environmental problems and identify solutions in human-dominated systems.  4 lectures.

classes.name: Digital Cities
classes.pre_reqs: 2020-21 or later: Upper-Div GE Area B2019-20 or earlier catalog: GE Area B5, B6, or B7Prerequisite: Junior standing; completion of GE Area A with grades of C- or better; and completion of GE Areas B1 through B4, with a grade of C- or better in one course in GE Area B4 (GE Area B1 for students on the 2019-20 or earlier catalogs).
classes.desc: Explores changes in urban form and urban experience associated with advances in digital technology.  Implications for the design of places and the distribution of economic and social benefit.  Lecture-discussions and opportunities to explore technology initiatives in community building.  Course may be offered in classroom-based or online format.  4 lectures.  Fulfills GE Area Upper-Division B (GE Areas B5, B6, or B7 for students on the 2019-20 catalog).

classes.name: Urban Design Studio III
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: CRP 203; CRP 213; and CRP 214.
classes.desc: Urban design theories and methods related to planning and urban development.  Integration of circulation, environmental, land-use, and design aspects.  Infill or new development projects at the scale of a neighborhood, large PUD, complex circulation corridor, small town or planned community.  4 laboratories.

classes.name: Environmental Planning Methods
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: CRP 336.
classes.desc: Case studies and applications of theory and methods to regional and environmental systems.  Interrelationships between natural, economic, and social and political systems.  Application of California Environmental Quality Act and environmental impact assessment methods.  Environmental equity and sustainable bioregions.  2 lectures, 2 laboratories.

classes.name: Introduction to Emergency Management in California
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: Completion of GE Area B1 (GE Area B3 for students on the 2019-20 or earlier catalogs) or GE Area D.
classes.desc: Emergency management emphasizing the Standardized Emergency Management System (SEMS) and Emergency Operations Center (EOC) operations.  Earthquake hazard used as the case to explore potential wide geographic impacts, multiple secondary hazards, and multidisciplinary problem-solving methods in natural disasters faced by local governments and communities.  2 lectures, 1 activity.  Crosslisted as CRP/NR 351.

classes.name: Special Problems for Advanced Undergraduates
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: Consent of instructor.
classes.desc: Individual or group investigation, research, studies, or surveys of selected problems.  Total credit limited to 4 units, with a maximum of 2 units per quarter.

classes.name: Disaster Recovery
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: CRP/NR 351.
classes.desc: Strategies and procedures for public sector management of recovery from disasters.  Understanding the role of, and relationship between, federal, state and local agencies to provide assistance to individuals and communities in the post-disaster environment.  Issues in the recovery process.  2 lectures, 1 activity.  Crosslisted as CRP/NR 401.

classes.name: Contemporary Urban Design
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: Completion of GE Area A2 with a grade of C- or better (GE Area A1 for students on the 2019-20 or earlier catalogs) and CRP 341; or graduate standing.
classes.desc: Study of contemporary urban design through the detailed examination of major city/country case studies.  Analysis of the cultural, social and political factors influencing the practice of urban design and its major trends in different countries.  4 lectures.

classes.name: Environmental Law
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: Junior standing.
classes.desc: Detailed examination of the law governing use and protection of natural resources with focus on the legal institutions entrusted with the public duty of protecting the environment.  4 lectures.  Crosslisted as CRP/NR 404.

classes.name: Water Resource Law and Policy
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: Junior standing.
classes.desc: Detailed examination of the various legal systems of water use, regulation and management in California and the United States.  Discussion on the key concepts and principles of state, federal and interstate water quantity and quality control; focusing on issues and problems, why conflicts occur and how solutions evolve.  4 lectures.  Crosslisted as CRP/NR 408.

classes.name: Planning Internship
classes.pre_reqs: CR/NCPrerequisite: Consent of instructor.
classes.desc: Work experience as a supervised employee in a planning-related agency or private firm.  Prior contract specifying the product of internship required between student, agency and faculty.  Sixty hours work experience for two units of credit.  Credit/No Credit grading.

classes.name: Community Planning Laboratory I
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: CRP 336, CRP 341 or consent of instructor.
classes.desc: Application of planning theory and methods to the analysis and creation of community plans.  Interrelationships in the natural and built environments related to land use, circulation, social and other conditions.  Includes field trips and individual, team and interdisciplinary approaches.  4 laboratories.

classes.name: Community Planning Lab II
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: CRP 342, CRP 410, or consent of instructor.
classes.desc: Continuation of CRP 410.  Application of planning theory and methods to the analysis and creation of community plans.  Interrelationships in the natural and built environments related to land use, circulation, social and other conditions.  Includes field trips and individual, team and interdisciplinary approaches.  4 laboratories.

classes.name: Plan Implementation
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: CRP 212.
classes.desc: Theory and practice of plan implementation.  Regulation and nonregulatory approaches to plan implementation, including development regulation, economic development, growth management, habitat conservation planning, capital improvement planning, redevelopment programs, and transportation system management.  The California Specific Plan will serve as the course model.  4 lectures.

classes.name: Land Use Law
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: CRP 212 and upper division standing.
classes.desc: Public controls protecting natural environmental systems.  Land use and environmental controls.  Review of control mechanisms.  State and federal legislation.  Legal implications of controls, public planning and policy issues.  4 lectures.

classes.name: Planning Healthy Communities
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: Junior standing; completion of GE Area A with grades of C- or better; and completion of two lower division GE Area D courses.
classes.desc: Introduction to advanced topics on the relationship between the built environment and public health, assessment methods, and planning approaches to creating healthier communities.  4 lectures.

classes.name: International Planning and Development
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: Junior standing. Recommended: CRP 334.
classes.desc: Comparative assessment of planning for international development to improve the quality of life of people in cities and regions around the world.  Critical analysis of theories and practices underlying programs and projects and their pertinence to the United States.  4 lectures.

classes.name: Professional Planning Practice
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: CRP 212.
classes.desc: Relationships of planning organizations to other governmental bodies, public agencies and citizen groups.  Working in a public planning agency and private practice.  Current topics in planning practice.  3 lectures.

classes.name: Transportation Theory
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: CRP 212, senior standing, or graduate standing.
classes.desc: Circulation and transportation elements of the General Plan.  Transportation planning theory, methods and tools related to systematic analysis of city and regional transportation problems including environmental impact assessment.  Application of techniques for assessing transportation systems, gravity models, route selections, land use models and relationship to transportation.  3 seminars, 1 activity.

classes.name: Collaborative Planning
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: CRP 212 or graduate standing.
classes.desc: Focus on processes and skills of citizen participation and consensus building.  Application of mediation and negotiation techniques.  Use of collaboration in forming visions of the future and reaching agreements among multiple interests.  Use of group process skills to establish effective communication and agreements.  Organizing and operating public meetings.  3 lectures, 1 laboratory.

classes.name: Climate Action Planning
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: Junior standing or graduate standing.
classes.desc: Introduction of the planning role in reducing greenhouse gas emissions and adapting to climate change.  Basic climate science, greenhouse gas emissions inventories, politics of climate change, and federal/state policy.  Focus on development and implementation of local climate action plans.  4 lectures.

classes.name: Housing and Planning
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: Junior standing.
