Integration of scheduling, estimating, and construction subcontracts with a project based approach.  3 laboratories, 2 activities.

classes.name: Jobsite Construction Management
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: CM 313.
classes.desc: Management activities applicable to the construction process involving techniques, applications, and theory needed in a jobsite environment.  Addresses the relationships, roles, and perspectives of all stakeholders.  Integrated utilization of temporary structures associated with field construction.  3 laboratories, 2 activities.

classes.name: Integrated Project Delivery
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: CM 413 and CM 480.
classes.desc: Team based collaborative effort to analyze and evaluate the unique interdisciplinary challenges associated with coordinating and integrating the design and construction processes to deliver a project with respect to the design, budget, schedule, quality, and performance expectations of a client.  Not open to students with credit in CM 450.  4 laboratories.

classes.name: Service / Experiential Learning
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: Third-year standing.
classes.desc: Service and project-based learning and teaching techniques as applied to a variety of construction management concepts.  Goals and objectives achieved through service-learning, project-based, and/or experiential pedagogical approaches.  The Class Schedule will list topic selected.  Total credit limited to 8 units.  1-6 activities.

classes.name: Emerging Trends
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: Third-year standing.
classes.desc: Emerging trends related to construction management concepts and practices.  Goals and objectives achieved through analysis, study, and research of a particular construction emerging trend.  The Class Schedule will list topic selected.  Total credit limited to 8 units.  1 to 6 activities.

classes.name: Professional Preparation
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: Third-year standing.
classes.desc: Professional practice related to the construction management industry.  Goals and objectives achieved through analysis, study, and preparation for a particular professional practice.  The Class Schedule will list topic selected.  Total credit limited to 8 units.  1 to 6 activities.

classes.name: Construction Materials / Assemblies
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: Third-year standing.
classes.desc: Various materials and assemblies related to construction process.  Goals and objectives achieved through analysis, study, and research of a particular construction material and/or assembly.  The Class Schedule will list topic selected.  Total credit limited to 8 units.  1 to 6 activities.

classes.name: Construction Technology
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: Third-year standing.
classes.desc: Technology related to construction management education and the construction industry.  Goals and objectives achieved through analysis, study, and research of a particular construction technology.  The Class Schedule will list topic selected.  Total credit limited to 8 units.  1 to 6 activities.

classes.name: Sustainability and Environment
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: Third-year standing.
classes.desc: Sustainable and environmental issues related to the construction industry.  Goals and objectives achieved through analysis of a particular construction related sustainable and/or environmental issue.  The Class Schedule will list topic selected.  Total credit limited to 8 units.  1 to 6 activities.

classes.name: International Construction Studies
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: Third-year standing.
classes.desc: Exploration of international construction studies through several potential teaching techniques, including field trips to countries overseas, research and case studies of companies and projects, and management skills and leadership as they relate to international construction.  The Class Schedule will list topic selected.  Total credit limited to 8 units.  1 to 6 activities.

classes.name: Heavy Civil Temporary Structures and Shoring
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: ARCE 315 or CE 352; and CM 314.
classes.desc: Design and construction of retaining walls, concrete formwork, falsework, scaffolding, ramps, platform, bracing, and guying as applied to heavy civil projects.  Field trip may be required.  2 lectures, 2 laboratories.  Crosslisted as CE/CM 436.

classes.name: Heavy Civil Projects and Equipment
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: CM 314.
classes.desc: Heavy civil projects logistics, construction, operations, planning, management, workflow and sequencing, equipment management, fleet configuration and maintenance, equipment productivity and cost optimization.  2 lectures, 2 laboratories.  Crosslisted as CE/CM 437.

classes.name: Management of the Construction Firm
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: CM 334; CM 335; and CM 413.
classes.desc: Applications of strategic management techniques and business strategy for managing and long-range planning of the construction firm.  3 activities.

classes.name: Integrated Project, Design and Program Management
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: STAT 251 or STAT 312, CM 313 and CM 334.
classes.desc: Evaluation of roles and relationships of owner, designer, and construction professionals over project life cycles.  Modeling, conceptual estimating, lean scheduling, contract selection, integrated delivery, design management, program management, and influential leadership strategies and techniques.  Not open to students with credit in CM 415.  3 laboratories, 2 activities.

classes.name: Senior Project Methodology
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: CM 313; junior standing; Construction Management majors only.
classes.desc: Introduction to senior project processes, timelines, requirements, and best practices including topic selection, literature review, methodology, and paper formatting.  2 lectures.

classes.name: Senior Project I
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: CM 460 and consent of project advisor. See department for additional guidelines and requirements.
classes.desc: Selection and completion of a comprehensive project under faculty supervision.  Problems to involve the student's technical and creative skills.  Student proposal must be submitted and approved by project advisor prior to registration for course.  Construction and team projects encouraged.

classes.name: Senior Project II
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: CM 460 and consent of project advisor. See department for additional guidelines and requirements.
classes.desc: Selection and completion of a comprehensive project under faculty supervision.  Problems to involve the student's technical and creative skills.  Student proposal must be submitted and approved by project advisor prior to registration for course.  Construction and team projects encouraged.

classes.name: Senior Project: Professional Practice for Constructors
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: CM 413. Corequisite: CM 443.
classes.desc: Practical application of construction management theory and practice solving problems related to the built environment.  3 laboratories.

classes.name: Selected Advanced Topics
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: Consent of instructor.
classes.desc: Directed group study of selected topics for advanced students.  Open to undergraduate and graduate students.  The Class Schedule will list topic selected.  Total credit limited to 8 units.  1 to 4 lectures.

classes.name: Selected Advanced Laboratory
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: Consent of instructor.
classes.desc: Directed group laboratory study of selected topics for advanced students.  Open to undergraduate and graduate students.  The Class Schedule will list topic selected.  Total credit limited to 8 units.  1 to 4 laboratories.

classes.name: Real Property Development Principles
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: Minimum junior standing.
classes.desc: Development process and its major actors:  investors, developers, government agencies, environmental and local stakeholders; their development roles, objectives, approaches.  Basics of urban markets and economics, financing, regulation, public planning; value added, contractual, environmental and community context factors.  4 lectures.

classes.name: Preconstruction Integration and Planning
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: CM 313.
classes.desc: Examination of the role of preconstruction services, team integration, and joint design planning in several Integrated Project Delivery (IPD) approaches.  Various tools and techniques associated with preconstruction services and design planning from the proposal stage through the design stages of a project.  2 activities.

classes.name: Cooperative Education Experience
classes.pre_reqs: CR/NCPrerequisite: Consent of instructor.
classes.desc: Full-time work experience in an area directly related to the construction industry for 3 months.  Positions are paid and usually require relocation and registration in course for one quarter.  Registration in course is required at start of work experience.  Formal report and evaluation by work supervisor required.  Credit/No Credit grading only.  May be repeated for credit.  Major credit limited to 6 units; total credit limited to 12 units.  See department for additional requirements.

classes.name: Cooperative Education Experience
classes.pre_reqs: CR/NCPrerequisite: Consent of instructor.
classes.desc: Full-time work experience in an area directly related to the construction industry for 6 months.  Positions are paid and usually require relocation for two consecutive quarters.  Registration in course is required at start of work experience.  Formal report and evaluation by work supervisor required.  Credit/No Credit grading only.  May be repeated for credit.  Major credit limited to 6 units; total credit limited to 24 units.  See department for additional requirements.

classes.name: Principles of Integrated Facility Management
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: Consent of instructor.
classes.desc: Examination of the facility management profession and all functions associated with it, including strategic planning, financial planning, budgeting, project management, operations and maintenance, sustainability, and emergency preparedness, and how those functions interface with the overall goals of the business enterprise.  Course offered online only.  4 lectures.

classes.name: Construction Cost Estimating and Work Procurement
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: Consent of program coordinator.
classes.desc: Examination of the construction discipline of cost estimating and pre-construction activities, emphasizing both the core and higher functions associated with types of estimates, measuring and pricing, bidding procedures and strategies, procurement, pre-construction services, budget, and cost control analysis.  4 lectures.

classes.name: Construction Planning, Scheduling, and Impact Analysis
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: Consent of program coordinator.
classes.desc: Examination of the construction discipline of planning, scheduling, management, and control relating to both core and higher functions associated with network diagram analysis, CPM scheduling, project diagnostics, short interval, resource loaded, pull scheduling, forecasting, and earned value management techniques.  4 lectures.

classes.name: Construction Contracts and Law
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: Consent of program coordinator.
classes.desc: Examination of the discipline of law and contracts as they relate to the construction industry, including both the core and higher functions associated with the construction process, business organization, employment responsibilities, liability, damages, claims, dispute resolution, and risk management.  4 lectures.

classes.name: Construction Project Management and Control
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: Consent of program coordinator.
classes.desc: Examination of the discipline of construction project management and control relating to both the core and higher functions associated with the construction process, pre-construction services, and management in the areas of safety, quality, resource, risk, schedule, budget, changes, and value.  4 lectures.

classes.name: Construction Workforce, Productivity, and Safety
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: Consent of program coordinator.
classes.desc: Examination of the disciplines of workforce productivity and safety as they relate to the construction industry, including both the core and higher functions associated with field personnel management, construction operations, lean construction techniques, equipment utilization, productivity, and OSHA regulations.  4 lectures.

classes.name: Selected Advanced Topics in Construction Management
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: Graduate standing or consent of instructor.
classes.desc: Directed study of selected topics in Construction Management.  The Class Schedule will list topic selected.  Total credit limited to 12 units.  4 seminars.

classes.name: Selected Advanced Laboratory
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: Graduate standing or consent of instructor.
classes.desc: Directed group laboratory study of selected topics for advanced students.  Open to undergraduate and graduate students.  The Class Schedule will list topic selected.  Total credit limited to 8 units.  1 to 4 laboratories.

classes.name: Dairy Operations and Safety
classes.desc: Dairy farm biosecurity, animal handling and welfare, equipment operation, employee safety and hazard analysis. Instruction in standard operating procedures (SOP) relevant to milking, transition cow and calf management and cattle identification. 2 activities.

classes.name: Special Problems for Undergraduates
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: Consent of instructor.
classes.desc: Individual investigation, research, studies, or surveys of selected problems.  Total credit limited to 4 units, with a maximum of 2 units per quarter.

classes.name: Dairy Promotion and Marketing
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: DSCI 230 and DSCI 231.
classes.desc: National and state dairy promotional programs, advertising and merchandising.  Marketing and pricing of milk and dairy products at the state and national level.  4 lectures.

classes.name: General Dairy Husbandry
classes.desc: Selection, breeding, feeding, and management of dairy cattle. Composition and food value of dairy products. Milk pricing, political influences, dairy industry statistics and opportunities. Producing and handling products. Intended as introductory course for non-dairy science majors. 3 lectures, 1 laboratory.

classes.name: General Dairy Manufacturing
classes.desc: Composition and properties of fluid milk and manufactured milk products. Chemistry and microbiology of dairy products. Processes and equipment involved in the manufacture of butter, cheeses, and other fermented dairy products, frozen, condensed, and dried dairy foods. 3 lectures, 1 activity.

classes.name: Milk Processing and Inspection
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: DSCI 231, or FSN 125, or FSN 230.
classes.desc: Composition and properties of fluid milk and its constituents.  Equipment used to handle, process, and distribute fluid milk and related products.  California dairy codes used for dairy farms and plants, with practice inspections of dairy farms and factories.  3 lectures, 1 laboratory.

classes.name: Dairy Cattle Selection, Breeds, Fitting and Showing
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: DSCI 230.
classes.desc: Selection of dairy cattle on type conformation and the correlation between type and production.  Dairy cattle breeds and breed comparisons.  Techniques to properly condition, groom and present dairy cattle for evaluation and merchandising.  2 lectures, 2 activities.

classes.name: Selected Topics
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: Open to undergraduate students and consent of instructor.
classes.desc: Directed group study of selected topics.  The Class Schedule will list topic selected.  Total credit limited to 8 units.  1 to 4 lectures.

classes.name: Dairy Cattle Nutrition
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: ASCI 220 with a grade of C- or better or consent of instructor.
classes.desc: Nutrition principles to maximize milk production.  Ruminal/post ruminal digestion, post absorptive metabolism, nutrient interactions and microbiology.  Use of computer models to evaluate and formulate diets.  3 lectures, 1 activity.

classes.name: Lactation Physiology
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: ASCI 220; DSCI 230; and BIO 111 or BIO 161.
classes.desc: Mechanisms of milk component secretion, including protein, lactose and fat metabolism.  Disorders of the mammary gland (mastitis) and control strategies.  Endocrine aspects of mammary gland development and lactogenesis.  4 lectures.

classes.name: Artificial Insemination and Embryo Biotechnology
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: ASCI 229 or DSCI 230.
classes.desc: Techniques in the collection, evaluation and processing of semen, along with embryo culturing and manipulation.  Insemination procedures, fertility problems, record keeping, estrous synchronization, endocrine control of reproduction, treating reproductive disorders and embryo transfer.  3 lectures, 1 laboratory.

classes.name: Dairy Animal Health, Safety and Applied Technology
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: ASCI 220 and DSCI 230.
classes.desc: Application of principles of herd health, biosecurity, lactation physiology, cattle management and reproductive physiology to successful dairy operations.  Assessment of animal comfort and general health and well-being.  Practical techniques in safe animal handling.  3 lectures, 1 activity.

classes.name: Special Problems for Advanced Undergraduates
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: Consent of instructor.
classes.desc: Individual investigation, research, studies, or surveys of selected problems.  Total credit limited to 4 units, with a maximum of 2 units per quarter.

classes.name: Physical and Chemical Properties of Dairy Products
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: Junior standing. Recommended: CHEM 312.
classes.desc: Composition, structure and properties of milk and milk products.  Physical and chemical changes that occur during processing and storage of dairy products.  Objective measurement of chemical and physical properties.  3 lectures, 1 laboratory.

classes.name: Quality Assurance and Control of Dairy Products
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: Junior standing. Recommended: DSCI 444 or MCRO 421.
classes.desc: Current methods used to evaluate dairy products with respect to production plant economics and consumer safety.  Accurate procedures for chemical and biological testing, appropriate product sampling protocols.  Design and interpretation of HACCP programs for assuring product quality and safety.  3 lectures, 1 laboratory.

classes.name: Advanced Dairy Nutrition
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: ASCI 229; and ASCI 355 or DSCI 301.
classes.desc: Nutrient metabolism and diet formulation technologies for all classes of dairy cattle; whole-farm feed management; physiological and nutritional aspects of predominant metabolic disorders; on-farm auditing and troubleshooting of nutritional management.  Field trip required.  3 lectures, 1 laboratory.

classes.name: Dairy Farm Consultation
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: DSCI 333.
classes.desc: Student consultation teams of three or four students visit dairies and/or attend management training seminars followed by presenting management recommendations to the dairy owners, consultants, and other industry leaders.  1 seminar and supervised work.

classes.name: Breeding and Genetics of Dairy Cattle
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: DSCI 241, BIO 111 or higher, STAT 130 or higher.
classes.desc: Evaluation of inherited characteristics in dairy cattle, including principles of inheritance and genomic evaluations.  Proving and selecting sires and dams, dairy genetic evaluations.  4 lectures.

classes.name: Advanced Dairy Herd Management
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: DSCI 333.
classes.desc: Dairy herd management skills needed in dairy operations.  Instruction and lab experience in management, records, labor, waste management, and milking management.  4 lectures.

classes.name: Dairy Microbiology
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: DSCI 233; and MCRO 221 or MCRO 224; and STAT 130 or STAT 218; or graduate standing.
classes.desc: Microorganisms involved in the fermentation and ripening processes in the dairy industry, as well as those involved in spoilage of milk and dairy products, in the transmission of disease through these products, and indicator systems used to determine sanitary quality of these products.  3 lectures, 1 laboratory.

classes.name: Selected Advanced Topics
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: Consent of instructor.
classes.desc: Directed group study of selected topics for advanced students.  Open to undergraduate and graduate students.  The Class Schedule will list topic selected.  Total credit limited to 8 units.  1 to 4 lectures.

classes.name: Selected Advanced Laboratory
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: Consent of instructor.
classes.desc: Directed group laboratory study of selected topics for advanced students.  Open to undergraduate and graduate students.  The Class Schedule will list topic selected.  Total credit limited to 8 units.  1 to 4 laboratories.

classes.name: Individual Study in Dairy Science
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: Consent of department head, graduate advisor and supervising faculty member.
classes.desc: Advanced independent study planned and completed under the direction of a member of the Dairy Science faculty.  Total credit limited to 6 units.

classes.name: Dairy Chemistry
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: CHEM 212 or CHEM 312; admission to Master of Professional Studies program in Dairy Products Technology. Recommended: Differential and Integral Calculus.
classes.desc: Composition, structure/functional relationships and properties of milk, milk components and products.  Physical, chemical and biochemical changes that occur during processing, storage and use of milk and milk components.  Chemical, physical, functional and nutritional properties of milk components.  3 lectures.

classes.name: Dairy Chemistry Laboratory
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: DSCI 501; admission to Master of Professional Studies program in Dairy Products Technology.
classes.desc: Objective measurements, analysis and isolation of milk components.  Experimental demonstration of chemical and physical reactions of milk components during typical processing conditions.  2 laboratories.

classes.name: Dairy Foods: Issues and Practices
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: Admission to Master of Professional Studies program in Dairy Products Technology.
classes.desc: Contemporary issues in the dairy foods and allied industries.  Consumer, political, environmental, regulatory, producer, technological, scientific, and economic considerations critical to future industry leaders.  Required field trips to the dairy foods processing industry in California.  1 lecture, 1 activity.

classes.name: Dairy Processing and Manufacturing I
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: Admission to Master of Professional Studies program in Dairy Products Technology. Concurrent: DSCI 540.
classes.desc: Principles of unit operations involving heat and mass transfer including pasteurization and related thermal processes, centrifugal separation, concentration processes, churning and related high shear extrusion, fractionation processes, freezing, and drying technologies.  Pneumatic and mechanical devices and systems.  2 lectures, 1 laboratory.

classes.name: Dairy Processing and Manufacturing II
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: DSCI 520; admission to Master of Professional Studies program in Dairy Products Technology.
classes.desc: Unit operations in process systems for the efficient manufacture of fluid milk products, cream, butter, and concentrated milk.  Process variables and their control, system integration.  Use of processes to manipulate physical and chemical properties to influence product quality.  3 lectures, 1 laboratory.

classes.name: Dairy Processing and Manufacturing III
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: DSCI 520 and admission to Master of Professional Studies program in Dairy Products Technology.
classes.desc: Unit operations in process systems for the manufacture of fermented milk, cheese, frozen desserts, and dried milk and whey products.  3 lectures, 1 laboratory.

classes.name: Dairy Foods Ingredient Functionality
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: DSCI 501 and admission to Master of Professional Studies program in Dairy Products Technology.
classes.desc: Physical, chemical, and sensory properties of functional milk components when used in food products.  3 lectures, 1 laboratory.

classes.name: Graduate Internship in Dairy Science
classes.pre_reqs: CR/NCPrerequisite: Admission to Master of Professional Studies program in Dairy Products Technology and consent of instructor.
classes.desc: Practical work experience and management assignments in a dairy food processing company.  Credit/No Credit grading only.

classes.name: Graduate Dairy Microbiology
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: Admission to Master of Professional Studies program in Dairy Products Technology. Concurrent: DSCI 520. Recommended: MCRO 221 or equivalent.
classes.desc: Raw milk microbiological principles, pasteurization and microorganisms in diary foods safety, microbiological analysis of dairy products, fermented milks and cheese, starters and probiotics, commercial practices and sources of information for regulation on microbial aspects of dairy foods.  2 lectures, 2 laboratories.

classes.name: Quality Assurance, Quality Control and Food Safety
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: Admission to Master of Professional Studies program in Dairy Products Technology.
classes.desc: Concepts and methodologies used in dairy industry and dairy food plants for assurance and control of the quality of finished product.  Basis for understanding physical, chemical and microbiological methods as they apply to quality evaluation of dairy foods.  3 lectures, 1 laboratory.

classes.name: Recent Developments in Dairy Science and Technology
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: Senior or graduate standing and approval of instructor.
classes.desc: Presentation and critical review of current research publications.  Methodological advances and applications in dairy food systems.  The Class Schedule will list topic selected.  Total credit limited to 6 units.  1 to 3 seminars.

classes.name: Industrial Plant Considerations for Sustainable Operation
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: DSCI 520; admission to Master of Professional Studies program in Dairy Science Technology.
classes.desc: Plant site selection considerations, project management, plant design and layout, management of productivity maintenance, plant improvement project selection criteria, working with regulatory environment, community relations, and personal safety for overall industrial plant sustainability.  3 lectures, 1 activity.

classes.name: Selected Topics in Dairy Science
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: Graduate standing or consent of instructor.
classes.desc: Directed group study of selected topics for advanced students.  Open to undergraduate and graduate students.  Class Schedule will list topic selected.  Total credit limited to 12 units.  1 to 4 seminars.

classes.name: Selected Advanced Laboratory in Dairy Science
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: Consent of instructor.
classes.desc: Directed group laboratory study of selected topics for advanced students.  Open to undergraduate and graduate students.  The Class Schedule will list topic selected.  Total credit limited to 8 units.  1 to 4 laboratories.

classes.name: Graduate Seminar in Dairy Science
classes.pre_reqs: CR/NCPrerequisite: Admission to Master of Professional Studies program in Dairy Products Technology.
classes.desc: Current challenges in the field and their application to industry.  Group study of industry issues.  Current research findings as applied to production, leadership and marketing.  Total credit limited to 3 units.  Credit/No Credit grading only.  1 to 3 seminars.

classes.name: Dairy Processing and Plant Management
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: Admission to Master of Professional Studies program in Dairy Products Technology.
classes.desc: Dairy plant operation, processing experience and production team dynamics.  Practical training and experience in dairy plant operations to allow efficient, safe and sanitary processing of dairy products manufacture in a team environment.  Total credit limited to 4 units.  2 laboratories.

classes.name: Cooperative Education Experience in Dairy Science
classes.pre_reqs: CR/NCPrerequisite: Graduate standing and consent of instructor.
classes.desc: Advanced study, analysis and part-time work experience in the field; current innovations, practices, and problems in administration, supervision, and organization of business, industry, and government.  Must have demonstrated ability to do independent work and research in career field.  Total credit limited to 9 units.  Credit/No Credit grading only.

classes.name: Thesis in Dairy Science
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: Graduate standing.
classes.desc: Systematic research of a significant problem in Dairy Science.  Problem identification, significance, methods, data analysis, and conclusion.  Enrollment required every quarter in which facilities are used or advising is received.  Total credit limited to 9 units.

classes.name: Pilates and Conditioning Fundamentals
classes.desc: Introduction to the Pilates method and conditioning fundamentals. Exploration and practice of physical fitness, and the maintenance of a uniformly developed body. Purchase of concert ticket(s) may be required. Total credit limited to 6 units. 2 activities.

classes.name: Beginning Ballet
classes.desc: Fundamentals of ballet technique stressing alignment, turnout, basic positions and terminology. Purchase of concert ticket(s) may be required. Total credit limited to 6 units. 2 activities.

classes.name: Beginning Modern Dance
classes.desc: Fundamentals of modern technique stressing alignment, off-centered use of torso, floorwork, movement phrases, and improvisation exercises. Purchase of concert ticket(s) may be required. Total credit limited to 6 units. 2 activities.

classes.name: Beginning Jazz Dance
classes.desc: Introduction of jazz dance techniques stressing a variety of styles, alignment, isolation, polyrhythms, syncopation, improvisation and technical presentation of dance phrases. Purchase of concert ticket(s) may be required. Total credit limited to 6 units. 2 activities.

classes.name: Beginning Ballroom Dance
classes.desc: Focus on one or more selected ballroom dances including Cha-Cha, Foxtrot, Merengue, Rhumba, Samba, Swing, Tango, and/or Line Dances. Emphasis on alignment, etiquette, leading and following, history, performance techniques and presentation of dance phrases. Purchase of concert ticket(s) may be required. Total credit limited to 6 units. 2 activities.

classes.name: International Folk Dance
classes.desc: Introduction to international folk dances including round, longway, and square sets. Study of various dance steps, formation, positions, historical and cultural background. Purchase of concert ticket(s) may be required. Total credit limited to 6 units. 2 activities.

classes.name: Active Wellness
classes.pre_reqs: 2019-20 or later catalog: GE Area E2017-19 or earlier catalog: GE Area D4
classes.desc: Investigation of health and wellness ideologies and techniques for dancers and non-dancers through active participation in fitness circuits and lecture. Elements of fitness, injury prevention, somatic methodologies, anatomy, and body image will be presented and discussed to help students maintain and cultivate optimum health now and in the future. 3 lectures, 1 activity. Fulfills GE Area E (GE Area D4 for students on the 2017-19 or earlier catalogs).

classes.name: Dance Appreciation
classes.pre_reqs: 2020-21 or later catalog: GE Area C12019-20 or earlier catalog: GE Area C3
classes.desc: Introductory survey of major experiments in dance. Examination of history, philosophy, aesthetics, cultural context and criticism of diverse dance genres. Focus on major western dance artists from the 19th century to the present. Purchase of concert ticket(s) may be required. Course may be offered in classroom-based or online format. 4 lectures. Fulfills GE Area C1 (GE Area C3 for students on the 2019-20 or earlier catalogs).

classes.name: Intermediate Ballet
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: Intermediate level experience as determined by instructor at first class meeting.
classes.desc: Continuation of training in basic technical skills in ballet stressing phrasing, performance, and more complex step patterns.  Purchase of concert ticket(s) may be required.  Total credit limited to 6 units.  2 activities.

classes.name: Intermediate Modern Dance
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: Intermediate level experience as determined by instructor at first class meeting.
classes.desc: Continuing study of DANC 132 with emphasis on various movement styles, phrasing, more complex step patterns, and performance.  Purchase of concert ticket(s) may be required.  Total credit limited to 6 units.  2 activities.

classes.name: Intermediate Jazz Dance
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: Intermediate level experience as determined by instructor at first class meeting.
classes.desc: Continuation of DANC 133 with emphasis on more extensive movement vocabulary.  Purchase of concert ticket(s) may be required.  Total credit limited to 6 units.  2 activities.

classes.name: Intermediate Ballroom Dance
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: DANC 134 or intermediate level experience as determined by instructor at first class meeting.
classes.desc: Continuation of DANC 134.  Selected ballroom dances:  cha cha, foxtrot, merengue, rumba, swing, tango, hustle, paso doble, polka and samba.  Emphasis on variations, styles, and performance skill.  Purchase of concert ticket(s) may be required.  Total credit limited to 6 units.  2 activities.

classes.name: Selected Topics
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: Open to undergraduate students and consent of instructor.
classes.desc: Directed group study of selected topics.  The Class Schedule will list topic selected.  Total credit limited to 8 units.  1 to 4 lectures.

classes.name: Body Awareness and Expression
classes.desc: Directed group study of movement techniques and exercises to facilitate expressive physical performance. Body effectiveness, alignment and conditioning practice integrated with creative exploration and movement analysis of effort, spatial awareness and detailed body usage. 4 lectures. Crosslisted as DANC/TH 280.

classes.name: Cultural Influence on Dance in America
classes.pre_reqs: 2020-21 or later: Upper-Div GE Area C2019-20 or earlier catalog: GE Area C4USCPPrerequisite: Junior standing; completion of GE Area A with grades of C- or better; one course in GE Area B4 with a grade of C- or better (GE Area B1 for students on the 2019-20 or earlier catalogs); and completion of GE Area C1 (GE Area C3 for students on the 2019-20 or earlier catalogs).
classes.desc: Multicultural approach to history of dance in America, with emphasis on American Indian, West African, Caribbean, Mexican, European, and Asian contributions and influences.  Explores culture through dance.  Purchase of concert ticket(s) required.  4 lectures.  Fulfills GE Upper-Division C (GE Area C4 for students on the 2019-20 or earlier catalogs); and USCP.

classes.name: Advanced Ballet and Repertory
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: DANC 231 or intermediate level experience as determined by instructor at first class meeting.
classes.desc: Advanced ballet technique and reconstruction of historical ballet repertories from the romantic, classical, neoclassical, and modern periods.  Participation in dance performance of selected repertory.  Purchase of concert ticket(s) may be required.  Total credit limited to 6 units.  2 activities.

classes.name: Contemporary Dance Repertory
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: Intermediate level experience as determined by instructor at first class meeting.
classes.desc: Intermediate to advanced dance skills learned through the study and performance of selected contemporary dance repertory.  Explores concepts in advanced performance technique through formal and informal presentation in performance situations.  Purchase of concert ticket(s) may be required.  Total credit limited to 6 units.  2 activities.

classes.name: Dance Composition
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: Intermediate level experience as determined by instructor at first class meeting.
classes.desc: Principles of dance composition.  Exploration of creative potential and development of movement motifs through choreographic studies.  Preparation for informal public presentation of student generated choreographic works.  Purchase of concert ticket(s) may be required.  Total credit limited to 8 units.  1 lecture, 1 laboratory, 2 activities.

classes.name: Dance Concert Practicum
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: consent of instructor.
classes.desc: Advanced practical application of choreography and dance concert production.  Production of the student-produced Spring Dance Concert will be developed and executed.  Investigation of complete choreographic work via peer and faculty review.  Total credit limited to 8 units.  2 laboratories.

classes.name: Choreography/Workshop in Dance Concert Preparation
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: By audition only.
classes.desc: Workshop in concert preparation for major public dance production.  Exploration and process of concert dance choreography.  Purchase of concert ticket(s) may be required.  Total credit limited to 16 units.  4 laboratories.

classes.name: Dance Production
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: One of the following: DANC 332, DANC 331, or DANC 345.
classes.desc: Directed production of annual Orchesis Dance Company Concert and other public performances.  Attendance of professional dance concert(s) required.  Purchase of concert ticket(s) may be required.  Total credit limited to 16 units.  1-4 laboratories.

classes.name: Dance Teaching Methods for Dance Minors
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: Dance Minor.
classes.desc: Dance skills and techniques.  Experience in selected dance forms.  Rhythmic structure and analysis of dance steps.  Includes introduction to dance pedagogy, curricular materials and evaluative procedures.  Purchase of concert ticket(s) may be required.  2 lectures, 2 activities.

classes.name: Special Problems
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: Consent of instructor and department head.
classes.desc: Individual investigation, research and studies or survey of selected problems in dance and related areas.  Total credit limited to 8 units with a maximum of 4 units per quarter.

classes.name: Advanced Selected Techniques
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: Consent of instructor.
classes.desc: Directed study of selected topics for advanced dance students.  Focus on advanced level technique, style, concepts and choreography of classical and contemporary dance forms.  The Class Schedule will list topic selected.  Total credit limited to 8 units.  2 activities.

classes.name: Selected Advanced Topics
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: Consent of instructor.
classes.desc: Directed study of selected topics for advanced dance students.  The Class Schedule will list topics selected.  Total credit limited to 8 units.  1 to 4 lectures.

classes.name: Selected Advanced Laboratory
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: Consent of instructor.
classes.desc: Directed group laboratory study of selected topics for dance students.  The Class Schedule will list topics selected.  Total credit limited to 8 units.  1 to 4 laboratories.

classes.name: Introduction to Data Science
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: CPE/CSC 202; and one of the following: IME 326, STAT 302, STAT 312, or STAT 313.
classes.desc: Introduction to the field of data science and the workflow of a data scientist.  Types of data (tabular, textual, sparse, structured, temporal, geospatial), basic data management and manipulation, simple summaries, and visualization.  3 lectures, 1 laboratory.

classes.name: Data Science Process and Ethics
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisites: DATA 301; CSC 365; and CSC 466. Concurrent: DATA 402 and DATA 403.
classes.desc: Complete life cycle of a data science project.  Requirements engineering and data acquisition.  Management and integration of data of high volume, velocity, and variety.  Deployment of data science products.  Engagement with stakeholders.  Ethical considerations, including privacy and fairness.  3 lectures.

classes.name: Mathematical Foundations of Data Science
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisites: CSC 466; DATA 301; and STAT 334. Concurrent: DATA 401 and DATA 403.
classes.desc: Mathematical foundations of machine learning and data science.  Principle of maximum likelihood.  Inferential and predictive modeling and their comparison.  Optimization techniques.  Linear regression and linear classifiers.  Mathematical foundations of neural networks and neural network analysis.  Dimensionality reduction and its use in supervised and unsupervised learning.  3 lectures.

classes.name: Data Science Projects Laboratory
classes.pre_reqs: Concurrent: DATA 401 and DATA 402.
classes.desc: Project-based lab component of DATA 401 and DATA 402.  Projects involving comparison of predictive and interpretable regression models, implementing linear classifiers with gradient descent, implementing neural networks from scratch, and deep learning.  1 laboratory.

classes.name: Bioinformatics Capstone I
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: BIO 351 or CHEM 373; BIO 441 or CSC 448; DATA 301.
classes.desc: Working with clients to design bioinformatics solutions to biological questions.  Software requirements, elicitation techniques, data gathering, project planning, and project team organization.  Ethics and professionalism.  2 laboratories.

classes.name: Bioinformatics Capstone II
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: DATA 441.
classes.desc: Continue projects initiated in DATA 441.  Team-based design, implementation of bioinformatics solutions and management of development teams.  Technical documentation, quality assurance, and systems testing.  Design and conduct empirical studies.  Data visualization.  Oral and written presentation.  2 laboratories.

classes.name: Data Science Capstone I
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: DATA 401.
classes.desc: Working with clients to develop data-driven solutions for systems to be constructed in DATA 452.  Specification and design requirements, elicitation techniques, research and data gathering methods; project planning, time and budget estimating; project team organization.  Ethics and professionalism.  2 laboratories.

classes.name: Data Science Capstone II
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: DATA 451.
classes.desc: Team-based design, implementation, deployment and delivery of a system or analytical methodology that involves working with and analyzing large quantities of data.  Technical management of research and development teams.  Technical documentation, quality assurance, integration and systems testing.  Design and conduct of empirical studies.  Visualization and presentation of results orally and in writing.  2 laboratories.

classes.name: Data Science Seminar
classes.pre_reqs: CR/NCPrerequisite: DATA 301.
classes.desc: Discussions of technical, societal and ethical aspects of modern data science theory and practice, concentrating on topics not covered in other courses.  1 seminar.  Total credit limited to 4 units.  Credit/No credit grading only.

classes.name: Early Start English
classes.pre_reqs: CR/NC
classes.desc: Review of fundamental written communication skills; guided discussion of and reflection on the ways in which students interact with and produce texts; practice employing rhetorical strategies to meet the purpose, context, and audience expectations of a writing task. For students required to fulfill the CSU Early Start Program. 1 unit for baccalaureate credit. Credit/No Credit grading only. 1 activity.

classes.name: Early Start Program: Mathematics Workshop
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: Appropriate Math Placement Level. Concurrent: ESM 105.
classes.desc: Review of basic algebra skills intended for students who need to meet the CSU Early Start Program (ESP) requirement.  Not for baccalaureate credit.  Credit/No Credit grading only.

classes.name: Early Start Program: Mathematics
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: Appropriate Math Placement Level. Concurrent: ESM 90.
classes.desc: Review of basic algebra skills and an introduction to functions intended for students who need to meet the CSU Early Start Program (ESP) requirement.  1 unit for baccalaureate credit.  Credit/No Credit grading only.  Course may be offered in hybrid format.  1 lecture.

classes.name: Introduction to Earth Science
classes.desc: Survey of fundamental processes of Earth science. Application of systems thinking to understanding the dynamic interactions among geological, geographic, soils and human factors in shaping the Earth. 3 lectures, 1 activity.

classes.name: Rocks and Minerals
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: SS 120; and CHEM 124 or CHEM 127.
classes.desc: Origin, composition, identification and weathering of rocks, minerals, and clays important in the development of soils.  Parent materials as related to the nature and properties of soils.  3 lectures, 1 laboratory.

classes.name: Physical Geography
classes.desc: Addresses the origins and patterns of the earth's diverse assemblage of climates, landforms, biota and soils. A major focus on relationship between human cultures and these earthly environments. 4 lectures. Crosslisted as ERSC/GEOG 250.

classes.name: Selected Topics
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: Consent of instructor.
classes.desc: Directed group study of selected topics.  The Class Schedule will list topic selected.  Total credit limited to 12 units.  1 to 4 lectures.  Crosslisted as ERSC/SS 270.

classes.name: Soil Erosion and Water Conservation
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: LA/NR 218 or GEOG 318; and SS 120.
classes.desc: Evaluation of soil and water conservation with application toward agriculture, rangeland, and urban land uses.  Study of process, regulation, and best management practices for soil erosion, water quality, and stormwater.  Development of stormwater pollution prevention or farm water quality plans to meet regulatory requirements.  3 lectures, 1 activity.

classes.name: Climate and Humanity
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: Junior standing.
classes.desc: Geographic perspective on the interrelationships between climate and human cultures.  Effects of people on climate and the influence of climate and weather upon human activities and behavior.  Focus on global human conditions which are responsible for the alteration of climate and in turn are vulnerable to climate change.  4 lectures.  Crosslisted as ERSC/GEOG 325.

classes.name: Human Impact on the Earth
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: Junior standing.
classes.desc: Global assessment of the impact of humans on the earth's vegetation, animals, soil, water and atmosphere.  Emphasis on problems stemming from the interactions of human attitudes, technologies, and population with natural resources.  4 lectures.  Crosslisted as ERSC/GEOG 333.

classes.name: Soil, Water, and Civilization
classes.pre_reqs: 2020-21 or later: Upper-Div GE Area B2019-20 or earlier catalog: GE Area B5, B6, or B7Prerequisite: Junior standing; completion of GE Area A with grades of C- or better; and completion of GE Areas B1 through B4, with a grade of C- or better in one course in GE Area B4 (GE Area B1 for students on the 2019-20 or earlier catalogs).
classes.desc: Explore past civilizations and how management of soil, water, and other natural resources allowed them to flourish, decline, or fail.  Sustainability of natural resource use in modern/future societies.  Issues include sustainability, agricultural practices, deforestation, water quality, and land management.  4 lectures.  Fulfills GE Area Upper-Division B (GE Areas B5, B6, or B7 for students on the 2019-20 catalog).

classes.name: Internship in Environmental Earth and Soil Sciences
classes.pre_reqs: CR/NCPrerequisite: Consent of internship instructor.
classes.desc: Selected students will spend up to 12 weeks with an approved firm or agency engaged in work and study related to their major.  A detailed written proposal and written interim and final reports required.  One unit of credit may be allowed for each full week of internship.  Credit/No Credit grading.  Crosslisted as ERSC/SS 339.

classes.name: Special Problems for Advanced Undergraduates
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: Consent of instructor.
classes.desc: Individual investigation, research, studies or surveys of selected problems.  Total credit limited to 12 units.  Crosslisted as ERSC/SS 400.

classes.name: Field-Geology Methods
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: GEOL 102 or GEOL 201, GEOL 241, GEOL 415, ERSC 223, ERSC 323.
classes.desc: Collecting and interpreting field-geologic data.  Description of sedimentary rocks and construction of stratigraphic columns.  Mapping geologic structures in the field.  Surficial geologic stratigraphy and surficial geologic mapping.  Understanding geologic processes through field study.  Communicating results of field study.  1 lecture, 3 activities.  Crosslisted as ERSC/GEOL 401.

classes.name: Geologic Mapping
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: ERSC/GEOL 401.
classes.desc: Bedrock geologic mapping on topographic maps and aerial photos.  Surficial geologic mapping on topographic maps and aerial photos.  Correlating and defining surficial geologic map units on the basis of soil development.  Understanding landscape evolution using soil development 4 activities.  Crosslisted as ERSC/GEOL 402.

classes.name: Global and Regional Climatology
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: Junior standing.
classes.desc: The earth's pattern of climates and the physical processes that account for them.  Focus on interrelationships between climate and the physical/biological and cultural environments.  Special emphasis on modern climate changes and their consequences.  3 lectures, 1 laboratory.  Crosslisted as ERSC/GEOG 414.

classes.name: Applied Meteorology and Climatology
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: ERSC/GEOG 250.
classes.desc: Physical processes in the atmosphere that determine regional weather, climate and climate variability.  Surface and satellite systems for weather observation, and weather/climate modeling.  Dynamics of weather systems, including thunderstorms and hurricanes.  Emphases on weather/climate affecting agriculture and other human activities.  3 lectures, 1 activity.  Crosslisted as ERSC/GEOG 415.

classes.name: Geomorphology
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: SS 120 or SS 121; and GEOL 201.
classes.desc: Evaluation of processes shaping landscapes.  Field-based production of surficial geologic maps.  Field, aerial photograph, and topographic map analysis to assess processes shaping landscapes.  Interpretation of landforms and landform relationships.  Understanding how tectonics and climate influence landscapes.  Fundamentals of soil geomorphology.  Field trip required.  2 lectures, 1 laboratory, 1 activity.  Formerly ERSC 323.

classes.name: Applied Environmental Groundwater Hydrology
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: ERSC 144 or GEOL 201; MATH 141 or MATH 161; and SS 120.
classes.desc: Applied field methods of vadose zone and groundwater flow modeling, resource evaluation, confined and unconfined aquifer characterization, well installation and groundwater monitoring.  Introduction to groundwater modeling software including MODFLOW and AQTESOLV.  3 lectures, 1 laboratory.  Formerly SS 442.

classes.name: Applied Environmental Contaminant Transport
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: CHEM 125 or CHEM 128; ERSC 144 or GEOL 201; MATH 141 or MATH 161; and SS 120.
classes.desc: Applied study of mechanisms of fate and transport of contaminants in soils and groundwater.  Field methods and technologies of soil and groundwater sampling and site characterization.  Representative conceptual and mathematical models, case studies, laboratory study of breakthrough behavior, and remediation technologies.  Field trip required.  3 lectures, 1 laboratory.

classes.name: Selected Advanced Topics
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: Consent of instructor.
classes.desc: Directed group study of selected topics for advanced students.  Open to undergraduate and graduate students.  The Class Schedule list topic selected.  Total credit limited to 12 units.  1 to 4 lectures.  Crosslisted as ERSC/SS 470.

classes.name: Selected Advanced Laboratory
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: Consent of instructor.
classes.desc: Directed group laboratory study of selected topics for advanced students.  Open to undergraduate and graduate students.  The Class Schedule will list topic selected.  Total credit limited to 8 units.  1 to 4 laboratories.  Crosslisted as ERSC/SS 471.

classes.name: Senior Project - Advanced Internship Experience in Environmental Science/Management
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: Completion of GE Area A with grades of C- or better; and ERSC 363 or NR 306 or NR 326.
classes.desc: Independent internship experience conducted under faculty supervision focusing on a discipline area of environmental science/management.  Completion of a project as a component of their internship.  Satisfies the senior project requirement.  Minimum 90 hours required.  Crosslisted as ERSC/NR 476.

classes.name: Senior Project - Research Experience in Environmental Science
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: Completion of GE Area A with grades of C- or better; and ERSC 363 or NR 306 or NR 326.
classes.desc: Guided research experience in a specific area of environmental science.  Implementation of materials and methods.  Collection, analysis and interpretation of data.  Completion of formal written report.  Satisfies senior project requirement.  1 lecture, 2 laboratories.  Crosslisted as ERSC/NR 477.

classes.name: Senior Project - Current Topics in Environmental Science/Management
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: Completion of GE Area A with grades of C- or better; and ERSC 363 or NR 306 or NR 326.
classes.desc: Critical evaluation and formal presentation of current issues in environmental science/management.  Evaluation of current topics, analysis of supporting evidence, and synthesis and presentation of resulting perspectives on different approaches to current challenges in environmental science/management.  Satisfies the senior project requirement.  3 lectures.  Crosslisted as ERSC/NR 478.

classes.name: Senior Project - Independent Study
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: Completion of GE Area A with grades of C- or better; ERSC 363 or NR 306 or NR 326; and consent of instructor.
classes.desc: Selection and completion of a project under faculty supervision.  Projects typical of problems which graduates must solve in their fields of employment.  Project results are presented in a formal report.  Minimum 90 hours total time.  Crosslisted as ERSC/NR 479.

classes.name: Selected Topics in Earth Science
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: Graduate standing or consent of instructor.
classes.desc: Directed group study of selected topics for advanced students.  The Class Schedule will list topic selected.  Total credit limited to 12 units.  1 to 4 seminars.

classes.name: Selected Advanced Laboratory
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: Graduate standing or consent of instructor.
classes.desc: Directed group laboratory study of selected topics for advanced students.  Open to undergraduate and graduate students.  The Class Schedule will list topic selected.  Total credit limited to 8 units.  1 to 4 laboratories.

classes.name: Special Problems for Undergraduates
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: Sophomore standing and consent of department head.
classes.desc: Individual investigation, research, studies, or surveys of selected problems.  Total credit limited to 4 units, with a maximum of 2 units per quarter.

classes.name: Survey of Economics
classes.pre_reqs: 2020-21 or later catalog: GE Area D22019-20 or earlier: GE Area D2 or D3
classes.desc: Basic principles of microeconomics and macroeconomics. Emphasis on applications to current national and global economic issues. For majors requiring one quarter of economics. Not open to students having previous credit in ECON 222 or equivalent. 4 lectures. Crosslisted as ECON/HNRS 201. Fulfills GE Area D2 (GE Area D2 or GE Area D3 for students on the 2019-20 or earlier catalogs).

classes.name: Microeconomics
classes.desc: Microeconomic principles. Marginal and equilibrium analysis of commodity and factor markets in determination of price and output. Normative issues of efficiency and equity. 4 lectures.

classes.name: Macroeconomics
classes.pre_reqs: 2020-21 or later catalog: GE Area D22019-20 or earlier: GE Area D2 or D3
classes.desc: Introduction to economic problems. Macroeconomic analysis and principles. Aggregate output, employment, prices, and economic policies for changing these variables. International trade and finance. Issues of economic growth and development. Comparative economic systems and economies in transition. 4 lectures. Fulfills GE Area D2 (GE Area D2 or GE Area D3 for students on the 2019-20 or earlier catalogs).

classes.name: Selected Topics
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: Open to undergraduate students and consent of instructor.
classes.desc: Directed group study of selected topics.  The Class Schedule will list topic selected.  Total credit limited to 8 units.  1 to 4 lectures.

classes.name: Economics of Poverty, Discrimination and Immigration
classes.pre_reqs: 2020-21 or later: Upper-Div GE Area D2019-20 or earlier catalog: GE Area D5USCPPrerequisite: Junior standing; completion of GE Area A with grades of C- or better; one course in GE Area B4 with a grade of C- or better (GE Area B1 for students on the 2019-20 or earlier catalogs); and ECON 201 or ECON 222.
classes.desc: Economic analysis of the cause, extent and impact of poverty, discrimination and immigration and of the policies designed to address these socioeconomic issues.  Emphasis on the experience of African-Americans, Latinos, and women in the United States.  4 lectures.  Crosslisted as ECON/HNRS 303.  Fulfills GE Upper-Division D (GE Area D5 for students on the 2019-20 or earlier catalogs); and USCP.

classes.name: Comparative Economic Systems
classes.pre_reqs: 2020-21 or later: Upper-Div GE Area D2019-20 or earlier catalog: GE Area D5Prerequisite: Junior standing; completion of GE Area A with grades of C- or better; one course in GE Area B4 with a grade of C- or better (GE Area B1 for students on the 2019-20 or earlier catalogs); and ECON 201 or ECON 222.
classes.desc: Analysis of economic systems as a set of mechanisms and institutions for decision making, and the implementation of decisions regarding income distribution, the levels of consumption and production, and the level of economic welfare.  4 lectures.  Fulfills GE Upper-Division D (GE Area D5 for students on the 2019-20 or earlier catalogs).

classes.name: Intermediate Microeconomics I
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: ECON 201; or ECON 221 and ECON 222; and MATH 141 or MATH 221.
classes.desc: Consumer behavior and the theory of demand; production, cost, supply functions; perfect competition; monopoly and oligopoly; labor markets.  4 lectures.

classes.name: Intermediate Microeconomics II
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: ECON 311.
classes.desc: Game theory; risk, uncertainty and information; choice over time; asset markets; general equilibrium; welfare economics, externalities and public goods.  4 lectures.

classes.name: Intermediate Macroeconomics
classes.pre_reqs: Corequisite: ECON 311.
classes.desc: Analysis of national income, price level, employment, international trade and economic growth.  Development of the theory of national income determination.  Evaluation of roles of monetary and fiscal policy.  4 lectures.

classes.name: International Trade Theory
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: Either ECON 221 and ECON 222, or ECON 201.
classes.desc: Theory of comparative advantage, gains from trade, and recent developments in trade theory; examination of tariffs, quotas, exchange controls, other trade barriers and underlying policy issues; review of U.S.  commercial policy, GATT, the common market, regional and world economic organizations.  4 lectures.  Not open to students with credit in ECON 404 or equivalent.

classes.name: Money, Banking and Credit
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: Either ECON 221 and ECON 222, or ECON 201.
classes.desc: Financial markets and institutions.  Structure of the banking industry and impacts of technological change in banking.  Structure and operations of the Federal Reserve.  Impacts of monetary policy on the economy.  4 lectures.

classes.name: Econometrics
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: either ECON 221 and ECON 222; or ECON 201; MATH 141 or MATH 221, and STAT 252 or STAT 302.
classes.desc: Application of statistical methods useful in economics.  General linear regression model.  Specific issues and problems related to economic models:  multicollinearity, autocorrelation, heteroscedasticity, dummy variables, lagged variables, and simultaneous equation estimation.  Application and evaluation of selected examples of empirical economic research.  Microcomputer applications.  4 lectures.

classes.name: Environmental and Natural Resource Economics
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: ECON 201; or ECON 221 and ECON 222.
classes.desc: Economics of environmental resource management.  Conservation, sustainability, and dynamic efficiency in natural resources.  Effects of property rights and economic incentives on environmental and economic systems.  Design of local and global environmental policies to align market outcomes with social welfare goals.  4 lectures.  Not open to students with credit in ECON 431, ECON 432 or equivalent.

classes.name: Programming for Economics and Analytics
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: Junior standing; STAT 252 or STAT 302.
classes.desc: Basic principles of algorithmic problem solving and computer programming for economics and business analytics applications.  Functions, iteration, recursion, and data structures.  Testing and debugging.  Design of algorithms and algorithmic complexity.  Stochastic programs.  Graph optimization.  Credit will only be granted in one of the following courses:  CSC 108, CSC 202, ECON 395.  4 lectures.

classes.name: Special Problems
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: Consent of department head.
classes.desc: Individual investigation, research, studies, or surveys of selected problems.  Total credit limited to 4 units.

classes.name: Industrial Organization
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: ECON 312.
classes.desc: Application of basic tools of economics to American Industry.  Case studies of individual firms and industries.  Performance of various business structures, such as monopoly and oligopoly.  Effects of government regulation and antitrust policy.  4 lectures.

classes.name: International Trade Theory
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: ECON 312.
classes.desc: Theory of comparative advantage, neoclassical model of trade, offer curves and terms of trade, edgeworth boxes, valuation of factor inputs, effects of migration and mobility of funds, emerging growth and trade distortions, welfare effects of trade, and recent developments in trade theory.  4 lectures.

classes.name: International Monetary Economics
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: ECON 313.
classes.desc: Nature of international payments, U.S.  balance of payments.  Theory and practice of foreign exchange rate determination under the gold standard, paper standard, and IMF system; international money and capital markets; problems of international liquidity and monetary stability.  4 lectures.

classes.name: Applied Forecasting
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: ECON 311 and ECON 339.
classes.desc: Causes and measurement of business fluctuations.  Techniques of forecasting with microcomputer applications.  4 lectures.

classes.name: Mathematical Economics
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: ECON 312.
classes.desc: Applications of quantitative techniques to topics in microeconomic and macroeconomic theory.  Use of multivariate calculus and linear algebra in formulating static economic models.  Applications of statistical inference, estimation and forecasting in economic models.  4 lectures.

classes.name: Probability Models for Economic Decisions
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: ECON 312.
classes.desc: Decision making in complex, realistic situations.  Simulation of random variables in Excel.  Risk aversion.  Subjective assessment of probabilities and correlations.  Decision trees.  Optimal bidding in auctions.  The winner's curse.  Moral hazard and risk sharing.  Repeated investment decisions under risk.  4 lectures.

classes.name: Public Finance and Cost-Benefit Analysis
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: ECON 312 or graduate standing.
classes.desc: Principles of rational decision making with respect to government revenues and spending.  Measurement of costs and benefits, and criterion selection.  Taxation, user fees, deficit financing, public goods, neighborhood effects and zoning.  Microcomputer applications.  4 lectures.

classes.name: Labor Economics
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: ECON 312.
classes.desc: Wage determination theory, basic economic factors that affect the labor movement, economic impact of union activities on employment, output, income, wages, prices, and national economic policy.  4 lectures.

classes.name: Development of Economic Analysis
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: ECON 311.
classes.desc: Analysis of ideas related to the development of economic theory in the Western civilization from the Greeks through the classical, neoclassical, and Keynesian to the current post-Keynesian concepts.  4 lectures.

classes.name: Monetary Economics
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: ECON 313.
classes.desc: The role of money in our economy.  Focus on the links between monetary policy, interest rates, prices, housing markets, mortgage lending and overall economic activity.  Public policy issues relating to real estate markets.  4 lectures.

classes.name: Environmental Economics
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: ECON 312.
classes.desc: Economic dimensions of environmental abuse and protection.  Use of simple economic models in developing and evaluating environmental policies.  Overview of current environmental problems.  Issues related to the sustainability of economic growth at the national and international levels.  4 lectures.

classes.name: Economics of Energy and Resources
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: ECON 312 or graduate standing.
classes.desc: Economic theory and public policies as applied to problems of natural resources and energy.  Dynamic resource and energy models developed with reference to public and private sector growth.  Application of the principles of capital theory emphasized.  Case studies.  Computer software applications in the study of natural resources and energy under uncertainty.  4 lectures.

classes.name: Urban Economics
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: ECON 311. Recommended: ECON 312.
classes.desc: Application of basic tools of economic analysis to problems of urban regions.  Causes and possible cures for inadequate growth rate, income levels, and the quality of life in urban regions.  4 lectures.

classes.name: Economics of Land and Water
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: ECON 312 or graduate standing.
classes.desc: Economic analysis of natural resource issues, policies and management with an emphasis on land and water use decisions in the western U.S.  Urban demand for water; water supply and economic growth; economic impacts of surface water law and institutions; economics of land management.  4 lectures.

classes.name: Advanced Econometrics
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: ECON 339.
classes.desc: Modern advanced econometric techniques with a special focus on those commonly used in academic and non-academic settings.  Discrete dependent variable models, instrumental variables, causal inference, nonlinear estimation, panel data, seemingly unrelated regression, distributed lag models, cointegration, and error correction models.  4 lectures.

classes.name: Experimental and Behavioral Economics
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: ECON 312 and ECON 395.
classes.desc: Design and implementation of economic experiments including computer programming and statistical methods for experimental analysis.  Behavioral economic models as an alternative to neoclassical economics including prospect theory, time-inconsistent preferences, and social preferences.  4 lectures.

classes.name: Research Methodology in Applied Economics
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: ECON 313; ECON 339 and Senior standing.
classes.desc: Theory and practice of the development of economic analysis.  Steps in the formulation and execution of an economics research project.  4 lectures.

classes.name: Senior Project I
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: ECON 313 and senior standing.
classes.desc: Selection and analysis of a problem under faculty supervision.  Problems typical of those which graduates must solve in their fields of employment.  Formal report is required.  Minimum 120 hours total time.

classes.name: Senior Project II
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: ECON 313 and senior standing.
classes.desc: Selection and analysis of a problem under faculty supervision.  Problems typical of those which graduates must solve in their fields of employment.  Formal report is required.  Minimum 120 hours total time.

classes.name: Applied Senior Project
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: Senior standing and two 400-level ECON courses other than ECON 460. Corequisite: ECON 460.
classes.desc: Analysis of selected economic topics and problems in directed individual or group-based projects, which require application of economic models, principles and theory to investigate important business, economic or social issues.  Formal report required.  4 seminars.

classes.name: Selected Advanced Topics
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: Consent of instructor.
classes.desc: Directed group study of selected topics for advanced students.  Open to undergraduate and graduate students.  The Class Schedule will list topic selected.  Total credit limited to 8 units.  1 to 4 lectures.

classes.name: Econometrics and Data Analysis
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: GSE 518. Corequisite: GSE 524.
classes.desc: Identification and estimation of linear and nonlinear regression models for analyzing business data.  Topics include multiple linear regression; model selection; robust standard errors; instrumental variables; maximum likelihood estimation; logit/probit, ordered logit/probit, and other microeconometric models.  4 lectures.

classes.name: First Year Seminar
classes.pre_reqs: CR/NC
classes.desc: Issues associated with the successful transition from high school or community college to Cal Poly. Links fostered between student needs and campus resources. Coverage of academic policies and procedures, university study skills, goal setting, career planning, wellness and other topics relevant to student success. Not open to students with credit in UNIV 100. Credit/No Credit grading only. 1 lecture, 1 activity. Crosslisted as EDUC/UNIV 125.

classes.name: Children's Learning and Development in Educational Settings
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: Sophomore standing; PSY 201 or PSY 202 or admission to the university with the intent to enter the MSTEP Program.
classes.desc: Study of theories and research about the development and learning of children and young adolescents within diverse backgrounds, and application to teaching in public school settings.  Observations/interactions with children in school settings.  3 lectures, 1 activity.  Participation in public schools requires mandated fingerprint clearance.  Crosslisted as CD/EDUC 207.

classes.name: Selected Topics
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: Open to undergraduate students and consent of instructor.
classes.desc: Directed group study of selected topics.  The Class Schedule will list topic selected.  Total credit limited to 8 units.  1 to 4 lectures.

classes.name: Historical, Philosophical, and Social Foundations of Public Education
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: Junior standing.
classes.desc: Historical, philosophical, and social foundations of public education in relation to school curriculum, instruction and dispositions of effective teachers.  Structured observation and participation in K-12 public schools with attention to instructional practices for diverse learners.  2 lectures, 1 activity.  Participation in public schools requires mandated fingerprint clearance.

classes.name: Special Problems for Undergraduates
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: Junior standing and consent of instructor.
classes.desc: Individual investigation, research, studies or surveys of selected problems.  Total credit limited to 8 units, with a maximum of 4 units per quarter.

classes.name: Learning to Teach K-8 Health and Physical Education with Diverse Populations
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: Admission to the Multiple Subject Teacher Preparation Program.
classes.desc: Subject-specific instructional methodologies in Health and Physical Education (PE).  Design and implementation of elementary school instruction to address state-adopted content standards for Health and Physical Education in the State of California.  Course may be offered in classroom-based or online format.  2 lecture, 1 laboratory.

classes.name: Social, Historical and Cultural Influences on Latino/a Students in Education
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: SPAN 202 with a grade of B or better; or appropriate score on placement exam; or consent of instructor.
classes.desc: Social, cultural, historical, political, economic, and educational factors and systems in Latin America and the United States that have contributed to and shaped Latino/a individual and group identity.  How factors affect individual acculturation in California and the United States and influence how Latino/as experience and participate with schooling in the United States.  Course may be offered in classroom-based or online format.  3 seminars, 1 activity.

classes.name: Social, Historical and Ethical Perspectives on Teaching and Learning
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: Admission to the Single Subject Credential Program.
classes.desc: Inquiry into the social, historical, philosophical and psychological foundations of education with an emphasis on applying educational theory to practice.  Prepares Single Subject Credential Program students for classroom teaching.  3 lectures.

classes.name: Access to Learning in a Pluralistic Society
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: Admission to the Single Subject Credential Program.
classes.desc: The role of culture, status, identity, and human development in public school experiences of diverse learners.  Organization and management of secondary school classrooms as related to adolescent development and issues of access to learning.  4 lectures.

classes.name: Curriculum and Inquiry in Public Schools
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: Admission to the Single Subject Credential Program.
classes.desc: Principles, methods and practices of organizing curriculum, instruction, and assessment for secondary school subject areas, with an emphasis on backward design in curriculum development and assessment.  Site visits to local schools to allow analysis of planning, instruction, and assessment in secondary school classrooms.  4 lectures.

classes.name: Literacy, Language, and Culture in Content Area Classrooms
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: Admission to the Single Subject Credential Program.
classes.desc: Theories and application of literacy learning, assessment and second language acquisition in content classrooms.  Observation of classrooms, tutoring English language learners, designing and teaching literacy lessons, planning and implementing assessments across content areas.  Recognition of the role of culture in language acquisition.  Course may be offered in classroom-based or online format.  3 lectures.

classes.name: Literacy, Language, and Culture in the Content Area Classroom Fieldwork
classes.pre_reqs: CR/NC
classes.desc: Fieldwork in the secondary classroom related to literacy, language and culture for Agriculture Education candidates. Includes 1-3 hours of observation each week. Participation in public schools requires mandated fingerprint clearance. Credit/No Credit grading. 1 activity.

classes.name: Culturally Responsive Teaching in Diverse Classrooms
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: Admission to the Single Subject Credential Program.
classes.desc: Differentiated instruction and further theoretical knowledge and skills needed for successful teaching of linguistically and culturally diverse learners, as well as students with special learning needs.  PACT assessments embedded in course prepare credential candidates for the teaching event.  3 lectures.

classes.name: Culturally Responsive Fieldwork in Diverse Classrooms
classes.pre_reqs: CR/NC
classes.desc: Fieldwork in the secondary classroom related culturally responsive teaching in diverse classrooms for Agriculture Education candidates. Includes 1-3 hours of observation each week. Participation in public schools requires mandated fingerprint clearance. Credit/No Credit grading. 1 activity.

classes.name: Bilingual Literacy
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: Admission to the Spanish Authorization for Bilingual Educators (SABE) Program.
classes.desc: Patterns of classroom organization, application of reading programs, approaches, methods in English and Spanish, and supervised field experiences in elementary classrooms with bilingual students.  Course may be offered in classroom-based or online format.  3 seminars, 1 activity.

classes.name: Theories, Methods, and Assessment of First and Second Language Acquisition in Schools
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: Senior standing. Recommended: ENGL 391.
classes.desc: Theories, methods, materials and assessment involved in the instruction of emergent bilingual students.  Bilingual, transitional, and English only programs compared across a historical framework.  Emphasis on an integrated language arts approach; theories of language acquisition.  3 seminars, 1 activity.  Participation in public schools requires mandated fingerprint clearance.

classes.name: Foundations of K-8 Literacy Teaching and Learning in Schools with Diverse Populations
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: Senior or Graduate standing.
classes.desc: Introduction of foundational topics in literacy teaching and learning in K-8 schools with diverse populations.  Examination of concepts and theories underlying literacy learning and instruction, and relating research-based patterns of reading and writing development to features of the learner and learning environments.  Participation in public schools requires mandated fingerprint clearance.  3 seminars, 1 activity.

classes.name: Learning to Teach K-8 Literacy in Schools with Diverse Populations
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: Admission to the Multiple Subject Teacher Preparation Program.
classes.desc: Integration of theory and practice for planning, instruction and assessment in a balanced, comprehensive, research-based K-8 literacy and language arts program to enable children of all abilities and background to read, write, speak, listen and think effectively.  4 seminars.

classes.name: Learning to Teach K-8 Social Studies with Diverse Populations
