classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: Admission to the Multiple Subject Teacher Preparation Program.
classes.desc: Curriculum instruction and assessment concepts regarding teaching social studies to culturally diverse students in grades K-8, to promote civic competence and the development of elementary students' knowledge and reasoning in the social sciences.  4 seminars.

classes.name: Foundations of Bilingual Education
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: Admission to the Spanish Authorization for Bilingual Educators (SABE) Program.
classes.desc: History, theories, and practices associated with contemporary bilingual education in California and the U.S.  Observation and limited teaching in bilingual classrooms.  Approximately one-half of the class taught in Spanish.  Course may be offered in classroom-based or online format.  3 seminars, 1 activity.

classes.name: Learning to Teach K-8 Mathematics with Diverse Populations
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: Admission to the Multiple Subject Teacher Preparation Program.
classes.desc: Curriculum, instruction, and assessment concepts regarding teaching mathematics for understanding to culturally diverse students in grades K-8, with emphasis on using manipulatives to promote elementary students' development of mathematical knowledge and reasoning.  4 seminars.

classes.name: Learning to Teach K-8 Science with Diverse Populations
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: Admission to the Multiple Subject Teacher Preparation Program.
classes.desc: Curriculum, instruction, and assessment concepts regarding teaching science for understanding to culturally diverse students in grades K-8, with emphasis on teaching via inquiry to promote the development of scientific knowledge and reasoning.  3 seminars, 1 activity.

classes.name: Multiple Subject Clinical Practice I
classes.pre_reqs: CR/NCPrerequisite: Admission to the Multiple Subject Teacher Preparation (MSTEP) Program.
classes.desc: Clinical experiences involving observation; limited lesson planning, instruction, assessment and reflection; growth as a professional educator and participation in school-related activities in K-8 public school classrooms.  Participation in public schools requires mandated fingerprint clearance.  Total credit limited to 4 units.  Credit/No Credit grading only.

classes.name: Multiple Subject Clinical Practice Seminar I
classes.pre_reqs: CR/NCPrerequisite: Admission to the Multiple Subject Teacher Preparation (MSTEP) Program.
classes.desc: Discussion of contemporary educational issues and classroom practice; reflection on beginning clinical experiences in elementary education and their connection with educational theory and research.  Credit/No Credit grading only.  3 seminars.

classes.name: Educating Individuals with Exceptional Needs
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: EDUC 429, EDUC 431, EDUC 435, EDUC 436, EDUC 438 and EDUC 439.
classes.desc: Characteristics, incidence, and etiology of individuals with exceptional needs.  Problems, assessment, and approaches toward accommodating students with exceptional needs in the regular classroom.  3 seminars, 1 activity.

classes.name: Elementary Field Experience in General and/or Special Education
classes.pre_reqs: CR/NCPrerequisite: Acceptance into the Preliminary Special Education Credential Program or the Multiple Subject Teacher Preparation (MSTEP) Program.
classes.desc: Public school classroom experiences in general education and/or special education classrooms at the elementary level.  Teaching individuals and small groups.  Total credit limited to 4 units.  Credit/No Credit grading only.

classes.name: Secondary Field Experience in General and/or Special Education
classes.pre_reqs: CR/NCPrerequisite: Acceptance into the Preliminary Special Education Credential Program or the Single Subject Credential Program.
classes.desc: Public school classroom experiences in general education classrooms and/or special education classrooms at the secondary level.  Teaching individuals and small groups.  Total credit limited to 4 units.  Credit/No Credit grading only.

classes.name: Special Education Student Teaching
classes.pre_reqs: CR/NCPrerequisite: Acceptance into Level I Special Education Credential Program, and completion of all program requirements. Concurrent: EDUC 451.
classes.desc: Participation in public schools as a student teacher in activities representing different roles of special education teachers.  Assumption of a teacher's responsibility for individual and small groups.  Minimum 4 days per week.  Credit/No Credit grading only.

classes.name: Teaching Performance Assessment Seminar
classes.pre_reqs: CR/NC
classes.desc: Tasks, timelines, evaluation rubrics, and academic writing in relation to the Teaching Performance Assessments that are required for teacher credentialing in California. Total credit limited to 2 units. Credit/No Credit grading. 1 seminar.

classes.name: Special Education Student Teaching Seminar
classes.pre_reqs: CR/NCPrerequisite: Acceptance into Level I Special Education Credential Program; completion of program requirements for the Level I Special Education Program. Concurrent: EDUC 449.
classes.desc: Educational issues and research, development and assessment of teaching portfolio, completion of materials for a job search, and beginning the first year as a special educator.  3 seminars, 1 activity.

classes.name: Multiple Subject Clinical Practice II
classes.pre_reqs: CR/NCPrerequisite: Admission to the Multiple Subject Teacher Preparation (MSTEP) Program.
classes.desc: Clinical experiences involving planning, instruction, assessment and reflection; growth as a professional and related activities in K-8 public school classrooms.  Participation in public schools requires mandated fingerprint clearance.  Credit/No Credit grading only.

classes.name: Multiple Subject Clinical Practice Seminar II
classes.pre_reqs: CR/NCPrerequisite: Acceptance into STEP II or STEP B of the Multiple Subject Teacher Preparation Program. Concurrent: EDUC 454.
classes.desc: Discussion of contemporary educational issues, state education policies and expectations for effective classroom practice; reflection on clinical experiences in elementary education and their connection with educational theory research.  Participation in public schools requires mandated fingerprint clearance.  Credit/No Credit grading.  3 seminars.

classes.name: Multiple Subject Clinical Practice III
classes.pre_reqs: CR/NCPrerequisite: EDUC 454 and EDUC 455. Concurrent: EDUC 457.
classes.desc: Advanced clinical experiences involving planning, instruction, assessment and reflection; growth as a professional and related activities in K-8 public school classrooms.  Credit/No Credit grading only.

classes.name: Multiple Subject Clinical Practice Seminar III
classes.pre_reqs: CR/NCPrerequisite: EDUC 454 and EDUC 455. Concurrent: EDUC 456.
classes.desc: Discussion of contemporary educational issues, national education policies and expectations for effective classroom practice; reflection on advanced clinical experiences in elementary education and their connection with educational theory and research.  Credit/No Credit grading.  3 seminars.

classes.name: Clinical Practice I
classes.pre_reqs: CR/NCPrerequisite: Admission to the Single Subject Credential Program.
classes.desc: Clinical experiences involving observation; limited planning, instruction, assessment and reflection; growth as a professional, and participation in other school-related activities in secondary public classrooms.  Credit/No Credit grading only.

classes.name: Clinical Practice II
classes.pre_reqs: CR/NCPrerequisite: Completion of courses and requirements to begin student teaching and approval of campus screening committee for credential candidates.
classes.desc: Part-time assignment in a classroom (Single Subject only).  Includes teaching activities under the direction of a selected cooperating teacher in consultation with a university supervisor.  Assignment consists of an entire morning in the classroom (or the equivalent) for one quarter.  Credit/No Credit grading only.

classes.name: Selected Advanced Topics
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: Consent of instructor.
classes.desc: Directed group study of selected topics for advanced students.  Open to undergraduate and graduate students.  The Class schedule will list topic selected.  Total credit limited to 8 units.  1 to 4 lectures.

classes.name: Selected Advanced Laboratory
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: Consent of instructor.
classes.desc: Directed group laboratory study of selected topics for advanced students.  Open to undergraduate and graduate students.  The Class Schedule will list topic selected.  Total credit limited to 8 units.  1 to 4 laboratories.

classes.name: Clinical Practice III
classes.pre_reqs: CR/NCPrerequisite: Completion of all courses and requirements prerequisite to full-time student teaching and approval by campus screening committee for credential candidates.
classes.desc: Full-time assignment in a classroom (Single Subject only).  Includes teaching activities under the direction of a selected cooperating teacher in consultation with a university supervisor.  Assignment consists of an entire teaching day in the school for one quarter.  Credit/No Credit grading only.

classes.name: Individual Study
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: Consent of department head, graduate major advisor, and supervising faculty member.
classes.desc: Advanced study planned and completed under the direction of a member of the department faculty.  Open only to graduate students who have demonstrated ability to do independent work.  Enrollment by petition.  Total credit limited to 8 units.

classes.name: Advancing Pedagogical Practices with Technology
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: Graduate standing.
classes.desc: Examination of technology-supported instruction with special focus on the use of technology to enable constructivist learning experiences for K-12 students.  A survey of advanced technologies including Web-based tools, apps, digital story telling, and media production.  Course offered online only.  3 seminars, 1 activity.

classes.name: Education Finance and Resource Allocation
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: Graduate standing and consent of instructor.
classes.desc: Financing public schools in America:  historical and current sources and types of funding.  District level and site level funding and budgeting including priorities and purchasing procedures.  Financial implications of personnel contracts and obligations.  3 seminars, 1 activity.

classes.name: Educational Law and Governance
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: Graduate standing and consent of instructor.
classes.desc: Legal aspects of school administration including unions, collective bargaining, and contract administration.  Governing roles of federal, state, and local agencies including boards and district administrators.  3 seminars, 1 activity.

classes.name: Education Organization and Management
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: Graduate standing and consent of instructor.
classes.desc: Principles of organization, management, sustainability, and regenerative practices, leadership and their relationship to educational effectiveness and productivity.  Activity experience in the application of management theory in schools.  This course meets the requirements of the Cal Poly Sustainability Learning Objectives (SLO).  3 seminars, 1 activity.

classes.name: Education Planning and Decision Making
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: Graduate standing and consent of instructor.
classes.desc: Concepts of planning and decision making in educational administration that utilize a wide range of data gathering and analysis procedures.  3 seminars, 1 activity.

classes.name: Educational Program Management and  Evaluation
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: Graduate standing and consent of instructor.
classes.desc: Supervision, management, and evaluation of educational curriculum and educational programs.  Current trends in program management including mapping, monitoring, alignment.  3 seminars, 1 activity.

classes.name: Educational Personnel Supervision and Evaluation
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: Graduate standing and consent of instructor.
classes.desc: Principles and processes for the supervision and evaluation of certificated and classified staff including legal, research, and professional considerations.  3 seminars, 1 activity.

classes.name: Managing Action Research Communities
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: Admission to School of Education's Educational Leadership and Administration Master's program.
classes.desc: Examination of issues that affect educational leaders implementing and managing large-scale collaborative action research projects.  Application of interventions based on action research findings.  2 seminars.

classes.name: Administrative Services Fieldwork
classes.pre_reqs: CR/NCPrerequisite: Admittance to the Administrative Services Credential program and consent of instructor.
classes.desc: Supervised fieldwork in school administration for supervision at the elementary and secondary level.  Assignments must encompass three of the four academic quarters and must involve some multicultural experience.  Total credit limited to 18 units, only 9 of which may be applied toward master's degree.  Credit/No Credit grading only.

classes.name: Professional e-Portfolios for Educational Leaders
classes.pre_reqs: CR/NCPrerequisite: Enrollment in the Educational Leadership and Administration Program (ELAP).
classes.desc: Demonstration of exemplars of professional practice keyed to standards for the California Preliminary Administrative Services Credential.  Class meets two (2) times per quarter.  Faculty meet individually with students as to address portfolio development on a case-by-case basis.  Credit/No Credit grading only.  1 activity.

classes.name: Literacy Across the Curriculum
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: Graduate standing.
classes.desc: Supporting students' literacy development across school subjects -- English language arts, mathematics, science, social studies -- through an integrated instructional approach focusing on critical literacy as meaning-making, accommodating diverse students including English language learners and students with special needs.  4 seminars.

classes.name: Advanced Classroom Pedagogy
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: Graduate standing.
classes.desc: Principles of authentic pedagogy and development of a classroom learning community.  Examination of the role of classroom culture and advanced instructional strategies to foster conceptual development and disciplinary ways of knowing in diverse classrooms.  4 seminars.

classes.name: Integrative Approaches to Curriculum
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: Graduate standing.
classes.desc: Perspectives, principles and practices for designing curriculum to foster authentic instruction using integrative approaches.  Emphasis on designing for the development of multiple literacies.  3 seminars, 1 activity.

classes.name: Advanced Classroom Pedagogy in English Language Arts
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: Graduate standing.
classes.desc: The relationship between theory, research and practice in English Language Arts.  Emphasis is on reading processes and principles and advanced teaching practices for the English Language Arts with attention to working with diverse students including English language learners and students with special needs.  4 seminars.

classes.name: Social Justice in Education: In & Out of the Classroom
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: Admission to a School of Education Master's program.
classes.desc: Examines social justice education approaches inside and outside the classroom.  Prepares graduate students to develop an action-oriented project that includes strategies for advocating for marginalized students.  3 seminars, 1 activity.

classes.name: Advanced Field Experiences in Education
classes.pre_reqs: CR/NCPrerequisite: Admission to a School of Education Master's program.
classes.desc: Advanced field experience and practical application of master's degree emphasis for general and special education teachers, school administrators and school support personnel.  Total credit limited to 12 units for specialist credentials.  Total credit limited to 6 units for the master's degree.  Credit/No Credit grading only.

classes.name: Advanced Classroom Pedagogy in Mathematics Education
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: Admission to a School of Education Master's program.
classes.desc: Standards-based principles and advanced pedagogical practices for mathematics instruction in diverse classroom settings.  4 seminars.

classes.name: Administration of Special Programs and Services
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: Graduate standing and consent of instructor.
classes.desc: Principles and practices of organizing and administering special education, reading, counseling, and other support programs.  Assessment and placement procedures, middle management's role, overview of specially funded programs, historical precedents and future trends.  3 seminars, 1 activity.

classes.name: Advanced Collaboration and Consultation for Teachers of Students with Special Needs
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: Admission into the Level I Special Education Credential Program and master's degree program in education.
classes.desc: Advanced studies and skills in educational consultation.  Emphasis on the collaborative and consultative role of the special educator with a wide range of individuals from diverse cultural backgrounds including school personnel, parents, outside agencies, and paraprofessionals.  3 seminars, 2 activities.

classes.name: Reading and Language Arts Instruction in Special Education
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: Admission into the Level I Special Education Credential Program and master's degree program in education.
classes.desc: Overview of principles of reading instruction, elements of the language arts program including literature-based reading, content area reading, and the role of phonics, emergent literacy, and diagnosis of reading problems for special education teachers.  3 seminars, 2 activities.

classes.name: Assessment Strategies for Special Education
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: Admission to MS in Special Education.
classes.desc: Using norm referenced, criterion referenced, and curriculum based testing for assessing academic, behavioral, and physical status of individuals with exceptional needs, including English language learners, for referral purposes.  Instructional and evaluation decisions regarding exceptional students in school settings.  3 seminars, 2 activities.

classes.name: Support and Transition Strategies in Special Education
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: Admission to MS in Special Education.
classes.desc: Basic guidance techniques for teachers working with exceptional individuals and their families.  Career selection, preparation, and counseling.  Transition from school to work, and community resource utilization.  3 seminars, 2 activities.

classes.name: Behavior Disorders and Positive Behavior Support Strategies
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: Admission to MS in Special Education.
classes.desc: Assessment of students whose behavior impedes either their own learning or the learning of other students.  Strategies for facilitating proactive educational, environmental and social-emotional techniques for supporting students with challenging behavior.  3 seminars, 2 activities.

classes.name: Introduction to the Counseling Profession
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: Admission to MS in Higher Education, Counseling and Student Affairs.
classes.desc: Overview of the counseling profession, history, philosophy, theory and ethics.  Required activity.  3 seminars, 1 activity.

classes.name: Multicultural Counseling
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: Admission to MS in Higher Education, Counseling and Student Affairs.
classes.desc: Initiation of critical analysis of personal beliefs and attitudes regarding counseling in a diverse society.  Focus on a variety of approaches to explore the beliefs and attitudes of the student in counseling settings, and examination of strategies considered effective in working with diverse populations.  3 seminars, 1 activity.

classes.name: Career Counseling
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: Admission to MS in Higher Education, Counseling and Student Affairs.
classes.desc: Focus on the study and application of career development theories in career counseling.  Utilizing appraisal instruments, community referral resources, occupational information, computerized retrieval systems, and personal and social data and required activities.  3 seminars, 1 activity.

classes.name: Counseling Theories
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: Admission to MS in Higher Education, Counseling and Student Affairs.
classes.desc: Theories and practice of counseling with special emphasis on the counseling process.  Emphasis of conditions of counseling, counseling techniques, counseling diverse populations and the counselor as a professional helper.  3 seminars, 1 activity.

classes.name: Group Counseling
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: EDUC 555, EDUC 560 or consent of instructor.
classes.desc: Theory and practice of group counseling, client selection, group structure, process and termination, and application of theories to specific developmental groups.  Communication and facilitation skills emphasized with relevant ethics and law.  3 seminars, 1 activity.

classes.name: Student Development - Higher Education
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: Admission to MS in Higher Education, Counseling and Student Affairs.
classes.desc: Exploration of the roles and competencies of the student development specialist in higher education.  Review of relevant developmental theory with emphasis on practical implementation.  Explore current issues and trends in higher education, and organizational framework.  4 seminars.

classes.name: Legal and Ethical Issues in Counseling
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: Admission to MS in Higher Education, Counseling and Student Affairs.
classes.desc: Consideration of legal, ethical, cultural and related professional issues as they affect the practice of counseling.  3 seminars, 1 activity.

classes.name: Counseling Measurement and Assessment
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: Admission to MS in Higher Education, Counseling and Student Affairs.
classes.desc: Training and evaluation in the utilization of tests, scales, measures, and other instruments with K-12, and college-age students.  An understanding of culturally appropriate tests and measures, collaboration with school personnel, parents, and students in the review and interpretation of test scores and measures.  3 seminars, 1 activity.

classes.name: Leadership and Consultation in Counseling
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: Admission to MS in Higher Education, Counseling and Student Affairs.
classes.desc: Development of skills in planning, organizing, coordinating, and delivering programs that generate systemic change through establishing collaboration within schools, communities and other stakeholders.  Emphasis on social action and its role in the counseling profession.  3 seminars, 1 activity.

classes.name: Individual Counseling Techniques
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: Admission to MS in Higher Education, Counseling and Student Affairs.
classes.desc: Theory and practice of individual counseling, process and termination, and application of theories to specific developmental issues working with K-12 students.  Communication and facilitation skills emphasized, working with diverse populations and following legal and ethical guidelines.  3 seminars, 1 activity.

classes.name: Selected Advanced Topics
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: Graduate standing or consent of instructor.
classes.desc: Directed group study of selected topics for graduate students.  Open to undergraduate and graduate students.  The Class Schedule will list topic selected.  Total credit limited to 8 units.  1 to 4 lectures.

classes.name: Field Experience, Counseling
classes.pre_reqs: CR/NCPrerequisite: EDUC 555, EDUC 560 and Advancement to Candidacy.
classes.desc: Practical application of guidance services and counseling in public schools, colleges and community settings.  Seminars with university staff included.  Total credit limited to 24 units.  Credit/No Credit grading only.  Maximum of 12 units may be applied toward MS in Higher Education, Counseling and Student Affairs.

classes.name: Introduction to Inquiry in Education
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: Admission to a School of Education Master's program.
classes.desc: Explanation of social construction of knowledge, and the philosophical basis of quantitative and qualitative research.  Introduction to professional literature search techniques and to professional organizations as a basis for educational inquiry.  The Class Schedule will list topic selected.  Total credit limited to 12 units.  3 seminars, 1 activity.

classes.name: Educational Foundations and Current Issues
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: Admission to a School of Education Master's Program.
classes.desc: Historical, organizational, legal and philosophical characteristics of education in the United States.  Emphasis on the analysis of contemporary issues focusing on these characteristics.  The Class Schedule will list topic selected.  Total credit limited to 12 units.  Course may be offered in classroom-based or online format.  4 seminars.

classes.name: Education, Culture, and Learning
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: Admission to School of Education Master's Program.
classes.desc: Cultural characteristics of educational institutions and practice.  Review of theory and research relating to the social and organizational context in which learning and teaching takes place.  The Class Schedule will list topic selected.  Total credit limited to 12 units.  4 seminars.

classes.name: Educational Research Methods
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: Admission to a School of Education Master's Program.
classes.desc: Educational research methodologies, application of inferential and descriptive statistics, critical analysis of research designs and data collection techniques.  The Class Schedule will list topic selected.  Total credit limited to 12 units.  3 seminars, 1 activity.

classes.name: Research Application in Education
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: EDUC 589.
classes.desc: Application of social science research techniques to problems in education and human services.  Capstone experience for the School of Education master's inquiry course sequence.  Completion of an inquiry project required.  2 seminars, 2 activities.

classes.name: Action Research Project in Education
classes.pre_reqs: CR/NCPrerequisite: EDUC 589.
classes.desc: Completion and presentation of the results of an action research project that addresses a meaningful question in the practice of education.  Total credit limited to 6 units.  Credit/No Credit grading only.

classes.name: Thesis in Education
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: Consent of graduate committee and supervising faculty member(s).
classes.desc: Completion of a thesis pertinent to the field of education.  Student must register for each quarter of advisement.  Total credit limited to 6 units.

classes.name: Introduction to Electrical Engineering
classes.pre_reqs: Concurrent: EE 151.
classes.desc: A general overview of the field of electrical engineering.  Preparation for successful completion of the Electrical Engineering (EE) program at Cal Poly.  1 lecture.  Not required for students with transfer credit for EE 211 or EE 241.

classes.name: Electric Circuit Analysis I
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: MATH 142 or equivalent. Recommended: EE 111/151.
classes.desc: Introduction to basic circuit analysis.  Resistive circuits, voltage and current sources, network theorems.  Course may be offered in classroom-based or online format.  2 lectures.

classes.name: Electric Circuit Analysis I
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: MATH 142. Concurrent: EE 143. Recommended: EE 111, EE 151; PHYS 133.
classes.desc: Basic circuit analysis and basic electronics manufacturing.  Resistive circuits, voltage and current sources, op-amps, network theorems.  Practical electronics manufacturing expanded through concepts such as CAD/CAM design, Design for Manufacture (DFM), documentation requirements, deposition and etching processes, prototyping, and production planning.  PCB design and assembly.  3 lectures.

classes.name: Digital Design
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: An orientation course in student's major (EE 111 and EE 151; or CPE 100) and CPE/CSC 101.
classes.desc: Number systems, Boolean algebra, Boolean functions, and function minimization.  Analysis and design of combinational and sequential digital logic circuits.  Hardware Description Language (HDL) concepts and applications digital design and synthesis in FPGAs.  Course may be offered in classroom-based or online format.  3 lectures, 1 laboratory.  Crosslisted as CPE/EE 133.

classes.name: Electronics Manufacturing and Circuit Analysis Laboratory
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: MATH 142. Concurrent: EE 113. Recommended: EE 111, EE 151; PHYS 133.
classes.desc: Use of electrical and electronic test equipment.  Introduction to engineering design flow (design, simulate, build, test).  PCB design and manufacturing.  1 laboratory.

classes.name: Introduction to Electrical Engineering Laboratory
classes.pre_reqs: Concurrent: EE 111.
classes.desc: A variety of hands-on experiments and demonstrations in electrical engineering, providing background and motivation for successful completion of the Electrical Engineering (EE) program at Cal Poly.  Not open to students with credit for EE 241.  1 laboratory.

classes.name: Special Problems
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: Consent of department chair.
classes.desc: Individual investigation, research, studies or surveys of selected problems.  Total credit limited to 4 units, with a maximum of 2 units per quarter.

classes.name: Electric Circuit Theory
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: MATH 244, PHYS 133.
classes.desc: Application of fundamental circuit laws and theorems to the analysis of DC, and steady-state single-phase and three-phase circuits.  Not for electrical engineering majors.  Course may be offered in classroom-based or online format.  3 lectures.

classes.name: Electric Circuit Analysis II
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: EE 112 or EE 113. Prerequisite or Concurrent: PHYS 133, MATH 244. Concurrent: EE 241.
classes.desc: Continuation of basic circuit analysis.  Op-amp circuits.  Energy storage elements, RC and RL circuits, and AC steady state analysis.  3 lectures.

classes.name: Electric Circuit Analysis III
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: MATH 244, EE 211. Concurrent: EE 242.
classes.desc: AC power, 3-phase circuits.  Mutual inductance, series and parallel resonance and two-port networks.  Frequency response, including Bode plots.  3 lectures.

classes.name: Continuous-Time Signals and Systems
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: BMED 355; or EE 212 and EE 242. Recommended: MATH 241.
classes.desc: Continuous-time systems analysis, with emphasis on linear time-invariant (LTI) systems.  Classifications of continuous-time systems.  Convolution and its application to LTI systems.  The Laplace transform, Fourier transform, and Fourier series, and their application to the analysis of LTI systems.  4 lectures.

classes.name: Computer Design and Assembly Language Programming
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: CPE/EE 133.
classes.desc: Design and implementation of digital computer circuits via CAD tools for programmable logic devices (PLDs).  Basic computer design with its datapath components and control unit.  Introduction to assembly language programming of an off-the-shelf RISC-based microcontroller.  Not open to students with credit in CPE/EE 229.  3 lectures, 1 laboratory.  Crosslisted as CPE/EE 233.

classes.name: Electric Circuit Analysis Laboratory II
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: EE 112 or EE 113; EE 151 for EE students. Prerequisite or concurrent: MATH 244; PHYS 133. Concurrent: EE 211.
classes.desc: Use of electrical and electronic test equipment.  Experimental verification of circuit analysis concepts including Kirchhoff's Laws, Thevenin's Theorem, maximum power transfer and superposition.  1 laboratory.

classes.name: Electric Circuit Analysis Laboratory III
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: MATH 244, EE 241 or consent of department chair. Concurrent: EE 212.
classes.desc: Observation of transient and steady-state phenomena, phase-shift circuits, resonance.  Use of phasor diagrams.  1 laboratory.

classes.name: Electric Circuits Laboratory
classes.pre_reqs: Concurrent: EE 201.
classes.desc: Techniques of measurement of DC and steady-state AC circuit parameters.  Equivalent circuits, nonlinear elements, resonance.  1 laboratory.

classes.name: Energy Conversion Electromagnetics
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: EE 212 and EE 242; or EE 201 and EE 251. Concurrent: EE 295.
classes.desc: Fundamentals of electro-mechanical energy conversion.  Magnetic circuits and electromagnetic devices.  Theory of operation and operating characteristics of transformers, and AC induction and synchronous machines.  3 lectures.

classes.name: Intro C Programming with a Hardware Emphasis
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: CPE/CSC 101. Recommended: EE 151.
classes.desc: Introduction to the C Programming Language with an emphasis on microprocessor implementation and applications.  Not open to students with credit in CPE/CSC 357 or CPE/EE 329.  1 laboratory.

classes.name: Intro C++ Programming with a Hardware Emphasis
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: CPE/CSC 101. Recommended: EE 151.
classes.desc: Introduction to the C++ Objected Oriented Programming Language with an emphasis on Microprocessor Implementation and applications.  1 laboratory.

classes.name: Selected Topics
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: Open to undergraduate students and consent of instructor.
classes.desc: Directed group study of selected topics.  The Class Schedule will list topic selected.  Total credit limited to 8 units.  1 to 4 lectures.

classes.name: Selected Laboratory
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: Consent of instructor.
classes.desc: Directed group laboratory study of selected topics.  The Class Schedule will list topic selected.  Total credit limited to 6 units.  1 to 2 laboratories.

classes.name: Energy Conversion Electromagnetics Laboratory
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: EE 212 & EE 242 or EE 201 & EE 251. Concurrent: EE 255.
classes.desc: Single-phase and three-phase transformers.  Starting of rotating machines, evaluation of characteristics of rotating machines.  1 laboratory.

classes.name: Classical Control Systems
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: EE 228. Concurrent: EE 342. Recommended: EE 368.
classes.desc: Introduction to feedback control systems.  System modeling.  Transfer functions.  Graphical system representation.  System time response, stability.  Root Locus.  Frequency response.  Compensation.  3 lectures.

classes.name: Semiconductor Device Electronics
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: CHEM 124, EE 212 & EE 242, EE 143 or IME 156 or IME 458, PHYS 211. Concurrent: EE 346.
classes.desc: Internal operation, semiconductor physics, terminal characteristics, models and application of diodes (LEDs, solar cells, and photo-diodes) and transistors (field-effect and bipolar).  3 lectures.

classes.name: Digital Electronics and Integrated Circuits
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: CPE/EE 133, EE 306 and EE 346. Corequisite: CPE/EE 233. Concurrent: EE 347.
classes.desc: Analysis, design, application and interfacing of integrated logic circuits, including NMOS, CMOS, TTL, ECL, and other logic families.  3 lectures.

classes.name: Analog Electronics and Integrated Circuits
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: EE 302 & EE 342, EE 307 & EE 347. Concurrent: EE 348.
classes.desc: Analysis and design of integrated circuits for use in analog applications.  Gain, frequency response, and feedback of linear small-signal amplifiers.  3 lectures.

classes.name: Introduction to Communication Systems
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: STAT 350.
classes.desc: Analog modulation, including:  double-sideband modulation, amplitude modulation, single-sideband modulation, frequency modulation, phase modulation.  Performances of such systems in the presence of white Gaussian noise.  Implementations of transmitters and receivers.  3 lectures.

classes.name: Electronics
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: EE 201 or BRAE 216 for BRAE majors.
classes.desc: Semiconductor devices and circuits.  Instrumentation amplifiers, power control rectifiers, feedback, pulse circuits, digital logic circuits.  Not for Electrical Engineering majors.  3 lectures.

classes.name: Microcontrollers for Everyone
classes.pre_reqs: 2020-21 or later: Upper-Div GE Area B2019-20 or earlier catalog: GE Area B5, B6, or B7Prerequisite: Junior standing; completion of GE Area A with grades of C- or better; and one course in GE Area B4 with a grade of C- or better (GE Area B1 for students on the 2019-20 or earlier catalogs).
classes.desc: Microcontroller history and computer systems overview.  Introduction to basic electrical circuits and computer programming concepts.  3 lectures, 1 laboratory.  Fulfills GE Area Upper-Division B (GE Areas B5, B6, or B7 for students on the 2019-20 catalog).

classes.name: Discrete Time Signals and Systems
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: BMED 355 or EE 228. Concurrent: CPE/EE 368.
classes.desc: Discrete-time systems and analysis, with emphasis on linear time-invariant (LTI) systems.  Sampling theorem.  Classification of discrete-time systems.  Convolution and its application to LTI systems.  The z transform, discrete-time Fourier transform, and discrete Fourier transform.  Introduction to digital filters.  Not open to students with credit in CPE 327.  3 lectures.  Crosslisted as CPE/EE 328.

classes.name: Microcontroller-Based Systems Design
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: EE 307 & EE 347, EE 229 & EE 269 or CPE/EE 233.
classes.desc: Design, implementation and testing of microcontroller-based systems.  Hardware and C software for embedded systems to sense and actuate external devices.  I/O common embedded systems to interface I/O devices and protocols.  Analysis of power consumption.  Ethics.  3 lectures, 1 laboratory.  Not open to students with credit in CPE/EE 336.  Crosslisted as CPE/EE 329.

classes.name: Electromagnetic Fields and Transmission
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: EE 201 and EE 251; or EE 212 and EE 242; and MATH 241. Concurrent: EE 375.
classes.desc: Maxwell's equations.  Plane wave propagation in free space.  Static electric and magnetic fields.  Distributed-circuit concepts and transmission line parameters.  Reflections and standing waves.  The Smith chart and its applications.  Transmission line measurements and impedance matching techniques.  4 lectures.

classes.name: Microprocessor System Design
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: CPE/EE 233.
classes.desc: Introduction to microcontrollers and integrated microprocessor systems.  Hardware/software trade-offs, system economics, and functional configurations.  Interface design, real-time clocks, interrupts, A/D conversion, serial and parallel communications, watch-dog timers, low power operation, event-based inter-peripheral communication, and assembly and higher-level language programming techniques.  Architecture and design of sampled data and low-power systems.  Not open to students with credit in CPE/EE 329.  3 lectures, 1 laboratory.  Crosslisted as CPE/EE 336.

classes.name: Classical Control Systems Laboratory
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: EE 228. Concurrent: EE 302. Recommended: EE 368.
classes.desc: Laboratory work pertaining to classical control systems, including servo control, transient and frequency responses, stability, and computer-aided analysis of control systems.  1 laboratory.

classes.name: Semiconductor Device Electronics Laboratory
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: CHEM 124, EE 212 & EE 242, EE 143 or IME 156 or IME 458, PHYS 211. Concurrent: EE 306. Recommended: ENGL 134.
classes.desc: Experimental determination of device characteristics and models.  1 laboratory.

classes.name: Digital Electronics and Integrated Circuits Laboratory
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: CPE/EE 133, EE 306 and EE 346. Corequisite: CPE/EE 233. Concurrent: EE 307.
classes.desc: Computer simulation and experimental investigation of the characteristics, applications and interfacing of different logic families.  1 laboratory.

classes.name: Analog Electronics and Integrated Circuits Laboratory
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: EE 302 & EE 342, EE 307 & EE 347. Concurrent: EE 308.
classes.desc: Design, simulation, construction and testing of solid state amplifiers and sub-circuits to meet stated specifications.  1 laboratory.

classes.name: Electronics Laboratory
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: EE 251 or BRAE 216 for BRAE majors. Concurrent: EE 321.
classes.desc: Instrumentation amplifiers, feedback, rectifiers and power control, pulse and digital logic circuits.  1 laboratory.

classes.name: Signals and Systems Laboratory
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: BMED 355 or EE 228. Concurrent: CPE/EE 328.
classes.desc: Laboratory work pertaining to linear systems, including Fourier analysis, time and frequency responses, and system transfer function.  Not open to students with credit in CPE 367.  1 laboratory.  Crosslisted as CPE/EE 368.

classes.name: Electromagnetic Fields and Transmission Laboratory
classes.pre_reqs: Concurrent: EE 335.
classes.desc: Transmission line and passive component measurements at microwave frequencies.  Response to pulse excitation using time domain techniques and sinusoidal excitation using frequency domain techniques.  Application of the Smith Chart and network analyzers in transmission line characterization and impedance matching techniques.  1 laboratory.

classes.name: Special Problems
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: Consent of department chair.
classes.desc: Individual investigation, research, studies, or surveys of selected problems.  Total credit limited to 5 units.

classes.name: Electromagnetic Waves
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: EE 335.
classes.desc: Maxwell's equations and plane wave propagation in materials.  Reflection and transmission of normal and oblique incidence plane waves at planar boundaries between different media.  Wave guides.  Antennas.  4 lectures.

classes.name: Introduction to Photonics and Fiber Optics
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: EE 306 and EE 346; or PHY 323. Concurrent: EE 443.
classes.desc: Introduction to modern fiber optics and photonics.  Lens systems, photodiodes, LEDs, laser diodes, transmitter and receiver design, diffraction, interference, optical signal processing, propagation of light in optical fibers.  3 lectures.

classes.name: High Frequency Amplifier Design
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: EE 308 & EE 348, EE 335. Concurrent: EE 445.
classes.desc: Design of modern electronic amplifiers and amplifier systems with advanced techniques.  UHF and microwave small signal amplifier design utilizing microstrip transmission lines, S parameters of GaAs FET, and bipolar transistors.  Low noise, broadband, and power amplifier designs.  Oscillator designs.  3 lectures.

classes.name: Power Systems Analysis I
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: EE 335, EE 255 & EE 295.
classes.desc: Introduction to electric power systems.  Representation of power systems and its components including transmission lines, synchronous machines, transformers and loads.  One line diagrams and per unit calculations.  symmetrical faults.  Load flow analysis.  4 lectures.

classes.name: Power Systems Analysis II
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: EE 406.
classes.desc: Symmetrical components, unbalanced faults, power system stability, system protection, relays and relay systems, power system instrumentation and measurement techniques, economic operation.  4 lectures.

classes.name: Electronic Design
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: EE 308 & EE 348; CPE/EE 328 & CPE/EE 368, or CPE 327 & CPE 367; CPE/EE 329 or CPE/EE 336 or CPE 316. Concurrent: EE 449.
classes.desc: Design of electronic systems and subsystems using analog and digital integrated circuits.  Design principles and techniques.  Analysis and design of feedback amplifiers; operational amplifier applications.  Design of analog/digital and digital/analog converters.  Power supply design.  Emphasis on IC implementation.  3 lectures.

classes.name: Power Electronics I
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: EE 308 and EE 348, or EE 321 and consent of instructor.
classes.desc: Introduction to power electronic converters and power semiconductor devices.  Steady state analysis, performance study, and design of uncontrolled and controlled rectifiers, non-isolated and isolated DC-DC converters, AC voltage controllers, and single-phase inverters.  Use of commercially available software.  3 lectures, 1 laboratory.

classes.name: Power Electronics II
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: EE 410.
classes.desc: Switching trajectory, switching losses, and Safe Operating Area of solid-state switches.  Analysis and design of snubber circuits.  Synchronous rectification.  Steady-state analysis and operation of resonant DC-DC converters.  Power quality and harmonics.  Operation of HVDC transmission lines, introduction to flexible AC transmission system (FACTS) controllers, multilevel and three-phase inverters.  Use of commercially available software.  3 lectures, 1 laboratory.

classes.name: Advanced Analog Circuits
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: EE 314, EE 409 & EE 449. Concurrent: EE 452.
classes.desc: Application of linear integrated circuits to data acquisition problems:  transducer interfacing, linear and nonlinear preprocessing, phase-locked loops, and high performance quantization and recovery (A/D, D/A conversion).  3 lectures.

classes.name: Advanced Electronic Design
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: CSC 101, EE 409 and EE 449.
classes.desc: Advanced design of electronic circuits and subsystems, including sustainability and design as a process.  Automated testing with GPIB instruments.  Implementation of specific design projects, including team-based projects.  3 lectures, 1 laboratory.

classes.name: Robotic Systems Integration
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: EE/CPE 329 or EE/CPE 336 or CSC/CPE 357 or ME 305.
classes.desc: Integration of sensors, actuators, chassis, and Linux-based computational platforms into functioning autonomous robotic systems.  Embedded Linux system programming, inter-process software communication, basic sensor fusion techniques, Pulse Width Modulation (PWM) motor actuation, and web-based interfacing for remote system way-pointing and monitoring.  3 lectures, 1 laboratory.  Crosslisted as CPE/EE 414.

classes.name: Communication Systems Design
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: CPE 327 or EE 328.
classes.desc: Design of modern wireline and wireless electronic communication and telemetry systems.  Emphasis:  practical implementation and comparative evaluation of various communication systems.  3 lectures.

classes.name: Digital Communication Systems
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: EE 314; EE 328 or CPE 327.
classes.desc: Baseband (PCM, PAM, DM) signals and transmission.  Bandpass (PSK, FSK, ASK) modulation and demodulation techniques.  Digital communication signals in the presence of noise and detection of signals in Gaussian noise.  Other topics such as:  quantization, multiplexing and multiple access, spread spectrum techniques, coding, synchronization.  3 lectures.

classes.name: Alternating Current Machines
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: EE 255 & EE 295.
classes.desc: Alternating current machines.  Generalized, operational and dynamic analysis.  Steady-state and transient operation of synchronous machines and linear induction machines.  3 lectures, 1 laboratory.

classes.name: Photonic Engineering
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: EE 335 or PHYS 323. Concurrent: EE 458.
classes.desc: Modern optical design with emphasis on the use of computers to design simple optical systems and to evaluate existing optical designs.  Paraxial and exact ray tracing through thin and thick lenses, mirrors, and prisms.  Radiometry and photometry.  Electro-optic, acousto-optic, and magneto-optic modulators and their applications.  Thermal detectors, semiconductor detectors, and charge coupled device (CCD) arrays.  3 lectures.

classes.name: Digital Signal Processing
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: CSC 101 or CSC 231; EE 328 and EE 368, or CPE 327 and CPE 367. Concurrent: EE 459.
classes.desc: Review of Z-transform, convolution and discrete Fourier Transform.  Digital filter design.  Fast Fourier Transform.  Theory and applications of digital signal processors.  3 lectures.

classes.name: Sustainable Electric Energy Conversion
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: CHEM 124; EE 255 and EE 295.
classes.desc: Electrical engineering aspects of photovoltaic and wind power generation and usage, and electrochemical energy conversion.  Power control, processing, and quality for grid-connected and stand-alone systems.  Distribution and storage of electric energy.  Hydrogen and synthetic fuels.  Distributed generation.  3 lectures, 1 laboratory.

classes.name: Polymer Electronics Laboratory
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: EE 347 or MATE 340 or CHEM 319 or PHYS 340.
classes.desc: Experimental procedures in polymer electronics.  Investigation of the characteristics of a polymer electronic device.  1 laboratory.  Crosslisted as EE/PHYS 422.

classes.name: Micro/Nano Fabrication
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: BMED 212 or MATE 210.
classes.desc: Fabrication science and technology for creating micro and nano scale devices.  Explore basic processes such as oxidation, diffusion, ion implantation, etching, chemical and physical vapor deposition, photolithography.  Develop an understanding of the science of each process and how to select the right steps for fabricating electronic, photon and micro-electro-mechanical systems devices.  3 lectures.  Crosslisted as BMED 434/EE 423/MATE 430.

classes.name: Introduction to Remote Sensing
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: MATH 244; senior or graduate standing in engineering.
classes.desc: Radiation characteristics, sensor technology and platforms, satellite systems, system design tradeoffs, collection and transmission of radio-metric data, GPS, thermal remote sensing, active radar and microwave remote sensing, interpretation and exploitation of remotely sensed data for various applications.  3 lectures, 1 laboratory.

classes.name: Analog Filter Design
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: EE 409 & EE 449. Concurrent: EE 455.
classes.desc: Approximation Theory.  All pole filters.  Frequency transformations.  Elements of passive synthesis.  Time delay filters.  Theory and design of active filter.  Sensitivity analysis.  3 lectures.

classes.name: Computer Vision
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: CPE 327 or CPE/CSC 357 or EE 328 or ME 305.
classes.desc: Introduction to the concepts of 2D and 3D computer vision:  low-level image processing methods such as filtering and edge detection; feature extraction; segmentation and clustering; stereo vision; appearance-based and model-based algorithms.  3 lectures, 1 laboratory.  Crosslisted as CPE/EE 428.

classes.name: Computer-Aided Design of VLSI Devices
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: EE 307 and EE 347. Recommended: EE 308 and EE 348, for students interested in analog design.
classes.desc: Design of VLSI circuits using state-of-the-art CAD software.  Design issues and algorithms related to design using CAD.  Full custom design through automated design and a major multi-week chip design project in lab.  3 lectures, 1 laboratory.  Crosslisted as CPE 441/EE 431.

classes.name: Digital Control Systems
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: EE 302 and EE 342; or CPE 327 and CPE 367. Concurrent: CPE/EE 472. Recommended: EE 328 and EE 368.
classes.desc: Theory and applications of digital computers in linear control systems.  Analysis and design of microprocessor-based controls.  Introduction of continuous and discrete transform methods for design of closed-loop dynamic systems.  Applications in robotics, automotive, aircraft and industrial process control.  3 lectures.  Crosslisted as CPE/EE 432.

classes.name: Introduction to Magnetic Design
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: EE 255 and EE 295.
classes.desc: Design of magnetic components.  Fundamentals of magnetics, magnetic cores, design of power transformer, three-phase transformer, dc inductor, ac inductors, dc-dc converter transformer design, actuators.  Use of commercially available software.  3 lectures, 1 laboratory.

classes.name: Automotive Engineering for a Sustainable Future
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: Junior standing in any engineering or physical science major.
classes.desc: Multidisciplinary investigation of automotive renewable fuels and electric/hybrid vehicles.  Analyze and design related technologies and systems.  Methods for complete-cycle energy and GHG analysis.  Comparative emissions, efficiency, power output, and infrastructure requirements.  Laboratory projects converting engines and vehicles to operate on alternative fuels or electric propulsion.  3 lectures, 1 laboratory.  Crosslisted as BRAE/EE 434.

classes.name: Industrial Power Control and Automation
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: EE 255, EE 295, EE 302, and EE 342.
classes.desc: Introduction to programmable automation controllers including custom developed functions, electrical hardware interfaces, communications networking to intelligent electronic devices, and machine operator interface terminals.  Applications of industrial power control and automation systems including protection equipment, motor controllers, renewable energy, and sensors.  1 laboratory.

classes.name: Introduction to Real-Time Operating Systems
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: CPE/EE 329 or CPE/EE 336.
classes.desc: Theory, design and implementation of real-time operating system-based embedded systems.  Scheduling algorithms, operating system resources, peripheral device interfacing and embedded system architecture.  Resource management issues in a resource-limited (microcontroller-based) environment.  3 lectures, 1 laboratory.  Crosslisted as CPE/EE 439.

classes.name: Wireless Communications
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: EE 335, EE 314. Concurrent: EE 480.
classes.desc: Wireless microwave system design and analysis.  RF transmission lines, microwave networks, receiver design, modulation techniques, and mixer characterization and realizations.  Noise and distortion, RF oscillators and frequency synthesizers, filter design.  Radiating systems and electromagnetic wave propagation, microwave amplifier design.  3 lectures.

classes.name: Real Time Embedded Systems
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: CPE/EE 329 or CPE/EE 336 or CPE 316.
classes.desc: Theory, design and implementation of modern embedded systems.  Scheduling algorithms and operating system resources.  System on Chip (SoC) design issues such as interfacing with custom hardware description language (HDL) peripherals, high-performance chip interconnect standards, energy use, area, and hardware versus software performance trade-offs.  3 lectures, 1 laboratory.  Crosslisted as CPE/EE 442.

classes.name: Introduction to Photonics and Fiber Optics Laboratory
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: EE 306 and EE 346; or PHYS 323. Concurrent: EE 403.
classes.desc: Experimental study of optical fibers, optical lens systems, fiber amplifiers, light sources, and optical detectors.  Simulation of a simple fiber optical network using CAD tools.  Design, build, and test of fiber optic and free-space optical communication systems.  1 laboratory.

classes.name: Power Systems Laboratory
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: EE 406.
classes.desc: Protective relaying, coordination, and relay calibration.  Power control using transformers, parallel operation of generators, and computer simulation of power systems.  1 laboratory.

classes.name: High Frequency Amplifier Design Laboratory
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: EE 308 & EE 348, EE 335. Corequisite: EE 405.
classes.desc: Experimental investigation employing advanced techniques.  Design of high-frequency electronic amplifiers utilizing S-parameters of bipolar transistors, network analyzers, and computer simulation techniques.  1 laboratory.

classes.name: Design of Fault-Tolerant Digital Systems
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: CPE/EE 329 or CPE/EE 336 or CPE 316. Recommended: STAT 350.
classes.desc: Hardware and software fault tolerance concepts:  fault models, coding in computer systems, module and system level fault detection mechanisms, reconfiguration techniques for general purpose processors and ASICs, and software fault tolerance techniques such as recovery blocks, N-version programming, checkpointing, and recovery.  3 lectures, 1 laboratory.  Crosslisted as CPE/EE 446.

classes.name: Stringed Musical Instrument Acoustics, Mechanics, and Transducer Design
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: EE/CPE 329 or EE/CPE 336 or CPE 316 or ME 305.
classes.desc: Acoustics, sound production, and transducer design in the context of stringed musical instruments.  Introduces music theory, scales and temperament, sound radiation, structural dynamics of stringed instruments.  Integrates engineering topics including frequency spectrum analysis, electromagnetics, properties of materials, digital and analog circuit design.  3 lectures, 1 laboratory.  Crosslisted as CPE/EE 447.

classes.name: Electronic Design Laboratory
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: EE 308 & EE 348; CPE/EE 328 & CPE/EE 368, or CPE 327 & CPE 367; CPE/EE 329 or CPE/EE 336 or CPE 316. Concurrent: EE 409.
classes.desc: Design of electronic systems and subsystems using integrated circuits.  1 laboratory.

classes.name: Solar Photovoltaic System Engineering
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: one of the following: PHYS 104; PHYS 118; PHYS 121; or PHYS 141; and junior standing.
classes.desc: Engineering principles, design, and installation of solar photovoltaic power systems including grid-tie and off-grid systems.  Photonic energy conversion, solar module engineering, solar power electronics, photovoltaic site planning, mechanical and structural considerations, permit processes, government incentives, and analysis of financial and investment issues.  Field trips required.  3 lectures, 1 laboratory.  Crosslisted as BRAE/EE/HNRS 450.

classes.name: Advanced Analog Circuits Laboratory
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: EE 314, EE 409 & EE 449. Concurrent: EE 412.
classes.desc: Advanced laboratory study of LC and VCO oscillators, phase detectors, phase-locked loop circuits, transducer interface circuits, noise sources and signal-to-noise determination, ADC and DAC for data conversion.  Formal experiments and computer SPICE simulation.  1 laboratory.

classes.name: Analog Filter Design Laboratory
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: EE 409 & EE 449. Concurrent: EE 425.
classes.desc: Advanced laboratory study of sensitivity and stability of active networks prescribed for realization of transfer functions by active network synthesis techniques.  Formal experiments and individual project work.  1 laboratory.

classes.name: Digital Communication Systems Laboratory
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: EE 314; EE 328 & EE 368 or CPE 327 & CPE 367.
classes.desc: Methods of digital modulation and demodulation.  Emphasis on spectral analysis, bandwidth requirements and other practical considerations of modulation and demodulation.  1 laboratory.

classes.name: Photonic Engineering Laboratory
classes.pre_reqs: Concurrent: EE 418.
classes.desc: Experimental investigation of the techniques used in processing optical signals.  Formal experiments on electro-optic modulation, acousto-optic modulation.  Construction of an RF spectrum analyzer.  Analog processing of optical signals, and charge-coupled array devices.  1 laboratory.

classes.name: Digital Signal Processing Laboratory
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: CSC 101 or CSC 231; CPE 327 and CPE 367 or EE 328 and EE 368. Concurrent: EE 419.
classes.desc: Experiments in digital filter design and digital signal processing emphasizing various areas of application.  Formal experiments and individual project work, including DSP algorithm and digital filter analysis, design and implementation using Matlab, and real-time implementations using C on an embedded DSP processor.  1 laboratory.

classes.name: Senior Project Preparation
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: EE 314, EE 335. Corequisite: EE 409 & EE 449.
classes.desc: Introduction to teamwork and team-oriented project execution.  Project planning, scheduling and analysis.  Usage of tools for project management including Gantt and Pert Charts.  Project development, cost and time estimation using top-down and bottom-up approaches.  Ethics and ethical issues as they pertain to the conduct of engineering.  Development of senior project proposal.  1 lecture, 1 laboratory.

classes.name: Senior Project I
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: EE 409, EE 449 and EE 460.
classes.desc: Investigation and design of a project under faculty supervision.  Projects typical of problems which graduates must solve in their fields of employment.  Project results are presented in a formal report.

classes.name: Senior Project II
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: EE 461.
classes.desc: Continuation and completion of a project under faculty supervision.  Projects typical of problems which graduates must solve in their fields of employment.  Project results are presented in a formal report.

classes.name: Senior Project Design Laboratory I
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: EE 409, EE 449 and EE 460.
classes.desc: Investigation and design of a project under faculty supervision.  Projects typical of problems which graduates must solve in their fields of employment.  Project results are presented in a formal report.  Not open to students with credit in EE 461.  2 laboratories.

classes.name: Senior Project Design Laboratory II
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: EE 463.
classes.desc: Continuation and completion of a project under faculty supervision.  Projects typical of problems which graduates must solve in their fields of employment.  Project results are presented in a formal report.  Not open to students with credit in EE 462.  2 laboratories.

classes.name: Selected Advanced Topics
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: Consent of instructor.
classes.desc: Directed group study of selected topics for advanced students.  Open to undergraduate and graduate students.  The Class Schedule will list topic selected.  Total credit limited to 8 units.  1 to 4 lectures.

classes.name: Selected Advanced Laboratory
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: Consent of instructor.
classes.desc: Directed group laboratory study of selected topics for advanced students.  Open to undergraduate and graduate students.  The Class Schedule will list topic selected.  Total credit limited to 8 units.  1 to 4 laboratories.

classes.name: Digital Control Systems Laboratory
classes.pre_reqs: Concurrent: CPE/EE 432.
classes.desc: Design and programming of microprocessor-based digital controls for electro-mechanical plants.  Topics include digital control laws, translation of transfer functions into algorithms, assembly language programming, real-time software design, sample rate selection, finite word-length considerations.  1 laboratory.  Crosslisted as CPE/EE 472.

classes.name: Microfabrication Laboratory
classes.pre_reqs: Corequisite: BMED 434/EE 423/MATE 430.
classes.desc: Application of basic processes involved in microfabrication:  cleanroom protocol, oxidation, diffusion, photolithography etching and sputtering.  Explore process development through fabrication of electronic, photonic or microfluidic devices.  Each student will be part of a team that will fabricate and test a device.  1 laboratory.  Crosslisted as BMED 435/EE 473/MATE 435.

classes.name: Communication Networks and Systems Laboratory
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: CPE 327 and CPE 367; or CPE/EE 328 and CPE/EE 368.
classes.desc: Methods of wireline and wireless communication networks and systems.  Emphasis on TCP/IP wired networks and modern mobile communication standards.  1 laboratory.

classes.name: Wireless Communications Laboratory
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: EE 335, EE 314. Concurrent: EE 440.
classes.desc: Wireless microwave system design and analysis.  RF transmission lines, microwave networks, receiver design, modulation techniques, and mixer characterization and realizations.  Noise and distortion, RF oscillators and frequency synthesizers, filter design.  Radiating systems and electromagnetic wave propagation, microwave amplifier design.  1 laboratory.

classes.name: Cooperative Education Experience
classes.pre_reqs: CR/NCPrerequisite: Sophomore standing.
classes.desc: Part-time work experience in business, industry, government, and other areas of student career interest.  Positions are paid and usually require relocation and registration in course for two consecutive quarters.  Formal report and evaluation by work supervisor required.  No major credit allowed; total credit limited to 6 units.  Credit/No Credit grading only.

classes.name: Cooperative Education Experience
classes.pre_reqs: CR/NCPrerequisite: Sophomore standing and consent of instructor.
classes.desc: Full-time work experience in business, industry, government, and other areas of student career interest.  Positions are paid and usually require relocation and registration in course for two consecutive quarters.  Evaluation by work supervisor required.  Credit/No Credit grading only.  No major credit allowed; total credit limited to 24 units.

classes.name: Cooperative Education Experience
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: Two consecutive quarters of EE 494 immediately preceding EE 495; sophomore standing and consent of instructor.
classes.desc: Full-time work experience in business, industry, government, and other areas of student career interest.  Positions are paid and usually require relocation and registration in course for two consecutive quarters.  Formal report and evaluation by work supervisor required.  Major credit limited to 4 units; total credit limited to 12 units.

classes.name: Individual Study
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: Consent of department chair, graduate advisor, and supervising faculty member.
classes.desc: Advanced study planned and completed under the direction of a member of the department faculty.  Open only to graduate students who have demonstrated ability to do independent work.  Enrollment by petition.  Total credit limit at discretion of graduate advisor, not to exceed 9 units.

classes.name: Microwave Component and System Engineering
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: Graduate standing; or EE 306, EE 346, EE 335, and EE 375.
classes.desc: Passive and active microwave/millimeter wave system theory, design and project construction.  Microwave components such as power splitters, filters, mixers, detectors, oscillators, modulators, and amplifiers are designed, fabricated and tested.  Components are combined for system-level functionality projects.  3 lectures, 1 laboratory.

classes.name: Software Defined Radio
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: EE 314; and EE 328 or CPE 327; or graduate standing.
classes.desc: Introduction to software defined radios, including architectures of software defined radio receivers and transmitters, design principles and trade-offs, signal processing techniques, and applications of the technologies.  3 seminars, 1 laboratory.

classes.name: Computational Intelligence
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: Senior or graduate standing.
classes.desc: Theory, design, and applications of biologically inspired computational paradigms, including artificial neural networks, evolutionary computation, swarm intelligence, and hybrid intelligent systems.  4 seminars.

classes.name: Electric Machines Theory
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: EE 255 or equivalent, and graduate standing or consent of instructor.
classes.desc: Advanced topics in electric machines theory.  Introduction to Park's transformation.  Analysis of electric machines using Kron's generalized concept.  Vector control of induction machines.  4 seminars.

classes.name: Control Systems Theory
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: EE 302 or equivalent, and graduate standing or consent of instructor.
classes.desc: State representation of dynamic systems.  Mathematical models of physical devices, controllability and observability.  Design of closed-loop systems.  Optimal control theory.  4 seminars.

classes.name: Advanced Topics in Automatic Control
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: EE 513 or equivalent, EE 328 or similar course on discrete-time linear systems.
classes.desc: Summary course covering five selected graduate-level topics in automatic control theory and practice; implementation issues in digital control, nonlinear control theory and design, LQ and time optimal control, variable structure control, and fuzzy logic/model-free control.  4 seminars.

classes.name: Discrete Time Filters
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: EE 314 or equivalent, and graduate standing or consent of instructor.
classes.desc: Advanced topics in filter design and implementation.  Emphasis placed on current applications and on the processing of real signals.  Topics may include signal analysis via spectral estimation, short time Fourier transforms, and spectrograms.  Effects of coefficient quantization, and limits of practical filters.  State space realization.  Optimal and adaptive filters for signal prediction, system identification, and noise cancellation.  Techniques implemented in programming assignments.  4 seminars.

classes.name: Pattern Recognition
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: STAT 312 or STAT 350.
classes.desc: Fundamental topics in statistical pattern recognition including Bayesian decision theory, Maximum-likelihood and Bayesian estimation, non-parametric density estimation, feature selection, dimension reduction, and clustering, with application to image pattern recognition.  3 seminars, 1 laboratory.

classes.name: Power System Protection
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: EE 406 and graduate standing.
classes.desc: Unsymmetrical faults.  Protection fundamentals.  Instrument transformers.  Power system grounding.  Generator protection, transformer protection, busbar protection, line and motor protection.  3 seminars, 1 laboratory.

classes.name: Advanced Analysis of Power Systems
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: EE 406 or equivalent, and graduate standing or consent of instructor.
classes.desc: Advanced power system stability analysis, numerical methods in power system analysis.  4 seminars.

classes.name: Advanced Solar-Photovoltaic Systems Design
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: Graduate standing or consent of instructor.
classes.desc: Solar radiation and insolation variability.  Solar cell theory.  Photovoltaic module and array design.  Interfacing PV generators with various kinds of loads.  Power processing circuits and systems.  Energy storage options.  Stand-alone and grid-connected systems.  Life Cycle Assessment and Recycling of Solar PV equipment.  Economic, policy and sustainability issues.  4 seminars.

classes.name: Computer Systems
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: CPE/EE 329 or CPE/EE 336, or equivalent, and graduate standing or consent of instructor.
classes.desc: Organization of modern general purpose, high speed digital computer systems.  Design of arithmetic units, control units, memories and memory subsystems.  Cost, power and speed trade-offs in the design of such systems.  3 seminars, 1 laboratory.  Crosslisted as CPE/EE 521.

classes.name: Advanced Real-Time Operating Systems Design
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: CPE/EE 439.
classes.desc: Define and implement a microcontroller-based Real-Time Operating System (RTOS).  Advanced real-time concepts, kernel structure, task and time management, various intertask communication constructs including semaphores, queues and mailboxes.  Scheduler design, memory management and shared resource management in a resource-constrained microcontroller environment.  3 seminars, 1 laboratory.  Crosslisted as CPE/EE 522.

classes.name: Digital Systems Design
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: CPE/EE 329 or CPE/EE 336, and graduate standing.
classes.desc: Full-custom design and analysis of digital circuits using full CMOS, pass-transistor and dynamic circuit topologies.  Transistor sizing for minimizing power consumption, delay and other design criteria.  3 seminars, 1 laboratory.  Crosslisted as CPE/EE 523.

classes.name: Solid State Electronics
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: PHYS 412 or equivalent, and graduate standing or consent of instructor.
classes.desc: Physical theory of solid-state devices.  Properties of metal-semiconductor junctions and p-n junctions.  Derivation of properties of diodes, transistors, and four-layer devices from basic physical and mathematical considerations.  3 seminars.

classes.name: Stochastic Processes
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: STAT 350 or equivalent, and graduate standing or consent of instructor.
classes.desc: Probability and stochastic processes used in random signal analysis.  Response of linear systems to random inputs.  Auto-correlation and power spectral densities.  Applications in signal processing using the discrete Kalman filter.  4 seminars.

classes.name: Advanced Digital Communications
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: EE 314, EE 416, and graduate standing.
classes.desc: Modern digital communication systems.  M-ary signals.  Vector space representation of signals.  Optimum receiver principles.  Common signal sets.  Signal space dimensionality versus time-bandwidth product.  4 seminars.

classes.name: Advanced Topics in Power Electronics
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: EE 410 or equivalent, and graduate standing or consent of instructor.
classes.desc: Selected advanced topics in power electronics such as dc-dc converters, phase-controlled rectifiers, switched-mode inverters, ac and dc drives, HVDC transmission, or utility applications of power electronics.  4 seminars.

classes.name: Digital Image Processing
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: CPE 327 or EE 328; EE 525; and graduate standing.
classes.desc: Processing and interpretation of images by computer.  Emphasis on current applications with real images used in programming assignments.  Topics may include histogram equalization, 2-D convolution, correlation, frequency-domain processing, median filtering, compression, Hough transform, segmentation and region growing, morphological operations, texture description, shape description, Bayes classifier.  4 seminars.

classes.name: Microwave Device Electronics
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: EE 306 or graduate standing.
classes.desc: Emphasis on device theory of operation, fabrication techniques and circuit principles of active microwave solid-state devices, their noise aspects and systems applications.  3 lectures, 1 laboratory.

classes.name: Fourier Optics
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: EE 402 or equivalent, EE 314 or equivalent, and graduate standing or consent of instructor.
classes.desc: Approach to the design and analysis of optical systems using linear communication theory, including Fourier analysis.  Analysis of two-dimensional signals and systems, foundations of scalar diffraction theory.  Fresnel and Fraunhofer diffraction.  Wave-optics analysis of coherent optical systems, frequency analysis of optical imaging systems, holo-graphy.4 seminars.

classes.name: Advanced VLSI Design
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: CPE 441/EE 431.
classes.desc: Advanced Very Large Scale Integrated (VLSI) design using state-of-the-art software.  Advanced topics in digital, analog and mixed signal circuit design to enable a quarter-long design project culminating in a tapeout-ready integrated circuit design.  3 lectures, 1 laboratory.  Crosslisted as CPE 541/EE 531.

classes.name: VLSI Circuit Testing
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: EE 531/CPE 541.
classes.desc: Characterization, testing and documentation of custom-fabricated Very Large Scale Integrated (VLSI) circuits.  Use of specialized test equipment.  1 laboratory.  Crosslisted as CPE/EE 532.

classes.name: Antennas
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: EE 402 or equivalent.
classes.desc: Principles of antenna theory.  Antenna parameters, radiation integrals.  Duality and reciprocity theorems.  Wire antennas.  Antenna arrays.  Traveling wave antennas.  Broadband and frequency independent antennas.  Aperture and reflector antennas.  Microstrip antennas.  Antenna design.  4 seminars.

classes.name: Advanced Photonic Systems
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: EE 335 or graduate standing. Recommended: EE 403 and EE 443.
classes.desc: Design, implementation, and characterization of advanced photonic systems including optical sensors, holography, optical coherence tomography (OCT), and light detection and ranging (LIDAR) systems.  3 lectures, 1 laboratory.

classes.name: Advanced Microwave Laboratory
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: EE 402 or equivalent and graduate standing.
classes.desc: Experimental measurement in waveguide and microstrip circuits employing the advanced Network Analyzer.  Design of both passive and active microwave circuits using microstrip.  Graphical and analytical design techniques as well as the use of computer-aided design codes.  2 laboratories.

classes.name: Advanced Real Time Embedded Systems
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: CPE/EE 442.
classes.desc: Advanced study and application of modern embedded systems.  Memory bandwidth matching, clock-domain crossing, IP creation and verification, and student-led lectures on modern System on Chip (SoC) design topics.  Building a prototype embedded system.  3 lectures, 1 laboratory.  Crosslisted as CPE/EE 542.

classes.name: Solid-state Electronics and VLSI Laboratory
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: Graduate standing; EE 431 or EE 524 (EE 524 may be taken concurrently).
classes.desc: Experimental procedures in solid-state electronics and integrated circuits.  Investigation and improvement of the characteristics of solid-state electronic devices and integrated circuits.  1 laboratory.

classes.name: Graduate Seminar
classes.pre_reqs: CR/NC
classes.desc: Current developments in the fields of electrical and electronic engineering. Participation by students, faculty and guest lecturers. Open to graduate students with a background in electrical or electronic engineering. Credit/No Credit grading only. Total credit limited to 3 units. 1 seminar.

classes.name: Selected Advanced Topics
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: Graduate standing or consent of instructor.
classes.desc: Directed group study of selected topics for advanced students.  Open to graduate students and selected seniors with electrical and electronic engineering background.  The Class Schedule will list topic selected.  Total credit limited to 8 units.  1 to 4 seminars.

classes.name: Selected Advanced Laboratory
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: Graduate standing or consent of instructor.
classes.desc: Directed group laboratory study of selected topics for advanced students.  Open to undergraduate and graduate students.  The Class Schedule will list topic selected.  Total credit limited to 8 units.  1 to 4 laboratories.

classes.name: Cooperative Education Experience
classes.pre_reqs: CR/NCPrerequisite: Graduate standing and consent of instructor.
classes.desc: Advanced study analysis and full-time work experience in student's career field; current innovations, practices, and problems in administration, supervision, and organization of business, industry, and government.
