Discussion of policy and ethical issues in the conduct of research, how to find appropriate resources, and understanding the process of presenting and publishing research.  Intended for entering graduate students.  Credit/No Credit grading only.  1 seminar.

classes.name: Food Product Innovation
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: FSN 408.
classes.desc: Focus on product innovation strategies, project management, product life cycle, project development team management, product innovation metrics, process optimization and cost management.  Plan and execute an industry-relevant specialized project.  3 lectures, 1 laboratory.

classes.name: Population Health and Epidemiology
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: FSN 416 and graduate standing.
classes.desc: Advanced concepts and issues in population health and epidemiology.  Covers epidemiologic methods, study design, and conceptual frameworks from public health perspective.  Analytical considerations related to population health will be presented.  Emphasis on nutrition-related issues at national and global levels.  3 lectures.

classes.name: Biochemical and Molecular Aspects of Human Macronutrient Metabolism
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: FSN 328 or FSN 331; and graduate standing.
classes.desc: Advanced topics in the human metabolism of carbohydrates, lipids and proteins.  Classic and recent findings related to mechanisms of nutrient-regulated gene expression.  Metabolism related to specific diseases will also be covered.  4 lectures.

classes.name: Metabolic and Molecular Aspects of Vitamins
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: FSN 329, or FSN 332 and FSN 333; and graduate standing.
classes.desc: Advanced topics in the molecular roles and functions of vitamins.  Classic and recent findings related to mechanisms of vitamin-regulated gene expression.  Specific aspects of vitamin deficiencies and toxicities will also be covered.  2 lectures.

classes.name: Metabolic and Molecular Aspects of Minerals
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: FSN 329, or FSN 332 and FSN 333; and graduate standing.
classes.desc: Advanced topics in the molecular roles and functions of minerals.  Classic and recent findings related to mechanisms of mineral-regulated gene expression.  Specific aspects of mineral deficiencies and toxicities will also be covered.  2 lectures.

classes.name: Dietetic Internship Seminar
classes.pre_reqs: CR/NCPrerequisite: Acceptance into the Cal Poly, San Luis Obispo Dietetic Internship, a special session program in Extended Education.
classes.desc: A forum for dietetic interns to make presentations and share their experiences in their supervised practice.  Guest presentations on current issues in nutrition therapy, foodservice management and community nutrition.  Total credit limited to 6 units, with a maximum of 2 units per quarter.  Credit/No Credit grading only.  2 seminars.

classes.name: Chemistry of Food Systems
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: FSN 364 or graduate standing.
classes.desc: Integration of food chemistry concepts to develop an in-depth understanding on the role of structural and functional properties of components in food systems.  Research topics for components in specific food systems.  4 lectures.

classes.name: Selected Topics in Food Science and Nutrition
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: Graduate standing or consent of instructor.
classes.desc: Directed group study of selected topics for advanced students.  Open to undergraduate and graduate students.  The Class Schedule will list topic selected.  Total credit limited to 12 units.  1 to 4 seminars.

classes.name: Selected Advanced Laboratory in Food Science and Nutrition
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: Consent of instructor.
classes.desc: Directed group laboratory study of selected topics for advanced students.  Open to undergraduate and graduate students.  The Class Schedule will list topic selected.  Total credit limited to 8 units.  1 to 4 laboratories.

classes.name: Food Process Failure Analysis
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: FSN 335 or graduate standing; FSN 444; and FSN 474.
classes.desc: Analysis of root causes and impacts of failure scenarios within the food industry.  Corrective actions relative to safety, quality, and economics of the affected products will be assessed.  3 lectures, 1 activity.

classes.name: Advanced Food Safety
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: FSN 375 or graduate standing; and MCRO 421.
classes.desc: In-depth analysis of food safety issues including outbreaks, risk assessment, Food Safety Modernization Act (FSMA), product and process assessments.  Special emphasis on the critical evaluation, development and execution of food safety research.  3 lectures, 1 laboratory.

classes.name: Graduate Seminar in Food Science and Nutrition
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: Graduate standing or consent of instructor.
classes.desc: Current findings and research problems in the field and their application to food science and nutrition.  The Class Schedule will list topic selected.  Total credit limited to 6 units with approval of advisor.  1 to 3 seminars.

classes.name: Current Nutrition Research
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: Graduate standing or consent of instructor.
classes.desc: Directed group study and presentation of selected nutrition research topics for graduate and advanced undergraduate students.  Students will select, read, critically analyze and present nutrition research within designated themes.  Total credit limited to 3 units.  1 seminar.

classes.name: Thesis
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: Graduate standing and consent of instructor.
classes.desc: Individual research in food science and nutrition under faculty supervision leading to a graduate thesis of suitable quality.  Total credit limited to 9 units.

classes.name: Elementary French I
classes.desc: Beginning French. Class practice and assigned outside work in pronunciation, sentence structure, reading, writing, and conversation. Language taught in its intercultural context. 3 lectures, 1 activity.

classes.name: Elementary French  II
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: FR 101 or appropriate score on placement exam or consent of instructor.
classes.desc: Class practice and assigned outside work in pronunciation, sentence structure, reading, writing, and conversation.  Language taught in its intercultural context.  To be taken in numerical sequence.  3 lectures, 1 activity.

classes.name: Elementary French III
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: FR 102 or appropriate score on placement exam or consent of instructor.
classes.desc: Class practice and assigned outside work in pronunciation, sentence structure, reading, writing, and conversation.  Language taught in its intercultural context.  To be taken in numerical sequence.  3 lectures, 1 activity.

classes.name: Intermediate French I
classes.pre_reqs: 2019-20 or earlier catalog: GE Area C5Prerequisite: FR 103 or appropriate score on placement exam or consent of instructor.
classes.desc: Development of presentational, interpersonal, and interpretive intermediate-level language skills in French within an intercultural context.  To be taken in numerical sequence.  3 lectures, 1 activity.  Fulfills GE Electives - Area C (GE Area C5 for students on the 2019-20 or earlier catalogs).

classes.name: Intermediate French II
classes.pre_reqs: 2019-20 or earlier catalog: GE Area C5Prerequisite: FR 201 or appropriate score on placement exam or consent of instructor.
classes.desc: Development of presentational, interpersonal, and interpretive intermediate-level language skills in French within an intercultural context.  To be taken in numerical sequence.  3 lectures, 1 activity.  Fulfills GE Electives - Area C (GE Area C5 for students on the 2019-20 or earlier catalogs).

classes.name: Intermediate French III
classes.pre_reqs: 2019-20 or earlier catalog: GE Area C5Prerequisite: FR 202 or appropriate score on placement exam or consent of instructor.
classes.desc: Development of presentational, interpersonal, and interpretive intermediate-level language skills in French within an intercultural context.  To be taken in numerical sequence.  3 lectures, 1 activity.  Fulfills GE Electives - Area C (GE Area C5 for students on the 2019-20 or earlier catalogs).

classes.name: French for Reading Knowledge
classes.pre_reqs: CR/NC
classes.desc: For students aiming primarily to acquire a reading knowledge of French in the minimum amount of time. Covers essential grammar and vocabulary. Useful for students interested in translation, needing to conduct research based on French-language sources, or preparing for the French graduate-level reading knowledge exam. Credit/No Credit grading only. 4 lectures.

classes.name: Critical Reading in French Literature
classes.pre_reqs: 2020-21 or later catalog: GE Area C22019-20 or earlier: GE Area C1 or C2Prerequisite: Completion of GE Area A with grades of C- or better; and FR 203 or consent of instructor.
classes.desc: Selected readings in French from Francophone authors that illustrate the French literary tradition from the Middle Ages to the present in both France and other French-speaking countries.  May include film and other media.  Conducted in French.  4 lectures.  Fulfills GE Area C2 (GE Area C1 or GE Area C2 for students on the 2019-20 or earlier catalogs).

classes.name: Selected Topics
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: Consent of instructor.
classes.desc: Directed group study of selected topics.  Open only to undergraduate students.  Conducted in French.  The Schedule of Classes will list topic selected.  Total credit limited to 8 units.  1 to 4 lectures.

classes.name: Advanced French Composition and Grammar
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: FR 203 or consent of instructor.
classes.desc: Written and oral development of structural grammar, syntax and complex components of French.  Expansion of vocabulary and idiomatic expressions through text study.  Written compositions.  May include French/English translation.  Conducted in French.  4 lectures.

classes.name: Advanced French Conversation and Grammar
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: FR 203 or consent of instructor.
classes.desc: Oral and written development of structural grammar, syntax and complex components of French.  Expansion of vocabulary and idiomatic expressions through topics focusing on culture.  Individual and/or group presentations.  Conducted in French.  4 lectures.

classes.name: Significant Works in French
classes.pre_reqs: 2020-21 or later: Upper-Div GE Area C2019-20 or earlier catalog: GE Area C4Prerequisite: Junior standing; completion of GE Area A with grades of C- or better; one course in GE Area B4 with a grade of C- or better (GE Area B1 for students on the 2019-20 or earlier catalogs); and FR 233 or consent of instructor.
classes.desc: Critical analysis and oral discussion of poetry, essays, novels, plays, films, and other media by selected French and Francophone authors.  Conducted in French.  The Class Schedule will list topic selected.  Total credit limited to 12 units.  4 lectures.   Fulfills GE Upper-Division C (GE Area C4 for students on the 2019-20 or earlier catalogs).

classes.name: French Literature in English Translation
classes.pre_reqs: 2020-21 or later: Upper-Div GE Area C2019-20 or earlier catalog: GE Area C4Prerequisite: Junior standing; completion of GE Area A with grades of C- or better; one course in GE Area B4 with a grade of C- or better (GE Area B1 for students on the 2019-20 or earlier catalogs); and completion of GE Area C2 (GE Area C1 for students on the 2019-20 or earlier catalogs).
classes.desc: Selected works to be read by students in English translation.  Critical analysis, interpretation, and comparison of works by French and/or Francophone authors.  Course may include film and other media.  Discussion in English.  The Class Schedule will list topic selected.  Total credit limited to 8 units.  4 lectures.  Fulfills GE Upper-Division C (GE Area C4 for students on the 2019-20 or earlier catalogs).

classes.name: Selected Advanced Topics
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: Consent of instructor.
classes.desc: Directed group study of selected topics for advanced students.  Open to undergraduate and graduate students.  Conducted in French.  The Class Schedule will list topic selected.  Total credit limited to 8 units.  1 to 4 lectures.

classes.name: Human Geography
classes.pre_reqs: 2020-21 or later catalog: GE Area D22019-20 or earlier: GE Area D2 or D3
classes.desc: The interplay of cultures, places, and environments, with emphasis on diversity and globalization. Topics include characteristics and patterns of human population, migration, ethnicity, agriculture, geopolitics, language, religion, urbanization, industry, and international development. 4 lectures. Fulfills GE Area D2 (GE Area D2 or GE Area D3 for students on the 2019-20 or earlier catalogs).

classes.name: Special Problems for Undergraduates
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: Consent of department head.
classes.desc: Individual investigation, research, studies, or surveys of selected problems.  Total credit limited to 8 units, with a maximum of 4 units per quarter.

classes.name: Applications in GIS
classes.desc: Introduction to Geographic Information System (GIS) computer software to explore environmental, natural resource, social and economic issues using spatial data. Principles of cartography and map interpretation. Development of data base and software management competencies. 2 lectures, 2 laboratories. Replaces GEOG 318.

classes.name: Physical Geography
classes.desc: Addresses the origins and patterns of the earth's diverse assemblage of climates, landforms, biota and soils. A major focus on relationship between human cultures and these earthly environments. 4 lectures. Crosslisted as ERSC/GEOG 250.

classes.name: Selected Topics
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: Open to undergraduate students and consent of instructor.
classes.desc: Directed group study of selected topics.  The Class Schedule will list topic selected.  Total credit limited to 8 units.  1 to 4 lectures.

classes.name: Global Geography
classes.pre_reqs: 2020-21 or later: Upper-Div GE Area D2019-20 or earlier catalog: GE Area D5Prerequisite: Junior standing; completion of GE Area A with grades of C- or better; one course in GE Area B4 with a grade of C- or better (GE Area B1 for students on the 2019-20 or earlier catalogs); and completion of GE Area D1.
classes.desc: Examination of the major world regions such as Europe, the Middle East, Africa, Asia and Latin America.  Focus on the origins and content of contemporary cultural landscapes and on their utility for understanding international differences, interactions, and current events.  Particular attention to the relationship between humans and the environment.  4 lectures.  Fulfills GE Upper-Division D (GE Area D5 for students on the 2019-20 or earlier catalogs).

classes.name: Climate and Humanity
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: Junior standing.
classes.desc: Geographic perspective on the interrelationships between climate and human cultures.  Effects of people on climate and the influence of climate and weather upon human activities and behavior.  Focus on global human conditions which are responsible for the alteration of climate and in turn are vulnerable to climate change.  4 lectures.  Crosslisted as ERSC/GEOG 325.

classes.name: Applications in Remote Sensing and GIS
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: GEOG 218 or NR 218.
classes.desc: Introduction to the use of satellite imagery to analyze natural and human features on the earth.  Applications in geology, water, climate, vegetation, agriculture, and urban land use.  Fundamentals of processing digital satellite images.  Emphasis on bridging the earth and social sciences.  3 lectures, 1 laboratory.

classes.name: Human Impact on the Earth
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: Junior standing.
classes.desc: Global assessment of the impact of humans on the earth's vegetation, animals, soil, water and atmosphere.  Emphasis on problems stemming from the interactions of human attitudes, technologies, and population with natural resources.  4 lectures.  Crosslisted as ERSC/GEOG 333.

classes.name: Geography of California
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: Junior standing.
classes.desc: Analysis of the land and people of California from a geographical perspective.  Patterns of environment, history, settlement, water, agriculture, ethnicity, economy, politics, and urban growth.  Current issues are examined in a national and global context.  4 lectures.

classes.name: The Global Environment
classes.pre_reqs: 2020-21 or later: Upper-Div GE Area B2019-20 or earlier catalog: GE Area B5, B6, or B7Prerequisite: Junior standing; completion of GE Area A with grades of C- or better; and completion of GE Areas B1 through B4, with a grade of C- or better in one course in GE Area B4 (GE Area B1 for students on the 2019-20 or earlier catalogs).
classes.desc: Interdisciplinary investigation of how human activities impact the Earth's environment on a global scale.  Examination of population, resource use, climate change, and biodiversity from scientific/technical and social/economic/ historical/political perspectives.  Use of remote sensing maps.  Sustainable solutions.  4 lectures.  Crosslisted as AG/EDES/ENGR/GEOG/ISLA/SCM/UNIV 350.  Fulfills GE Area Upper-Division B (GE Areas B5, B6, or B7 for students on the 2019-20 catalog).

classes.name: Geography of Latin America
classes.pre_reqs: 2020-21 or later: Upper-Div GE Area D2019-20 or earlier catalog: GE Area D5Prerequisite: Junior standing; completion of GE Area A with grades of C- or better; one course in GE Area B4 with a grade of C- or better (GE Area B1 for students on the 2019-20 or earlier catalogs); and one course in GE Area D2 (or in GE Area D3 for students on the 2019-20 or earlier catalogs).
classes.desc: Geographic analysis of the lands and peoples of Mexico, Central America, the Caribbean, and South America.  Patterns of environment, culture, politics, economy, and development.  Issues (local, regional, and global) shaping Latin America today, with emphasis on U.S.-Latin America relations.  4 lectures.  Fulfills GE Upper-Division D (GE Area D5 for students on the 2019-20 or earlier catalogs).

classes.name: Geography of the Caribbean
classes.pre_reqs: 2020-21 or later: Upper-Div GE Area D2019-20 or earlier catalog: GE Area D5Prerequisite: Junior standing; completion of GE Area A with grades of C- or better; one course in GE Area B4 with a grade of C- or better (GE Area B1 for students on the 2019-20 or earlier catalogs); and two lower-division courses in GE Area D.
classes.desc: Geographic analysis of the Caribbean including the Greater Antilles, Lesser Antilles, and the Caribbean coasts of Central and South America.  Investigates patterns and relationships between the physical and cultural geographies from local, regional, and global perspectives.  4 lectures.  Fulfills GE Upper-Division D (GE Area D5 for students on the 2019-20 or earlier catalogs).

classes.name: Professional Preparation for Anthropologists/Geographers
classes.pre_reqs: CR/NCPrerequisite: Sophomore standing; ANT 201 or GEOG 150.
classes.desc: Preparation for professional advancement in the fields of anthropology and geography.  Supervised career planning emphasizing resume development, selection of an internship or international experience, exploration of career options and graduate programs.  Lectures from outside, practicing professionals.  Credit/No Credit grading only.  1 seminar.  Formerly GEOG 464.

classes.name: Special Problems for Advanced Undergraduates
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: Consent of department head.
classes.desc: Individual investigation, research, studies, or surveys of selected problems.  Total credit limited to 8 units, with a maximum of 4 units per quarter.

classes.name: Geography of International Development
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: GEOG 308.
classes.desc: Detailed analysis of international development from a geographical perspective.  Survey of various theories of development and their cultural and ecological components at multiple geographic scales, including institutions and actors involved.  Applicable skills for development research and practice, emphasizing sustainability.  4 lectures.

classes.name: Global and Regional Climatology
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: Junior standing.
classes.desc: The earth's pattern of climates and the physical processes that account for them.  Focus on interrelationships between climate and the physical/biological and cultural environments.  Special emphasis on modern climate changes and their consequences.  3 lectures, 1 laboratory.  Crosslisted as ERSC/GEOG 414.

classes.name: Applied Meteorology and Climatology
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: ERSC/GEOG 250.
classes.desc: Physical processes in the atmosphere that determine regional weather, climate and climate variability.  Surface and satellite systems for weather observation, and weather/climate modeling.  Dynamics of weather systems, including thunderstorms and hurricanes.  Emphases on weather/climate affecting agriculture and other human activities.  3 lectures, 1 activity.  Crosslisted as ERSC/GEOG 415.

classes.name: Biodiversity and Biogeography Methods
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: ERSC/GEOG 250.
classes.desc: Origins and spatial patterns of the earth's flora and fauna across gradients of climate, landforms, geology and time.  Will focus on the history of biogeography and new applications of geospatial technology such as GIS and remote sensing.  3 lectures, 1 laboratory.

classes.name: Advanced Applications in Geospatial Technologies
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: GEOG 218 or LA/NR 218. Recommended: BRAE 345 or GEOG 328.
classes.desc: Advanced applications in Geographic Information Systems (GIS), Remote Sensing, and other geospatial technologies.  Emphasizing research, methodologies, and career fields in geography, earth sciences, and the social sciences.  The Class Schedule will list topic selected.  Total credit limited to 12 units.  2 lectures, 2 laboratories.

classes.name: Anthropology-Geography Research Design and Methods
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: Completion of GE Area B2; and two upper-division ANT or GEOG courses.
classes.desc: Development of knowledge and skills needed to conduct original scientific anthropology-geography research and prepares students for senior projects.  Various empirical methodologies highlighted, with a focus on quantitative design and measurement of human culture, biology, behavior, environment and ecology.  Course may be offered in classroom-based, online, or hybrid.  3 lectures, 1 laboratory.  Crosslisted as ANT/GEOG 455.

classes.name: Senior Project I
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: Senior standing.
classes.desc: Selection and completion of a project under faculty supervision.  Projects typical of problems which graduates must solve in their fields of employment.  Project results are presented in a formal report.  Minimum 120 hours total time.

classes.name: Senior Project II
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: Senior standing.
classes.desc: Selection and completion of a project under faculty supervision.  Projects typical of problems which graduates must solve in their fields of employment.  Project results are presented in a formal report.  Minimum 120 hours total time.

classes.name: Internship
classes.pre_reqs: CR/NCPrerequisite: GEOG 464, senior standing and/or consent of instructor.
classes.desc: Supervised training, research, and work in public and private organizations.  Credit/No Credit grading only.  Total credit limited to 18 units.

classes.name: Selected Advanced Topics
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: Consent of instructor.
classes.desc: Directed group study of selected topics for advanced students.  Open to undergraduate and graduate students.  The Class Schedule will list topic selected.  Total credit limited to 12 units.  1 to 4 lectures.

classes.name: Introduction to Geology
classes.pre_reqs: 2020-21 or later catalog: GE Area B12019-20 or earlier catalog: GE Area B3
classes.desc: Processes responsible for the Earth's minerals, rocks, structure, and surface features. Volcanism; mountain building; plate tectonics; weathering. Erosion and deposition by streams, glaciers, wind and waves. Geological resources, earth hazards, and interaction of humanity with global processes. 3 lectures, 1 discussion. Fulfills GE Area B1 (GE Area B3 for students on the 2019-20 or earlier catalogs).

classes.name: Special Problems for Undergraduates
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: Consent of department chair.
classes.desc: Individual investigation, research, studies, or surveys of selected problems.  Total credit limited to 4 units, with a maximum of 2 units per quarter.

classes.name: Physical Geology
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: MATH 119.
classes.desc: Processes responsible for the Earth's rocks, structural surface features, geologic hazards, and natural resources, with emphasis on interactions with human activities.  3 lectures.

classes.name: The Geologic Record: Fossils and the History of Life
classes.pre_reqs: 2020-21 or later catalog: GE Area B12019-20 or earlier catalog: GE Area B5
classes.desc: A historical account of life on Earth interpreted from the fossil record. Paleoenvironmental controls on the rise and decline of lineages of organisms deduced from stratigraphy, and from the composition, character, and geochemistry of sedimentary rocks. Identification of fossils. 3 lectures, 1 discussion. Fulfills GE Area B1 (GE Area B5 for students on the 2019-20 or earlier catalogs).

classes.name: Geologic Excursions
classes.pre_reqs: CR/NC
classes.desc: Field trips to places of geologic interest. The Class Schedule will indicate destinations. Students must provide their own transportation, food, and camping equipment. May be repeated for a maximum of 3 units provided field trips are taken to different locations. Credit/No Credit grading only. 1 laboratory.

classes.name: Physical Geology Laboratory
classes.pre_reqs: Corequisite: GEOL 102 or GEOL 201.
classes.desc: Properties and identification of minerals and rocks.  Topographic maps and landform analysis.  Geologic maps and interpretation of rock structure.  1 laboratory.

classes.name: Selected Topics
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: Consent of instructor.
classes.desc: Directed group study of selected topics.  The Class Schedule will list topic selected.  Total credit limited to 8 units.  1 to 4 lectures.

classes.name: Physical Models in the Geosciences
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: MATH 142; PHYS 141; and GEOL 201.
classes.desc: Development and analysis of geodynamical models.  Stress and strain, flexure, heat flow, faulting, and elastic waves in the solid earth.  Additional topics may include fluid flow, flow of natural materials, geochronology, and equations of state in high pressure mineral physics.  4 lectures.

classes.name: Computation and Visualization in the Geosciences
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: GEOL 301 and one of the following: STAT 217, STAT 218, STAT 301, STAT 312, or STAT 321.
classes.desc: Introduction to scientific programming and data visualization for solving problems in the geosciences.  Import and export of data, plotting data and maps, time series analysis, statistical description of data, and numerical approximations of equations.  2 lectures, 1 laboratory.

classes.name: Seismology and Earth Structure
classes.pre_reqs: 2020-21 or later: Upper-Div GE Area B2019-20 or earlier catalog: GE Area B5, B6, or B7Prerequisite: Junior standing; completion of GE Area A with grades of C- or better; one course in GE Area B4 with a grade of C- or better (GE Area B1 for students on the 2019-20 or earlier catalogs); GEOL 303; or PHYS 132 and MATH 242 or MATH 244.
classes.desc: Elastic waves in layered media.  Principle of the seismometer.  Magnitude, seismic moment and energy calculations.  Source mechanics.  Major California faults and paleoseismology.  Theory of plate tectonics.  Seismic properties, structure, and composition of the Earth.  Field trip required.  3 lectures, 1 laboratory.  Fulfills GE Area Upper-Division B (GE Areas B5, B6, or B7 for students on the 2019-20 catalog).

classes.name: Igneous Petrology
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: GEOL 102 or GEOL 201; and ERSC 223.
classes.desc: Processes associated with melt generation and igneous crystallization with special attention to relationships with tectonic setting.  Field trip required.  Not open to students with credit in GEOL 310.  2 lectures, 1 laboratory.

classes.name: Metamorphic Petrology
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: GEOL 309.
classes.desc: Textures and minerals associated with the metamorphism of igneous and sedimentary rocks.  Principles of metamorphic reactions and thermobarometry.  Special attention to metamorphic processes in the context of plate tectonics.  Field trip required.  Not open to students with credit in GEOL 310.  2 lectures, 1 laboratory.

classes.name: Principles of Stratigraphy
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: GEOL 102 or GEOL 201, and GEOL 241.
classes.desc: Description and analysis of stratified rock and sediment.  Sedimentology, diagenesis, transgressive/regressive sequences, bedform interpretation, marine and terrestrial sediment and sedimentary-rock sequence interpretation, and sequence stratigraphy.  Required field trips.  3 lectures, 1 laboratory.

classes.name: Special Problems for Advanced Undergraduates
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: Consent of department chair.
classes.desc: Individual investigations, research, studies, or surveys of selected problems.  Total credit limited to 4 units, with a maximum of 2 units per quarter.

classes.name: Field-Geology Methods
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: GEOL 102 or GEOL 201, GEOL 241, GEOL 415, ERSC 223, ERSC 323.
classes.desc: Collecting and interpreting field-geologic data.  Description of sedimentary rocks and construction of stratigraphic columns.  Mapping geologic structures in the field.  Surficial geologic stratigraphy and surficial geologic mapping.  Understanding geologic processes through field study.  Communicating results of field study.  1 lecture, 3 activities.  Crosslisted as ERSC/GEOL 401.

classes.name: Geologic Mapping
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: ERSC/GEOL 401.
classes.desc: Bedrock geologic mapping on topographic maps and aerial photos.  Surficial geologic mapping on topographic maps and aerial photos.  Correlating and defining surficial geologic map units on the basis of soil development.  Understanding landscape evolution using soil development 4 activities.  Crosslisted as ERSC/GEOL 402.

classes.name: Research Experience for Advanced Undergraduates
classes.pre_reqs: CR/NCPrerequisite: Consent of department chair.
classes.desc: Individual investigations, research, studies, or surveys of selected problems.  Credit/No Credit grading only.  Total credit limited to 4 units, with a maximum of 2 units per quarter.

classes.name: Structural Geology
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: GEOL 241 and ERSC 223.
classes.desc: Recognition, interpretation, and depiction of geological structures.  Understanding rock deformation through the study of faults and folds.  3 lectures, 1 laboratory.  Required weekend field trips.

classes.name: Applied Geophysics
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: GEOL 201 and PHYS 141.
classes.desc: Introduction to geophysical exploration of the shallow subsurface:  seismic refraction, seismic reflection, electrical resistivity, magnetic and gravity methods.  Application to determination of subsurface structure, groundwater and mineral resources.  Field trip required.  2 lectures, 1 laboratory.

classes.name: Selected Advanced Topics
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: Consent of instructor.
classes.desc: Directed group study of selected topics for advanced students.  Open to undergraduate and graduate students.  The Class Schedule will list topic selected.  Total credit limited to 8 units.  1 to 4 lectures.

classes.name: Selected Advanced Laboratory
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: Consent of instructor.
classes.desc: Directed group laboratory study of selected topics for advanced students.  Open to undergraduate and graduate students.  The Class Schedule will list topic selected.  Total credit limited to 8 units.  1 to 4 laboratories.

classes.name: Elementary German I
classes.desc: Beginning German. Class practice and assigned outside work in pronunciation, sentence structure, reading, writing and conversation. Language taught in its intercultural context. 3 lectures, 1 activity.

classes.name: Elementary German II
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: GER 101 or appropriate score on placement exam or consent of instructor.
classes.desc: Class practice and assigned outside work in pronunciation, sentence structure, reading, writing and conversation.  Language taught in its intercultural context.  To be taken in numerical sequence.  3 lectures, 1 activity.

classes.name: Elementary German III
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: GER 102 or appropriate score on placement exam or consent of instructor.
classes.desc: Class practice and assigned outside work in pronunciation, sentence structure, reading, writing and conversation.  Language taught in its intercultural context.  To be taken in numerical sequence.  3 lectures, 1 activity.

classes.name: Intermediate German I
classes.pre_reqs: 2019-20 or earlier catalog: GE Area C5Prerequisite: GER 103 or appropriate score on placement exam or consent of instructor.
classes.desc: Development of presentational, interpersonal, and interpretive intermediate-level language skills in German within an intercultural context.  To be taken in numerical sequence.  3 lectures, 1 activity.  Fulfills GE Electives - Area C (GE Area C5 for students on the 2019-20 or earlier catalogs).

classes.name: Intermediate German II
classes.pre_reqs: 2019-20 or earlier catalog: GE Area C5Prerequisite: GER 201 or appropriate score on placement exam or consent of instructor.
classes.desc: Development of presentational, interpersonal, and interpretive intermediate-level language skills in German within an intercultural context.  To be taken in numerical sequence.  3 lectures, 1 activity.  Fulfills GE Electives - Area C (GE Area C5 for students on the 2019-20 or earlier catalogs).

classes.name: Intermediate German III
classes.pre_reqs: 2019-20 or earlier catalog: GE Area C5Prerequisite: GER 202 or appropriate score on placement exam or consent of instructor.
classes.desc: Development of presentational, interpersonal, and interpretive intermediate-level language skills in German within an intercultural context.  To be taken in numerical sequence.  3 lectures, 1 activity.  Fulfills GE Electives - Area C (GE Area C5 for students on the 2019-20 or earlier catalogs).

classes.name: Critical Reading in German Literature
classes.pre_reqs: 2020-21 or later catalog: GE Area C22019-20 or earlier: GE Area C1 or C2Prerequisite: Completion of GE Area A with grades of C- or better; and GER 203 or consent of instructor.
classes.desc: Selected readings from German-language authors that show the literary tradition from the Middle Ages to the present.  May include film and other media.  Conducted in German.  4 lectures.  Fulfills GE Area C2 (GE Area C1 or GE Area C2 for students on the 2019-20 or earlier catalogs).

classes.name: Selected Topics
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: Consent of instructor.
classes.desc: Directed group study of selected topics.  Open only to undergraduate students.  Conducted in German.  The Class Schedule will list topic selected.  Total credit limited to 8 units.  1 to 4 lectures.

classes.name: Advanced German Composition and Grammar
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: GER 203 or consent of instructor.
classes.desc: Written and oral development of structural grammar, syntax and complex components of German.  Vocabulary expansion and idiomatic construction.  Written compositions.  May include German/English translation.  Conducted in German.  4 lectures.

classes.name: Advanced German Conversation and Grammar
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: GER 203 or consent of instructor.
classes.desc: Oral and written development of structural grammar, syntax and complex components of German.  Expansion of vocabulary and idiomatic expressions through topics focusing on culture.  Individual and/or group presentations.  Conducted in German.  4 lectures.

classes.name: Significant Works in German
classes.pre_reqs: 2020-21 or later: Upper-Div GE Area C2019-20 or earlier catalog: GE Area C4Prerequisite: Junior standing; completion of GE Area A with grades of C- or better; one course in GE Area B4 with a grade of C- or better (GE Area B1 for students on the 2019-20 or earlier catalogs); and GER 233 or consent of instructor.
classes.desc: Critical analysis and oral discussion of poetry, essays, novels, plays, films, and other media by selected German-language authors.  Conducted in German.  The Class Schedule will list topic selected.  Total credit limited to 12 units.  4 lectures.  Fulfills GE Upper-Division C (GE Area C4 for students on the 2019-20 or earlier catalogs).

classes.name: German Literature in English Translation
classes.pre_reqs: 2020-21 or later: Upper-Div GE Area C2019-20 or earlier catalog: GE Area C4Prerequisite: Junior standing; completion of GE Area A with grades of C- or better; one course in GE Area B4 with a grade of C- or better (GE Area B1 for students on the 2019-20 or earlier catalogs); and completion of GE Area C2 (GE Area C1 for students on the 2019-20 or earlier catalogs).
classes.desc: Selected works to be read by students in English translation.  Critical analysis, interpretation, and comparison of works by German-language authors.  Course may include film and other media.  Discussion in English.  The Class Schedule will list topic selected.  Total credit limited to 8 units.  4 lectures.  Fulfills GE Upper-Division C (GE Area C4 for students on the 2019-20 or earlier catalogs).

classes.name: Selected Advanced Topics
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: Consent of instructor.
classes.desc: Directed group study of selected topics for advanced students.  Open to undergraduate and graduate students.  Conducted in German.  The Class Schedule will list topic selected.  Total credit limited to 8 units.  4 lectures.

classes.name: Continued Graduate Study
classes.pre_reqs: CR/NCPrerequisite: Must be in good standing in a graduate program at Cal Poly.
classes.desc: Activities other than regular coursework that are needed to complete the requirements for the degree.  Analysis of data, thesis and project report writing, oral defense of the thesis/project, preparation for the comprehensive exam, and other activities related to the culminating experience for the student's program.  Can be used to fulfill the continuous enrollment requirement for graduate students.  Units earned in this course may not be used toward degree completion.  Credit/No Credit grading only.  Total credit limited to 15 units; repeatable in same term.

classes.name: Graduate Accounting Individual Research
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: OCOB graduate standing in Accounting and formal petition with approval from the Associate Dean.
classes.desc: Advanced individual research in accounting topics planned and completed under the direction of a member of the college faculty.  Designed to meet the needs of qualified students who wish to pursue investigations in accounting which cannot be followed effectively in regularly offered elective courses.  A formal written proposal must be accepted by the Associate Dean of OCOB before work begins.

classes.name: Taxation of Trusts, Estates, and Transfer Taxes
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: OCOB graduate standing or approval from the Associate Dean.
classes.desc: Income taxation of trusts and estates as flow-through entities; transfer taxation of gifts and estates, including generation-skipping transfers.  4 lectures.

classes.name: State and Local Taxation
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: OCOB graduate standing or approval from the Associate Dean.
classes.desc: Multi-state income and franchise taxation; property taxes; sales and use taxes; and the constitutional authority for the imposition of state taxes.  4 lectures.

classes.name: Current Developments in Taxation
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: OCOB graduate standing or approval from the Associate Dean.
classes.desc: Current developments in income taxation of individuals, trusts and estates and business entities; transfer taxation of gifts and estates; and ethics and professional responsibility in taxation.  4 lectures.

classes.name: Clinical Tax Education Internship
classes.pre_reqs: CR/NCPrerequisite: OCOB graduate standing in Specialization in Tax, MS Accounting program.
classes.desc: Accounting internship that allows graduate level accounting students the opportunity to apply skills and competencies to an employment opportunity.  Placement in a full-time supervised work experience at a public accounting firm or in an accounting or internal audit department of a private enterprise or government agency.  Credit/No Credit grading only.

classes.name: Taxation of Corporations and Partnerships
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: OCOB graduate standing or approval from the Associate Dean.
classes.desc: Comparative study of the taxation of C corporations and flow-through tax entities, including S corporations, partnerships and limited liability companies.  Not open to students with credit in BUS 417.  4 lectures.

classes.name: Advanced Financial Reporting Issues I
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: OCOB graduate standing or approval from the Associate Dean.
classes.desc: Comprehensive coverage of selected advanced financial accounting and reporting topics.  Topics include accounting changes and errors, leases, pensions and other post-employment benefits, income taxes, and consolidated financial statements.  4 seminars.

classes.name: Advanced Financial Reporting Issues II
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: GSA 541 and OCOB graduate standing or approval from the Associate Dean.
classes.desc: Comprehensive coverage of selected advanced financial accounting and reporting topics.  Topics include financial statement footnote and MD&A disclosures and coverage of SEC statutes, regulations and filing forms.  5 seminars.

classes.name: Advanced Enterprise Wide Business Processes for Accounting
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: OCOB graduate standing or approval from the Associate Dean.
classes.desc: Study of various transactions in order to understand the underlying business processes and information flows between various business units, in order for a transaction to occur and be properly reported, and the information determined that is critical for the information system to capture.  Emphasis of role of information systems in controlling the authorization of transactions, access to information, access to assets, preparation of accounting records and reports.  4 seminars.

classes.name: Applied Accounting Research and Communications
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: OCOB graduate standing or approval from the Associate Dean.
classes.desc: Advanced use of authoritative accounting and auditing data bases and actual filings by public companies.  Frequent writing and speaking exercises.  Real world accounting and auditing issues facing public and private enterprises.  In-depth coverage of federal and state regulation of securities transactions.  4 lectures.

classes.name: Tax Research and Administrative Procedures
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: OCOB graduate standing or approval from the Associate Dean.
classes.desc: Research techniques applicable to tax issues including the communication of research results.  Administrative procedures necessary for tax compliance with the various tax jurisdictions with primary emphasis on IRS practices.  4 seminars.

classes.name: Advanced Individual Taxation and Tax Planning
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: OCOB graduate standing or approval from the Associate Dean.
classes.desc: Advanced concepts concerning the impact of taxes on individuals.  Introduction to transfer taxes imposed on individuals.  Financial, estate and compensation tax planning issues.  4 seminars.

classes.name: Advanced Taxation of Flow-Through Entities
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: OCOB graduate standing or approval from the Associate Dean.
classes.desc: Advanced and special topics related to the income tax treatment of partnerships, limited liability companies, trusts and S corporations and their owners and beneficiaries.  Creation, operation, liquidation and sale of such organizations.  4 seminars.

classes.name: Advanced Corporate Taxation
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: OCOB graduate standing or approval from the Associate Dean.
classes.desc: Advanced and special topics related to the income tax treatment of regular corporations and their shareholders.  Mergers and acquisitions, tax accounting methods and periods, cross-boundary topics, and current issues.  4 seminars.

classes.name: International Taxation
classes.pre_reqs: Corequisite: BUS 417, or BUS 414 and BUS 415, and OCOB graduate standing or approval from the Associate Dean.
classes.desc: Fundamental tax concepts of inbound and outbound investments of U.S.  taxpayers, controlled foreign corporations, Subpart F, the foreign tax credit, transfer pricing and contracting country treaties.  4 lectures.

classes.name: Fraud Auditing and Examination
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: OCOB graduate standing or approval from the Associate Dean.
classes.desc: Occupational and financial statement fraud; particular emphasis on the breakdown of corporate governance and ethics systems and developing internal control systems to prevent and detect fraudulent activities.  4 lectures.

classes.name: International Accounting
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: OCOB graduate standing or approval from the Associate Dean.
classes.desc: International accounting, auditing, and corporate governance standards including international financial reporting standards (IFRS).  4 lectures.

classes.name: Advanced Spreadsheet Modeling for Accounting
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: OCOB graduate standing or approval from the Associate Dean.
classes.desc: Advanced topics in electronic spreadsheets and their use in accounting and financial applications.  Developing spreadsheet models for data analysis and decision making.  Integrating automation tools and external data sources into spreadsheets.  Course may be offered in classroom-based or online format.  4 lectures.

classes.name: Database Modeling and Analysis for Accounting
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: OCOB graduate standing or approval from the Associate Dean.
classes.desc: Fundamental concepts in database analysis, design, implementation, administration, and audit including issues such as requirements specification, REA modeling, ER modeling, normalization, SQL, transaction control, database security, and query optimization.  May also include topics such as data warehouses, XBRL and ebXLM.  Course may be offered in classroom-based or online format.  4 lectures.

classes.name: Financial Accounting and Valuation
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: OCOB graduate standing or approval from the Associate Dean.
classes.desc: Comprehensive coverage of approaches to the measurement of fair values that are used in accounting situations such as mergers and acquisitions, recognition of stock based compensation, and determination of impairments in the carrying amounts of long-lived assets including intangible assets and goodwill.  Role of financial reporting in the valuation of securities, credit analysis, and the determination of the cost of capital.  4 lectures.

classes.name: Selected Advanced Topics for Accounting
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: OCOB graduate standing or approval from the Associate Dean.
classes.desc: Directed group study of selected topics for graduate students.  Open to undergraduate and graduate students.  The Class Schedule will list topic selected.  Total credit limited to 8 units.  1 to 4 lectures.

classes.name: Independent Study
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: OCOB graduate standing and formal petition with approval from the Associate Dean.
classes.desc: Advanced study planned and completed under the direction of the Director of Graduate Programs.  Open only to graduate students who have demonstrated ability to do independent work.  A formal written proposal must be accepted by the Associate Dean of OCOB Graduate Programs before work begins.

classes.name: Individual Research
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: OCOB graduate standing and formal petition with approval from the Associate Dean.
classes.desc: Advanced individual research planned and completed under the direction of a member of the college faculty.  Designed to meet the needs of qualified students who wish to pursue investigations which cannot be followed effectively in regularly offered elective courses.  A formal written proposal must be accepted by the Associate Dean of OCOB Graduate Programs before work begins.

classes.name: Collaborative Industry Project
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: OCOB graduate standing and formal petition with approval from the Associate Dean.
classes.desc: Collaborative business project with a client organization that allows graduate level students the opportunity to apply knowledge, skills and competencies to address a business problem.  Small teams work in collaboration with a client organization and a faculty advisor.  A formal written proposal must be accepted by the Associate Dean of OCOB Graduate Programs before work begins.  The project may last up to one year.  Course may be offered in classroom-based or online format.

classes.name: Data Visualization and Communication in Business
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: OCOB graduate standing or approval from the Associate Dean.
classes.desc: Principles of data visualization and storytelling.  Data visualization tools for different types of data in the context of business analytics.  Communication of results for business actionable insights.  Software use includes Excel, Tableau and R.  Course may be offered in classroom-based, online, or hybrid format.  4 lectures.

classes.name: Accounting for Managers
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: OCOB graduate standing or approval from the Associate Dean.
classes.desc: Emphasis on development of the ability to read and interpret public and internal financial reports.  Public reporting responsibilities of companies and management's responsibilities for developing and maintaining effective internal control systems.  4 lectures.

classes.name: Quantitative Analysis
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: OCOB graduate standing or approval from the Associate Dean.
classes.desc: Focus on a variety of statistical techniques that help to transform data into useful information that can be used to make informed business predictions and decisions.  Course may be offered in classroom-based, online, or hybrid format.  4 seminars.

classes.name: Organizational Behavior
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: OCOB graduate standing or approval from the Associate Dean.
classes.desc: Application of behavioral, social and organizational science concepts to management.  Individual, team and organizational levels of analysis, including such topics as expectations, perception, motivation, communications, creativity, leadership, cultural and ethical behavior, group dynamics, team effectiveness, work design, organization change and development.  4 seminars.

classes.name: The Legal and Regulatory Environment of Business
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: OCOB graduate standing or approval from the Associate Dean.
classes.desc: Legal and regulatory environment in which business operates.  Consideration of historical, societal, and global perspectives reflecting political, social and/or economic beliefs and values.  Strong emphasis on fundamental concepts of law and analytical tools to understand interaction between law, ethics and management decisions.  4 seminars.

classes.name: Strategic Marketing Analytics
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: GSB 512 or GSE 518 or IME 503.
classes.desc: Analysis of customer information, using a broad range of tools and techniques including predictive, statistical, and optimization models.  Integration of data into reporting platforms.  Application of findings to marketing decision-making.  Course may be offered in classroom-based or online format.  4 lectures.

classes.name: Strategic People Analytics
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: GSE 519; and OCOB graduate standing or approval from the Associate Dean.
classes.desc: Application of business analytics approaches and techniques to understanding and managing human resources.  Emphasizes problems addressed using people analytics, including which methods are best and under what conditions, data quality and validity issues, and interpretation in the HR context.  Course may be offered in classroom-based, online, or hybrid format.  4 lectures.

classes.name: Essential Statistics for Business Analytics
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: OCOB graduate standing or approval from the instructor.
classes.desc: Statistics background needed for analysis of business data and econometrics.  Topics include basics of probability theory, random variables, distribution functions, conditional distributions, independence, expectations, covariance, correlation, random samples, estimation, asymptotic theory, hypothesis testing, and confidence intervals.  Couse may be offered in classroom-based, online, or hybrid format.  4 lectures.

classes.name: Data Management for Business Analytics
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: OCOB graduate standing or approval from the Associate Dean.
classes.desc: Exploration of data management including relational databases, data warehouses, and NOSQL databases.  Foundation for analyzing, designing, implementing and using information repositories in a business environment.  Topics include the database development life cycle, data modeling, SQL programming, data quality and integration.  Course may be offered in classroom-based or online format.  4 lectures.

classes.name: Cloud Services & Applications for Business Analytics
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: OCOB graduate standing or approval from the Associate Dean. Recommended: GSB 520.
classes.desc: Apply cloud resources for business analytics.  Identify business benefits of cloud computing, storage, networking, data management and security.  Use web services to analyze big data including query, statistical analysis, machine learning and visualization.  Course may be offered in classroom-based, online, or hybrid format.  4 lectures.

classes.name: Advanced Management Information Systems
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: OCOB graduate standing or approval from the Associate Dean.
classes.desc: Analysis of the challenges, successes, and failures managers face when planning for and implementing information system initiatives, particularly enterprise systems such as supply chain management, customer relationship management and enterprise resource planning systems.  Focus on the strategic and operational impact of emerging information technologies in modern day business management.  Design and development of knowledge worker applications including database and decision support systems.  4 lectures.

classes.name: Managerial Economics
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: OCOB graduate standing or approval from the Associate Dean.
classes.desc: Managerial economics, or microeconomics, focuses on private markets.  Choices made by firms and consumers within topics that include demand, supply, efficiency, marketing structure, and government intervention.  Development of an analytical framework for analyzing how these topics are important for managers.  4 lectures.

classes.name: Marketing Management
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: OCOB graduate standing or approval from the Associate Dean.
classes.desc: Introduction to marketing management.  Concepts and principles necessary to plan, direct and control the product, promotion, distribution and pricing strategies of the firm.  4 lectures.

classes.name: Effective Communication Skills for Managers
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: OCOB graduate standing or approval from the Associate Dean.
classes.desc: Enhancement of business writing and oral presentation skills, organized around two areas:  1) preparing written business documents and reports, and 2) professional oral presentation skills.  Preparation of a variety of business reports and documents.  Multiple business presentations.  4 lectures.

classes.name: Data Analytics and Mining for Business
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: GSA 555 or GSB 520.
classes.desc: Exploration of the concepts, tools and techniques of data mining in the business context, using case study and problem-solving approaches.  Topics include multidimensional data modeling, predictive analytics, pattern discovery, forecasting, text mining, and data visualization.  Course may be offered in classroom-based, online, or hybrid format.  4 lectures.

classes.name: Managerial Finance
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: OCOB graduate standing or approval from the Associate Dean.
classes.desc: Theories, practices and tools of corporate financial decision making.  Topics include valuation of fixed income securities and stocks, capital budgeting, capital structure, dividends, and an overview of financial markets and institutions.  Introduction to valuation of derivative securities, market efficiency, and agency costs.  4 seminars.

classes.name: Aggregate Economics Analysis and Policy
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: OCOB graduate standing or approval from the Associate Dean.
classes.desc: Development of the theoretical and empirical framework of the macroeconomy in which businesses must operate.  Topics include GDP, inflation, unemployment, interest rates and monetary and fiscal policies.  The dynamics of the macroeconomic environment over time.  4 lectures.

classes.name: Lean Operations Management
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: OCOB graduate standing or approval from the Associate Dean.
classes.desc: Introduction to the operations function and its interaction with other areas in an organization.  Emphasis on applying lean six sigma thinking to achieve competitive advantage in cost, quality, time, and flexibility in manufacturing and service operations.  4 lectures.  Course may be offered in classroom-based or online format.

classes.name: Data Ethics for Business Analytics
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: GSB 520; and OCOB graduate standing or approval from the Associate Dean.
classes.desc: Examination of ethical risks raised by data analysis, including data collection, ownership and usage.  Philosophical examination of topics raised by data analysis, including consent, privacy, transparency, bias and potential harms from data collection and use.  Course may be offered in classroom-based, online, or hybrid format.  2 lectures.

classes.name: Graduate Internship in Business
classes.pre_reqs: CR/NCPrerequisite: OCOB graduate standing and formal petition with approval from the Associate Dean.
classes.desc: Correlation of experience and academic knowledge.  Placement in a supervised business or public organization.  A formal written proposal must be accepted by the Associate Dean of OCOB Graduate Programs before work begins.  Credit/No Credit grading only.

classes.name: Computing and Machine Learning for Business Analytics
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: OCOB graduate standing or approval from the Associate Dean.
classes.desc: Use of computers for advanced data analysis in business analytics.  Topics include computer programming using statistical software, data gathering and cleaning, and machine learning.  Course may be offered in classroom-based, online, or hybrid format.  4 lectures.

classes.name: Advanced Machine Learning for Business Analytics
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: GSB 544; and OCOB graduate standing or approval from the Associate Dean.
classes.desc: Use of computers for advanced machine learning in business analytics.  Topics include boosting, ensemble learning, Bayesian methods, and various types of neural networks.  Course may be offered in classroom-based, online, or hybrid format.  4 lectures.

classes.name: Bayesian Econometrics
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: GSE 520.
classes.desc: Introduction to Bayesian econometrics with a focus on business decision making.  Making appropriate use of prior information; computation of posterior densities; Bayesian forecasting and policy evaluation; model selection and diagnostic tools; alternative loss functions tailored to specific business applications.  4 lectures.

classes.name: Negotiation
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: OCOB graduate standing or approval from the Associate Dean.
classes.desc: Theory and practice of negotiation in a variety of professional and managerial contexts (e.g., business acquisitions, compensation, business disputes, transfer pricing, inter- and intra-organizational) and in one-on-one, group, and team-based arrangements.  Includes impact of culture, ethics, dispute resolution, coalitions and use of creativity to develop integrative solutions.  4 seminars.

classes.name: Entrepreneurship and New Venture Management
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: OCOB graduate standing or approval from the Associate Dean.
classes.desc: Exploration of entrepreneurship with emphasis on the formation and management of new business ventures.  Analysis of typical operating problems of these firms and application of appropriate techniques for their solution.  4 seminars.

classes.name: Seminar in General Management and Strategy
classes.pre_reqs: Corequisite: OCOB graduate standing and GSB 511, GSB 513, GSB 523, GSB 531, GSB 533 and either GSB 512 or IME 503; and either GSB 524 or GSB 573; and either GSB 534 or IME 580, or approval from the Associate Dean.
classes.desc: Application of interdisciplinary skills to business and corporate strategy formulation and implementation.  Analysis of interdependence between external environments and internal systems.  Focus on responsibilities, tasks, and skills of general managers.  Case studies, group problem solving.  Integrating course of MBA core curriculum.  Course satisfies comprehensive examination requirement.  4 seminars.

classes.name: International Business Tour
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: OCOB graduate standing or approval from the Associate Dean.
classes.desc: Business tour exposure to different management systems and their operating environments.  Pre-trip and on-the-road meetings, readings, case studies and discussions.  Tours of firms, government offices, ministries, etc; interviews of managers and government officials.  Conducted in English.  Passport required.  The Class Schedule will list topic selected.  Total credit limited to 8 units.  2 seminars, 2 activities.

classes.name: Entrepreneurial Finance
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: GSB 531; and OCOB graduate standing or approval from the Associate Dean.
classes.desc: The process of financing new and fast-growing firms.  Preparation of pro forma financial statements for a new venture.  Readings on the venture capital process, from seed capital through the initial public offering (IPO).  Valuation of firms seeking venture capital, and those planning their IPO.  Valuing convertible securities.  Real options valuation.  4 lectures.

classes.name: Managing Technology in the International Legal Environment
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: OCOB graduate standing or approval from the Associate Dean.
classes.desc: Practical legal decisions required to conduct business for or with high technology companies.  Methods to protect high technology developments in international markets, including copyrights, patents, trade secrets, trademarks and contracts.  4 seminars.

classes.name: Selected Advanced Topics
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: OCOB graduate standing or approval from the Associate Dean.
classes.desc: Directed group study of selected topics for advanced students.  Total credit limited to 8 units.  The Class Schedule will list topic selected.  1 to 4 seminars.

classes.name: Marketing Research
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: OCOB graduate standing; and GSB 512 or GSE 518 or IME 503 or approval from the Associate Dean.
classes.desc: Preparation to become competent users and creators of marketing research information.  Focus on collecting customer information as well as analyzing, interpreting and presenting information to be used in executive decision making.  4 lectures.

classes.name: Career Readiness in Data Analytics
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: OCOB graduate standing or approval from the Associate Dean.
classes.desc: Career development and preparation with specific focus on the impact of organizational structures on the professions of business analytics and data science.  Personal marketing in a dynamic technological environment.  Course may be offered in classroom-based or online format.  1 lecture.

classes.name: Management of Human Resources
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: OCOB graduate standing or approval from the Associate Dean.
classes.desc: An overview of the major functional and support activities in the personnel/human resource field, including strategic human resource planning, job analysis, recruitment, selection, performance appraisal, compensation, employee rights, and employee safety and health.  4 seminars.

classes.name: Managing Change
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: OCOB graduate standing or approval from the Associate Dean.
classes.desc: The knowledge and the elementary skills/competencies needed to intervene in an organization in order to improve its effectiveness.  Design and use of action to improve organizational effectiveness.  4 seminars.

classes.name: Seminar in Selected Economic Problems
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: GSB 523 and OCOB graduate standing or approval from the Associate Dean.
classes.desc: Selected economic problems analyzed at an advanced level in a particular field, such as international trade, public finance, urban, industrial organization or transportation.  4 seminars.

classes.name: Independent Study
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: Consent of department head.
classes.desc: Advanced study planned and completed under the direction of a departmental faculty member.  Open only to graduate students demonstrating ability to do independent work.  Enrollment by petition.

classes.name: Essential Mathematics for Economic Analysis
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: Graduate standing. Recommended: MATH 206, MATH 244, or MATH 408.
classes.desc: Review and discussion of the basic math tools needed for graduate work in economics, including set theory, linear algebra, properties of functions, static and dynamic optimization.  4 lectures.

classes.name: Microeconomic Analysis
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: Graduate standing. Concurrent: GSE 510.
classes.desc: Preferences and choice, preferences over commodities, consumer demand theory, producer theory, choice under uncertainty, simultaneous and sequential move games, incomplete information games, mechanism and incentive design.  4 lectures.

classes.name: Dynamic Stochastic Modeling
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: GSE 511 and graduate standing.
classes.desc: Finite Markov chains, linear state space models, dynamic programming, rational expectations equlibrium, Markov perfect equilibrium, Stackelberg plans, general equilibrium under certainty and uncertainty, Arrow securities, consumption-based asset pricing, incomplete markets.  4 lectures.

classes.name: Essential Statistics for Econometrics
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: Graduate standing. Recommended: MATH 206 or MATH 244 or GSE 510.
classes.desc: Statistical concepts for use in theoretical and applied econometric applications including random variables, independence, expectations, probability, distributions, covariance and correlation, large sample theory, and properties of estimators.  4 lectures.

classes.name: Econometrics and Data Analysis
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: GSE 518. Corequisite: GSE 524.
classes.desc: Identification and estimation of linear and nonlinear regression models for analyzing business data.  Topics include multiple linear regression; model selection; robust standard errors; instrumental variables; maximum likelihood estimation; logit/probit, ordered logit/probit, and other microeconometric models.  4 lectures.

classes.name: Advanced Econometrics I
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: GSE 518 and graduate standing. Recommended: ECON 339.
classes.desc: The linear regression model.  Confidence and prediction intervals.  Hypothesis testing.  The generalized regression model and heteroscedasticity.  Identification and causal inference:  randomization, regression, instrumental variables, regression discontinuity, differences in differences.  4 lectures.

classes.name: Advanced Econometrics II
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: GSE 520 and graduate standing.
classes.desc: Maximum likelihood estimation.  Binary, multinomial, and ordered discrete response models.  Truncated, censored regression.  Structural equation modeling.  Factor models, filtering and Bayes rule.  Random utility and mixed logit models.  Demand estimation.  4 lectures.

classes.name: Computing and Machine Learning for Economics
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: Graduate standing.
classes.desc: Use of computers for advanced data analysis in economics and analytics.  Topics include computer programming using statistical software, data gathering and cleaning, and machine learning.  4 lectures.

classes.name: Microeconometrics
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: GSE 520 and graduate standing. Recommended: GSE 524.
classes.desc: Potential outcomes framework and causal treatment effects.  Unconfoundedness designs, including matching and propensity score methods.  Selection on unobservable designs.  Quantile regressions.  The econometrics of randomized experiments.  4 lectures.

classes.name: Environmental and Natural Resource Economics
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: GSE 511 and graduate standing.
classes.desc: Economic analysis of pollution, congestion, public good provision, and natural resource conservation.  Static and dynamic efficiency, economic growth and sustainability, pollution taxes, marketable permits, and the design of market-based regulations.  4 lectures.

classes.name: International Economics
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: GSE 511 and graduate standing.
classes.desc: Analysis of the international movement of goods, services, capital and payments.  The role of exchange rates, tariffs, quotas, and transport costs.  Relationship between international trade and economic growth.  4 lectures.

classes.name: Public Economics
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: GSE 511 and graduate standing.
classes.desc: Economic analysis of the rationale for public expenditure and taxation.  Externalities, pollution and public policy, income redistribution and public welfare, public goods, collective choice and political institutions, public budgeting techniques and cost-benefit analysis, taxation and tax policy, state-local finance and fiscal federalism.  4 lectures.

classes.name: Industrial Economics
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: GSE 511 and graduate standing.
classes.desc: Economic theories of industrial organization with specific reference to such topics as cartels, market concentration and performance, vertical integration, franchise contracts, ownership and control of firms, multipart and discriminatory pricing, and tie-in sales.  Economic aspects of antitrust law and government regulation of industry.  4 lectures.

classes.name: Advanced Labor Economics
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: GSE 522 and graduate standing, or consent of instructor. Recommended: GSE 526.
classes.desc: Research methods in labor economics and application of modern empirical techniques to the analysis of labor markets.  Topics include labor supply and demand, discrimination, migration, and human capital accumulation.  4 lectures.

classes.name: Evidence-Based Decision Analysis
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: GSE 520 and graduate standing. Recommended: GSE 524 and GSE 526.
classes.desc: Representing uncertainty using discrete and continuous conditional probabilities.  Monte Carlo simulation of independent and correlated random variables.  Optimization of decision variables.  Randomization in program evaluation.  Model mis-specification.  Visualization and representation of the results of a decision analysis.  Case studies.  4 lectures.

classes.name: Incentives and Market Design
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: GSE 511 and graduate standing.
classes.desc: Ascending, first-price, second-price, and double auctions.  Revenue equivalence, multi-unit auctions, the Vickrey-Clarke-Groves mechanism, and matching markets.  The deferred acceptance algorithm, the immediate acceptance algorithm, and the many-to-one matching model.  4 lectures.

classes.name: Machine Learning for Prediction and Causal Inference
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: GSE 526 and graduate standing.
classes.desc: Regularization, model selection, and supervised and unsupervised learning.  Post model selection inference for causal effects.  Double/debiased machine learning, causal trees, casual forests, and synthetic controls.  4 lectures.

classes.name: Selected Advanced Topics
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: Graduate standing or consent of instructor.
classes.desc: Directed group study of selected topics for graduate students.  Open to undergraduate and graduate students.  The Class Schedule will list topic selected.  Total credit limited to 8 units.  1 to 4 lectures.

classes.name: Seminar in Economics
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: Graduate standing.
classes.desc: Advanced topics in economics chosen according to the common interests and needs of the students enrolled.  The Class Schedule will list topic selected.  1 to 4 seminars.  Total credit limited to 5 units.

classes.name: Thesis
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: Graduate standing and consent of thesis committee.
classes.desc: Individual research under the general supervision of the faculty, leading to a graduate thesis of suitable quality.  Minimum of 8 units required for degree.

classes.name: Packaging Value Chain
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: OCOB graduate standing or approval from the Associate Dean.
classes.desc: Packaging value chain from raw material supplier to retailers in the context of meeting current needs within the packaging arena.  Global exploration of value chain strategies to increase innovation, sustainability, cost savings, quality, organizational agility, and responsiveness.  Course may be offered in classroom-based or online format.  2 lectures.

classes.name: Packaging Materials
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: OCOB graduate standing or approval from the Associate Dean of OCOB. Corequisite: GSP 530.
classes.desc: Fundamental and physical properties of packaging materials.  Processing of materials.  Design and fabrication of packaging materials for efficient, economically viable and environmental sustainable product-package systems for global supply chain solutions.  Course may be offered in classroom-based or online format.  4 lectures.

classes.name: Advanced Packaging Laws and Regulations
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: OCOB graduate standing or approval from the Associate Dean. Corequisite: GSP 530.
classes.desc: Overview of packaging laws and regulations.  Content ranges from FDA, USDA, FTC, and EPA concepts, to labeling and structural issues such as bio-terror, product security and environmental packaging to materials issues, litigation, international concepts and intellectual property issues.  Course may be offered in classroom-based or online format.  3 lectures.

classes.name: Packaging Value in Logistics and Supply Chain Management
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: OCOB graduate standing or approval from the Associate Dean. Corequisite: GSP 530.
classes.desc: Integrated view of procurement, operations and logistics management.  Management of the flow of products from raw material sourcing and acquisition through delivery to the final user.  Capturing and understanding the value across these flows and how to increase it.  Course may be offered in classroom-based or online format.  3 lectures.

classes.name: Packaging Design
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: OCOB graduate standing or approval from the Associate Dean. Corequisite: GSP 530.
classes.desc: Overview of structural and graphic design concepts for package design with focus on creating value throughout the entire packaging value chain.  Topics include design thinking, innovation, design processes, two-dimensional and three-dimensional design elements, positioning, value creation, and distribution packaging considerations.  Course may be offered in classroom-based or online format.  4 lectures.

classes.name: Distribution Packaging for Business Managers
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: OCOB graduate standing or approval from the Associate Dean of OCOB.
classes.desc: Physical properties of distribution packaging and equipment used in prototyping and testing of product-packaging systems for global supply chains.  Application of packaging knowledge to solve distribution packaging problems in modern business, with a view towards costs and environmental sustainability.  Course may be offered in classroom-based or online format.  4 lectures.  Formerly ITP 537.

classes.name: Quality Evaluation of Packaged Products
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: OCOB graduate standing or approval from the Associate Dean. Corequisite: GSP 530.
classes.desc: Overview of the role of quality of packaged product and techniques used for testing and evaluating quality of consumer products as related to material quality assessment, product-package interaction and human-package interaction.  Course may be offered in classroom-based or online format.  4 Lectures.

classes.name: Marketing and Sales for Packaged Products
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: OCOB graduate standing or approval from the Associate Dean. Corequisite: GSP 530.
classes.desc: Packaging as a means to increase sales of product.  Package design, structure, materials and production costs.  Exploration of color, imagery, sustainability, and recent trends.  Course is offered online only.  4 lectures.

classes.name: Quantitative Analysis for Packaging
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: OCOB graduate standing or approval from the Associate Dean. Corequisite: GSP 530.
classes.desc: Analytical and quantitative techniques.  Summary measures, smoothing, interpolation curve fitting, root-finding, extrema.  Numerical differentiation, integration.  Boundary value problems.  Numerical simulation.  Course may be offered in classroom-based or online format.  4 lectures.

classes.name: Corporate Finance for Packaging
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: OCOB graduate standing or approval from the Associate Dean. Corequisite: GSP 530.
classes.desc: Decisions with financial implications for firms' owners and stakeholders in the context of packaging.  Choice of best packaging alternative from the financial standpoint.  Course offered online only.  4 Lectures.

classes.name: Applied Industry Project I
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: OCOB graduate standing or approval from the Associate Dean.
classes.desc: Initiation, completion and presentation of an individual project, involving research, allowing an opportunity to apply knowledge, skills, and competencies to address a significant issue in the field of packaging value chain, preferably in connection with the student's employment.  Formerly ITP 591.

classes.name: Introduction to Graphic Communication
classes.desc: Graphic communication history, theory, processes, applications, and practices.
