Introduces the use of commercial finite element codes.  3 lectures, 1 laboratory.  Crosslisted as BMED/CE/ME 404.

classes.name: Mechatronics
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: EE 321, EE 361, ME 305, and ME 329 (ME329 may be taken concurrently); or CPE 316 or CPE/EE 329 or CPE/EE 336.
classes.desc: Microprocessor applications in machine control and product design.  Applied electronics.  Drive technology; transducers and electromechanical systems.  Real-time programming.  Mechatronic design methodology.  3 lectures, 1 laboratory.

classes.name: Interdisciplinary Study in Biomechanics
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: BMED 410 and CE 207; or KINE 403; or ME 326.
classes.desc: Examination of human motion biomechanics.  Experimental and analytical methods in motion analysis based on rigid body dynamics.  Protocols for protection of human subjects in research.  Hypothesis-driven research in interdisciplinary teams, including written proposal development and written/oral communication of results to a scientific audience.  1 lecture, 3 activities.  Crosslisted as BMED/KINE/ME 409.

classes.name: Experimental Methods in Mechanical Design I
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: ME 328. Recommended: ME 318.
classes.desc: Bonded resistance strain gages for static and dynamic measurements; rosettes, bridge circuits, lead wire effects, special gages.  Data acquisition systems, and measurement of displacement, velocity, and acceleration.  Photoelastic methods including birefringent coatings.  Applications in mechanical design and metrology.  3 lectures, 1 laboratory.

classes.name: Composite Materials Analysis and Design
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: AERO 331 or ME 328.
classes.desc: Behavior of unidirectional fiber composites.  Properties of short-fiber composites, and orthotropic lamina.  Analysis of laminated composites.  Strength and hygrothermal behavior of composite materials.  Structural optimization.  3 lectures, 1 laboratory.

classes.name: Energy Conversion
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: ME 302.
classes.desc: Engineering aspects of energy sources, conversion and storage.  Topics selected from fossil fuel systems, nuclear power, thermoelectric systems, thermionic converters, fuel cells, magnetohydrodynamic generators, and geothermal, tidal, wind and ocean temperature energy conversion systems.  4 lectures.

classes.name: Ground Vehicle Dynamics and Design
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: ME 318 and ME 329.
classes.desc: Design of ground vehicles for directional stability and control.  Tire mechanics and their effects on vehicle performance.  Simulation of vehicle dynamics using digital computer.  Synthesis of steering mechanism and suspension system.  3 lectures, 1 laboratory.

classes.name: Implementation of Mechanical Controls
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: ME 322.
classes.desc: Analysis, design, and implementation of automated controllers for mechanical systems.  Experimental measurement of dynamic properties and creation of system models.  Analysis and simulation of the effect of control strategies on system dynamics.  Design of closed-loop control systems, including control of dynamic properties and implementation using common embedded computing hardware.  Not open to students with credit in ME 419 or ME 422.  3 lectures, 1 laboratory.

classes.name: Advanced Control Systems
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: ME 322, ME 236.
classes.desc: Modeling and control of physical systems.  Design of mechanical, hydraulic and electrical feedback control systems using time response, transfer function, frequency response, state space and computer simulation.  Address state feedback, observability and controllability of multi-input, multi-output systems.  Not open to students with credit in ME 418 or ME 422.  3 lectures, 1 laboratory.

classes.name: Thermal System Design and Simulation
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: ME 303; ME 347; and ME 350.
classes.desc: Radiation and combined mode heat transfer.  Design of thermal systems.  Engineering economics, thermal component sizing, and steady-state simulation techniques applied to the design and performance analysis of thermal systems.  Not open to students with credit in ME 440.  3 lectures, 1 laboratory.

classes.name: Mechanical Control Systems
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: ME 318.
classes.desc: Modeling and control of physical systems.  Design of mechanical, hydraulic and electrical systems using time response, frequency response, state space, and computer simulation.  Not open to students with credit in ME 418 or ME 419.  3 lectures, 1 laboratory.

classes.name: Robotics: Fundamentals and Applications
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: ME 326; ME 418 or ME 419 or ME 422.
classes.desc: Introduction to robots and their types.  Homogeneous transformations.  Kinematic equations and their solutions.  Motion trajectories, statics, dynamics, and control of robots.  Robot programming.  Actuators, sensors and vision systems.  3 lectures, 1 laboratory.

classes.name: Senior Design Project I
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: ME 329. Corequisite: ME 318; ME 343 or ME 350; and IME 141, IME 142, IME 143, IME 146, ME 161, or ITP 341.
classes.desc: First of three courses taken sequentially in component and system design using real-world problems.  Small teams study and apply techniques of the engineering design process including problem definition, concept generation, feasibility studies and decision making.  Practice of professional skills including written and oral communication, teaming, project management, societal responsibility and ethics.  2 laboratories.

classes.name: Senior Design Project II
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: ME 428.
classes.desc: Continuation of a project begun in ME 428.  Activities focused on detail design, analysis and material procurement.  2 laboratories.

classes.name: Senior Design Project III
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: ME 429.
classes.desc: Completion of a project begun in ME 428 and continued in ME 429.  Design verified through prototyping and testing.  2 laboratories.

classes.name: Enhanced Oil Recovery
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: ME 302; ME 347; and ME 343 or ME 350.
classes.desc: Primary, secondary, and tertiary (enhanced) oil recovery methods.  Waterflooding, polymerflooding, gas injection, steam injection, in-situ combustion, chemical flooding, miscible flooding.  Performance calculations and computer applications in EOR.  4 lectures.

classes.name: Drilling Engineering
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: ME 329, ME 347.
classes.desc: Theory and practice of oilwell planning, drilling, well logging, and completion applied to the development of new oil and gas production, from onshore and offshore fields.  4 lectures.

classes.name: Petroleum Production Engineering
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: ME 329, ME 347.
classes.desc: Design and operation of surface and subsurface equipment required in oil production.  Processes and systems involved are rod pumping, gas lifting, acidizing, hydraulic fracturing, fluid gathering and storage, separation of oil, gas, water and sediment from produced fluid.  Includes equipment used in enhanced oil recovery processes.  4 lectures.

classes.name: Nuclear Energy Power Generation
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: Junior standing; PHYS 132 and PHYS 133.
classes.desc: Operation of a nuclear electric generation station; includes reactor water chemistry, material science, electric science, mechanical science, civil engineering for the nuclear power plant engineers and digital process control systems.  Field trip may be required.  4 lectures.

classes.name: Nuclear Power Plant Design
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: ME 302.
classes.desc: Principal elements of pressurized water reactor nuclear power systems; overview of reactor physics, thermodynamics, and heat transfer; includes basic reactor physics, reactor heat generation, reactor plant systems, support systems, and reactor safety.  Field trip may be required.  4 lectures.

classes.name: Nuclear Power Plant Operations
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: ME 437 or ME 438.
classes.desc: Overview of mass, momentum and energy conversion related to nuclear power plants; includes coupled neutronic/thermal models to study plant operation semi-quantitatively achieving an integrated plant understanding.  Content includes:  Neutron power kinetics, Coupled neutronic/thermal hydraulic modeling, Quantitative transient modeling, demonstration transients.  Field trip may be required.  4 lectures.

classes.name: Single Track Vehicle Design
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: ME 326 and ME 329; or consent of instructor.
classes.desc: Design of single track vehicles, including handling characteristics, ergonomics and human power, strength and stiffness considerations, braking and suspension.  Laboratory focus on designing a single track vehicle, including fabrication of a handling prototype.  3 lectures, 1 laboratory.

classes.name: Design of Machinery
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: ME 212.
classes.desc: Graphical synthesis and analysis of mechanisms and machines.  Analytical fundamentals for study of displacements, velocities, accelerations, and static and dynamic forces necessary for design of planar linkages and gearing systems.  Creative design projects using software simulation tools.  3 lectures, 1 laboratory.

classes.name: Turbomachinery
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: MATH 344; ME 303; ME 347; and ME 343 or ME 350.
classes.desc: Performance characteristics of various types for liquids and for gases.  Criteria for proper selection of type and main dimensions.  Cavitation criteria.  Gas turbine cycles and performance.  Two-dimensional cascades.  Axial flow turbines and compressors.  Centrifugal compressors and radial-inflow turbines.  4 lectures.

classes.name: Combustion Engine Design
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: ME 303; ME 347; and ME 343 or ME 350.
classes.desc: Application of design parameters to the various engine cycles.  Aspects of the combustion processes.  Emission regulation effects on engine design.  Static and dynamic loading.  3 lectures, 1 laboratory.

classes.name: Thermal System Design
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisites: ME 303, ME 343, and ME 347.
classes.desc: Design of thermal systems.  Engineering economics, thermal component sizing, and simulation techniques applied to the design and performance analysis of thermal systems.  Not open to students with credit in ME 420.  3 lectures, 1 laboratory.

classes.name: Solar Thermal Power Systems
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: ME 343 or ME 350. Recommended: ME 415.
classes.desc: High and intermediate temperature systems for conversion of solar energy to mechanical power and heat.  Thermal energy storage and total thermal energy system design.  3 lectures, 1 laboratory.

classes.name: Trends and Opportunities in HVAC&R
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: ME 302 or ENVE 304.
classes.desc: Overview of the roles of the Heating, Ventilating, Air-Conditioning and Refrigeration (HVAC&R) industry.  Presentation of state-of-the-art HVAC&R systems, components and design solutions.  Includes guest speakers from HVAC&R industry.  1 activity.

classes.name: Benchmarking and Assessment of Building Energy Performance
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: ME 343 or ME 350. Recommended: ME 359.
classes.desc: An introduction and study of building energy assessment principles and protocols for existing commercial buildings.  Course topics include techniques of energy measurement and verification, energy metric comparison and analysis, and energy auditing.  Field trip required.  3 lectures, 1 laboratory.

classes.name: Introduction to Building Energy Modeling
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: ME 343 or ME 350. Recommended: ME 359.
classes.desc: Introduction to principles and practices of building energy modeling.  Case studies using state of the art energy modeling computer software to simulate the energy use of buildings.  Methods to reduce energy consumption of buildings.  2 lectures, 1 laboratory.

classes.name: HVAC Air and Water Distribution System Design
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: ME 302, ME 347.
classes.desc: Air and water distribution components and systems and the design of these systems with applications to the heating, ventilating and air-conditioning (HVAC) industry.  3 lectures, 1 laboratory.

classes.name: Refrigeration Principles and Design
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: ME 341; ME 343 or ME 350.
classes.desc: Basic engineering principles of refrigeration processes including:  vapor compression cycles, multipressure systems, absorption systems, steam jet cooling, air cycles, and low temperature refrigeration.  3 lectures, 1 laboratory.

classes.name: Building Heating and Cooling Loads
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: ME 303; and ME 343 or ME 350.
classes.desc: Building heating and cooling load calculations, estimating energy consumption and operating costs for heating, ventilating and air-conditioning system design and selection.  3 lectures, 1 laboratory.

classes.name: HVAC Senior Design Project I
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: ME 456.
classes.desc: First quarter of a two quarter sequence.  Team project work in designing heating, ventilating and air-conditioning (HVAC) systems.  New developments, policies and practices in the HVAC industry.  Professional ethics relevant for practicing engineers.  1 lecture, 2 laboratories.

classes.name: HVAC Senior Design Project II
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: ME 459.
classes.desc: Continuation of work begun in ME 459.  Team project designing heating, ventilating and air-conditioning (HVAC) systems.  2 laboratories.

classes.name: Selected Advanced Topics
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: Consent of instructor.
classes.desc: Directed group study of selected topics for advanced students.  Open to undergraduate and graduate students.  The Class Schedule will list topic selected.  Total credit limited to 12 units.  1 to 4 lectures.

classes.name: Selected Advanced Laboratory
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: Consent of instructor.
classes.desc: Directed group laboratory study of selected topics for advanced students.  Open to undergraduate and graduate students.  The Class Schedule will list topic selected.  Total credit limited to 8 units.  1 to 4 laboratories.

classes.name: Wind Energy Engineering
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: ME 329, ME 347, ME 302.
classes.desc: Engineering aspects of windpower systems including mechanical design, support structure design, aerodynamic analysis, wind field analysis, system concepts and analysis, and economics.  4 lectures.

classes.name: Cooperative Education Experience
classes.pre_reqs: CR/NCPrerequisite: Sophomore standing and consent of instructor.
classes.desc: Part-time work experience in business, industry, government, and other areas of student career interest.  Positions are paid and usually require relocation and registration in course for two consecutive quarters.  Formal report and evaluation by work supervisor required.  Credit/No Credit grading only.  No major credit allowed; total credit limited to 6 units.

classes.name: Cooperative Education Experience
classes.pre_reqs: CR/NCPrerequisite: Sophomore standing and consent of instructor.
classes.desc: Full-time work experience in business, industry, government, and other areas of student career interest.  Positions are paid and usually require relocation and registration in course for two consecutive quarters.  Formal report and evaluation by work supervisor required.  Credit/No Credit grading only.  No major credit allowed; total credit limited to 18 units.

classes.name: Cooperative Education Experience
classes.pre_reqs: CR/NCPrerequisite: Sophomore standing and consent of instructor.
classes.desc: Full-time work experience in business, industry, government, and other areas of student career interest.  Positions are paid and usually require relocation and registration in course for two consecutive quarters.  A more fully developed formal report and evaluation by work supervisor required.  Credit/No Credit grading only.  No major credit allowed; total credit limited to 24 units.

classes.name: Individual Study
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: Consent of department head, graduate advisor and supervising faculty member.
classes.desc: Advanced study planned and completed under the direction of a member of the department faculty.  Open only to graduate students who have demonstrated ability to do independent work.  Enrollment by petition.

classes.name: Continuum Mechanics and Elasticity
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: Graduate standing.
classes.desc: Introduction to continuum mechanics.  Kinematics, stress, and balance laws.  Constitutive theory for isotropic and anisotropic solids and viscous fluids.  Applications including design of beams and pressure vessels, stress concentrations, fiber-reinforced composites, and non-homogeneous biological materials.  4 lectures.  Crosslisted as CE 511/ME 501.

classes.name: Inelastic Stress Analysis
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: ME 501 or CE 511.
classes.desc: Perfectly plastic and work hardening materials; von Mises and Tresca yield, isotropic and kinematic hardening flow rules, boundary-value problems.  Finite elasticity:  kinematics, Cauchy- and Green-elasticity, invariance, constraints, Neo-Hookean and Mooney-Rivlin materials, experimental approaches, non-uniqueness, anisotropy, residual stress, thermoelasticity, boundary-value problems.  4 lectures.  Crosslisted as CE 513/ME 503.

classes.name: Finite Element Analysis
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: CE/ME 404 and CE 511/ME 501 or consent of instructor.
classes.desc: Finite element theory and application with a focus on computer implementation of the method.  Strong, weak and variational formulations, physical and isoparametric spaces, error estimates, numerical integration, finite element algorithms, and programming architecture.  3 lectures, 1 laboratory.  Crosslisted as CE/ME 504.

classes.name: System Dynamics
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: Graduate standing or consent of instructor.
classes.desc: Unified approach for mathematical modeling and analysis of dynamic physical systems which may store energy in multiple energy domains.  Emphasis on developing lumped-parameter linear system models from a set of primitive elements in a systematic manner.  4 lectures.

classes.name: Mechanical Control System Design
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: Graduate standing or consent of instructor.
classes.desc: Application of principles of high-level design to mechanical control system implementation.  Use of modified state transition logic in conjunction with object-oriented programming as design methodology.  Real-time programming using above techniques for control of mechanical systems.  3 lectures, 1 laboratory.

classes.name: Advanced Vibrations
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: ME 318, graduate standing or consent of instructor.
classes.desc: Vibration of complex engineering systems.  Inertia and stiffness matrices.  Natural frequencies and normal modes.  Approximate solutions and computer techniques.  Response to transient and periodic inputs.  3 lectures, 1 laboratory.

classes.name: Machinery Vibration and Rotor Dynamics
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: ME 318, graduate standing or consent of instructor.
classes.desc: Vibrations relating to rotating machinery.  Modeling of structural rotordynamic phenomena induced by shaft flexibility, bearings, and seals.  Laboratory measurement of rotor system dynamic response and interpretation of machinery diagnostic information.  Research project on a related topic.  3 lectures, 1 laboratory.

classes.name: Viscous Flow
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: ME 347, MATH 344 and graduate standing or consent of instructor.
classes.desc: Introduction to tensor calculus and indicial notation.  Development of Reynolds' Transport Theory.  Special forms of the governing equations of fluid motion.  Internal flows and other classical solutions to the Navier-Stokes equations.  4 lectures.

classes.name: Advanced Thermodynamics
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: ME 303 and ME 347; ME 343 or ME 350; and graduate standing.
classes.desc: Selected modern applications of thermodynamics which may include topics from:  1) equilibrium and kinetics as applied to combustion and air pollution, analysis and evaluation of techniques used to predict properties of gases and liquids, and 2) improvement of modern thermodynamic cycles by second law analysis.  4 lectures.

classes.name: Dynamics and Thermodynamics of Compressible Flow
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: MATH 244; ME 303; ME 347; ME 343 or ME 350; and graduate standing.
classes.desc: Control volume analysis of fluid-thermo equations for one-dimensional, compressible flow involving area change, normal shocks, friction, and heat transfer.  Two-dimensional supersonic flow including linearization, method of characteristics, and oblique shocks.  One-dimensional constant area, unsteady flow, 4 lectures.

classes.name: Advanced Heat Transfer I
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: MATH 344; ME 347; ME 343 or ME 350; and graduate standing.
classes.desc: Advanced principles of heat transfer.  Classical solution techniques to problems in conduction and/or radiation.  4 lectures.

classes.name: Advanced Heat Transfer II
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: MATH 344; ME 347; ME 343 or ME 350; and graduate standing.
classes.desc: Advanced principles of heat transfer.  Classical solution techniques to problems in convection.  4 lectures.

classes.name: Computational Heat Transfer
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: MATH 418; ME 347; ME 343 or ME 350; and graduate standing.
classes.desc: Numerical solutions of classical, industrial, and experimental problems in conduction, convection, and radiation heat transfer.  3 lectures, 1 laboratory.

classes.name: Advanced Heat Transfer III
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: ME 347 or FPE 502; ME 343 or ME 350.
classes.desc: Advanced principles of heat transfer.  Classical solution techniques to problems in radiation with applications related to the role of radiation heat transfer in the development of fire in buildings.  4 lectures.  Crosslisted as FPE/ME 556.

classes.name: Graduate Seminar
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: Graduate standing in mechanical engineering program.
classes.desc: Current developments in mechanical engineering.  Participation by graduate students, faculty and guests.  1 seminar.

classes.name: Selected Advanced Topics
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: Graduate standing or consent of instructor.
classes.desc: Directed group study of selected topics for advanced students.  The Class Schedule will list topic selected.  Total credit limited to 8 units; may be repeated in same term.  1 to 4 seminars.

classes.name: Selected Advanced Laboratory
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: Graduate standing of consent of instructor.
classes.desc: Directed group laboratory study of selected topics for advanced students.  The Class Schedule will list topic selected.  Total credit limited to 8 units; may be repeated in same term.  1 to 4 laboratories.

classes.name: Fluid Power Control
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: ME 418 or ME 419 or ME 422.
classes.desc: Design, analysis, and control of fluid power systems.  Analysis of fluid power system components such as valves, actuators, pumps and motors.  System response and stability.  Dynamic modeling and computer simulation 3 lectures, 1 laboratory.

classes.name: Design Project (Thesis)
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: Graduate standing.
classes.desc: Each individual or group will be assigned a project for solution under faculty supervision as a requirement for the master's degree, culminating in a written report/thesis.

classes.name: Introduction to Microbiology Research
classes.pre_reqs: CR/NC
classes.desc: Group research experience in microbiology through participation in a faculty-student research project. Foundations of the scientific method including literature review, design of experiments, common laboratory techniques, data analysis, interpretation of results and scientific communication. Intended for freshmen and sophomores with no research experience. Priority to MCRO majors. Credit/No Credit grading only. 1 seminar, 1 laboratory.

classes.name: Microbiology
classes.pre_reqs: 2020-21 or later catalog: GE Area B22020-21 or later catalog: GE Area B32019-20 or earlier catalog: GE Area B22019-20 or earlier catalog: GE Area B4Prerequisite: CHEM 110 or CHEM 124 or CHEM 127.
classes.desc: Microbial classification and identification, cell structure and function, metabolism, microbial systems and evolutionary processes, with applications to industry, agriculture, food production, environment, and health.  Not open to students with credit in MCRO 224; not for credit for Biology and Microbiology majors.  3 lectures, 1 laboratory.  Fulfills GE Areas B2 and B3 (GE Areas B2 and B4 for students on the 2019-20 or earlier catalogs).

classes.name: General Microbiology I
classes.pre_reqs: 2020-21 or later catalog: GE Area B22020-21 or later catalog: GE Area B32019-20 or earlier catalog: GE Area B22019-20 or earlier catalog: GE Area B4Prerequisite: BIO 161; and CHEM 125 or CHEM 128. Recommended: CHEM 129.
classes.desc: Fundamental concepts of prokaryotes, eukaryotic microorganisms and microbiological entities.  Microbial taxonomy, classification, cellular structure and function, metabolism, growth dynamics and control.  Introduction to microbial genetics and molecular techniques.  Microbial interaction with human and society.  Fundamental laboratory techniques in microbiology.  3 lectures, 2 laboratories.  Fulfills GE Areas B2 and B3 (GE Areas B2 and B4 for students on the 2019-20 or earlier catalogs).

classes.name: General Microbiology II
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: MCRO 224.
classes.desc: Microbial diversity, systematics, ecology, and symbiotic relationships.  Introduction to host-microorganism interactions including pathogenesis, epidemiology, and immunology.  3 lectures, 2 laboratories.

classes.name: Wine Microbiology
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: MCRO majors must have MCRO 224; WVIT majors must have MCRO 221 or MCRO 224; and WVIT 202; open to MCRO or WVIT majors only.
classes.desc: Wine yeasts, bacteria, and molds:  morphology and methods of identification; successful alcoholic and malolactic fermentations; management and prevention of unwanted microbial growth; micro-organisms and flavor development.  3 lectures, 1 laboratory.  Crosslisted as MCRO/WVIT 301.

classes.name: Emerging Infectious Diseases
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: BIO 161; and MCRO 221 or MCRO 224.
classes.desc: Recent outbreaks of human diseases, interrelationships between infectious disease agents, human biology, and the environment.  Infectious agents and disease processes, virulence mechanisms, and host immune response.  Clinical approaches and surveillance methods to detect, investigate, and monitor emerging pathogens.  Factors involved in the accelerating emergence of diseases and bioterrorist agents.  3 lectures.

classes.name: Public Health Microbiology
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: MCRO 221 or MCRO 224.
classes.desc: Principles of disease prevention and control.  Water-, food-, and air-borne microbial contaminations and epidemiology of ensuing diseases.  3 lectures, 1 laboratory.

classes.name: General Virology
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: BIO 351 or CHEM 373, or graduate standing in Biological Sciences. Recommended: BIO 452.
classes.desc: Infective macromolecules (prions, viroids, and viruses) associated with microbes, plants, and animals.  Epidemiology, immune responses, pathogenicity, carcinogenesis, diagnoses, vaccination, and therapy.  3 lectures, 1 laboratory.

classes.name: Food Microbiology
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: MCRO 221 or MCRO 224. Recommended: CHEM 212/312.
classes.desc: Physiological activities of microorganisms involved in the preparation, preservation, deterioration, and toxicity of foods and related products.  Detection and prevention of spoilage microorganisms and foodborne pathogens.  3 lectures, 1 laboratory.

classes.name: Medical Microbiology
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: Junior standing; MCRO 225; and CHEM 216, CHEM 312 or CHEM 316; and consent of instructor.
classes.desc: Microorganisms as agents of disease in humans.  Epidemiology, host-parasite relationships, and chemotherapy.  The compromised host and opportunistic disease.  Laboratory safety.  Procedures for laboratory diagnosis of human diseases.  Rapid miniaturized methods of identification.  3 lectures, 2 laboratories.

classes.name: Microbial Physiology
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: MCRO 225 and CHEM 313 or CHEM 371, or graduate standing in Biological Sciences.
classes.desc: Cellular structure and life processes of bacteria; chemical composition, growth, and metabolism.  General biological and evolutionary considerations.  3 lectures, 2 laboratories.

classes.name: Microbial Biotechnology
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: MCRO 221 or MCRO 224; and BIO 303 or BIO 351 or equivalent; and CHEM 216, CHEM 312 or CHEM 316 or equivalent, or graduate standing in Biological Sciences.
classes.desc: Principles and methods used for production of enzymes, pharmaceuticals, chemicals, and food additives using micro-organisms.  Topics include screening and strain improvement, regulation of metabolite production, genetic engineering, heterologous gene expression systems, large-scale production, and intellectual property.  3 lectures.

classes.name: Microbial Ecology
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: BIO 160; BIO 161; BIO 263; and MCRO 221 or MCRO 224; or graduate standing in Biological Sciences.
classes.desc: Ecology and interactions of microorganisms in natural environments.  Role of microorganisms in ecosystem function such as nutrient cycling, extreme environments, symbioses.  Applications of microorganisms in the environment such as bioremediation, biocontrol, biofuels.  Field trip may be required.  2 lectures, 2 activities.

classes.name: Foundation of Officership I
classes.desc: Introduction to issues and competencies of the Army officer profession. Emphasis on stereotypes about the military, the role of the Army officer, customs and traditions within the military, and personal and physical development. 1 lecture.

classes.name: Foundation of Officership II
classes.desc: The role of leadership within a large organization. Emphasis on the definition of leadership, leadership framework, individual and organizational core values, and the moral responsibility of leadership. 1 lecture.

classes.name: Basic Leadership
classes.desc: The foundation of basic leadership fundamentals such as problem solving, communications, briefings and effective writing, techniques for improving listening and speaking skills, and an introduction to counseling. 1 lecture.

classes.name: Exercises in Military Leadership
classes.pre_reqs: CR/NCPrerequisite: Enrollment in any MSL course or consent of department head.
classes.desc: Hands-on instruction on the proper execution of small-unit military operations.  Incorporation of the military decision-making process in the planning, execution and conducting of a wide variety of squad, platoon and company sized missions.  Credit/No Credit grading only.  1 activity.

classes.name: Orienteering
classes.desc: Principles of orienteering, basic map reading and compass skills; course running techniques applied in field orienteering events. 1 lecture, 1 activity.

classes.name: The Army Physical Fitness Program
classes.desc: The Army Physical Fitness Program and its proper execution. Physical training to the Army standard with the goal of successfully passing the Army Physical Fitness Test. 1 laboratory.

classes.name: Foundations of Leadership I
classes.desc: The development of individual leadership traits and capabilities using the Army officer as a model. The Army's problem solving methods, written and oral communications, tactics and group leadership. 2 lectures.

classes.name: Foundations of Leadership II
classes.desc: The development of individual leadership traits and capabilities using the Army officer as a model. The Army's problem solving methods, tactics and group leadership. 2 lectures.

classes.name: Foundations of Leadership III
classes.desc: The development of individual leadership traits and capabilities using the Army officer as a model. The Army's problem solving methods, land navigation techniques, tactics and group leadership. 2 lectures.

classes.name: Leader's Training Course
classes.desc: One to seven units of credit may be granted depending upon successful completion of training. Five weeks of training, Fort Knox, Kentucky. Travel pay and salary provided through the Military Science Department. No obligation. LTC graduates eligible to enroll in ROTC Advanced Program.

classes.name: Ranger Challenge
classes.pre_reqs: CR/NC
classes.desc: Selection and preparation of the Ranger Challenge Team which will represent Cal Poly in military tactical skills competition. Includes rope bridging, orienteering, weapons knowledge, hand grenade accuracy, 10K road march with equipment, first aid, marksmanship, physical fitness and tactics. Credit/No Credit grading only. 2 activities.

classes.name: American Military History and the Evolution of Western Warfare
classes.desc: Comprehensive analysis of American military history from the early Anglo-French period to the end of the 20th Century. Examination of the strategies, operations and tactics of military warfare, and exploration of how social, economic, and technological factors produced the distinct patterns of war that characterize the struggles of the past two hundred plus years. Open to all students. 4 lectures.

classes.name: Selected Topics
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: Open to undergraduate students and consent of instructor.
classes.desc: Directed group study of selected topics.  The Class Schedule will list topic selected.  Total credit limited to 8 units.  1 to 4 lectures.

classes.name: Facilitation and Teambuilding
classes.desc: Techniques and models used in leadership, facilitation, and teambuilding. Emphasis on leadership and facilitation styles and models, teambuilding and group dynamics, and working with various populations. Field trip required. 2 seminars. Crosslisted as MSL/RPTA 275.

classes.name: Tactical Leadership I
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: Completion of MSL 101, MSL 102, MSL 103, MSL 201, MSL 202, MSL 203, or completion of MSL 212, and consent of department head.
classes.desc: Introduction to the life of a professional Army officer.  Instruction in the operational art of small-unit leadership, and the roles and responsibilities of an Army 2nd Lieutenant in preparation for attendance at the Leader Development and Assessment Course.  3 lectures.

classes.name: Tactical Leadership II
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: MSL 301, and consent of instructor.
classes.desc: Continuation of study of the life of a professional Army officer.  Instruction in the operational art of small-unit leadership, and the roles and responsibilities of an Army 2nd Lieutenant in preparation for attendance at the Leader Development and Assessment Course.  3 lectures.

classes.name: Applied Leadership
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: MSL 301, MSL 302, and consent of instructor.
classes.desc: Demonstration of proficiency in leading small units.  Emphasis on clear and concise oral communications, land navigation, weapons skills, and timely decision-making.  Completion of training for the Leader Development and Assessment Course and preparation for attendance at the course.  3 lectures.

classes.name: Advanced Leadership of Military Exercises
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: MSL 110. Recommended: MSL 203 or MSL 212.
classes.desc: The planning, resourcing and execution of selected Army tactical missions in a field environment, and leading all students enrolled in MSL 110.  Total credit limited to 3 units.  1 activity.

classes.name: Leadership of the Army Physical Fitness Program
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: MSL 112. Recommended: MSL 203 or MSL 212.
classes.desc: The planning, resourcing and execution of the Army Physical Fitness Program, and leading all students enrolled in MSL 112.  Total credit limited to 3 units.  1 laboratory.

classes.name: Leadership Development and Assessment Course
classes.pre_reqs: CR/NCPrerequisite: MSL 301, MSL 302, MSL 303, and consent of instructor.
classes.desc: Five week summer training program required to achieve an Army commission.  Testing and training as functional Army officers and determination of potential for service.  Travel pay, room and board, and salary provided by the U.S.  Army.  Held at Fort Lewis, Washington.  Credit/No Credit grading only.

classes.name: Special Problems for Advanced Undergraduates
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: Consent of instructor.
classes.desc: Individual investigation, research, studies, or surveys of selected problems.  Total credit limited to 4 units, with a maximum of 2 units per quarter.

classes.name: Developmental Leadership I
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: MSL 301, MSL 302, MSL 303 and consent of instructor.
classes.desc: In-depth study and analysis of the duties and responsibilities of an ethical Army officer.  Emphasis on honing skills required at follow-on training.  Administrative actions and self and subordinate developmental processes utilized by an Army 2nd Lieutenant.  3 lectures.

classes.name: Developmental Leadership II
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: MSL 401 and consent of instructor.
classes.desc: Continuation of MSL 401 with a focus on communications and personal development.  Continuation of in-depth study and analysis of the duties and responsibilities of an ethical Army officer.  Emphasis placed on honing skills required at follow-on training.  Administrative actions and self and subordinate developmental processes utilized by an Army 2nd Lieutenant.  3 lectures.

classes.name: Adaptive Leadership
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: MSL 401 and MSL 402.
classes.desc: Beginning of transition from student to commissioned officer.  Emphasis on expectations of an Army 2nd Lieutenant.  Cultural awareness, effective command climates, terrorism and force protection in the current operational environment, and individual officer skills.  3 lectures.

classes.name: Administration and Evaluation of Exercises in Military Leadership
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: MSL 303 or MSL 310. Recommended: MSL 314.
classes.desc: The supervision and evaluation of the organization, planning, resourcing, and execution of selected Army tactical missions, and mentoring assigned students enrolled in MSL 310.  Total credit limited to 3 units.  1 activity.

classes.name: Administration and Evaluation of the Army Physical Fitness Program
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: MSL 303 or MSL 312. Recommended: MSL 314.
classes.desc: The supervision and evaluation of the organization, planning, resourcing, and execution of the Army Physical Fitness Program, and mentoring assigned students enrolled in MSL 312.  Total credit limited to 3 units.  1 laboratory.

classes.name: Selected Advanced Topics
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: Consent of instructor.
classes.desc: Directed group study of selected topics for advanced students.  The Class Schedule will list topic selected.  Total credit limited to 8 units.  1 to 4 lectures.

classes.name: Introduction to Music Theory
classes.pre_reqs: 2020-21 or later catalog: GE Area C12019-20 or earlier catalog: GE Area C3
classes.desc: Introduction to the elements of music and their use by composers and performers. Notation of pitch and rhythm, scales, key signatures, intervals and chords. 3 lectures, 1 activity. Fulfills GE Area C1 (GE Area C3 for students on the 2019-20 or earlier catalogs).

classes.name: Music Theory I: Diatonic Materials
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: MU 101 with a grade of C- or better, or consent of instructor.
classes.desc: Introduction to species counterpoint, structure of tonality, four-part writing of root position and inverted triads, dominant seventh chord, phrase structure, harmonic progressions, harmonization of a melody and nonharmonic tones.  Composition project.  4 lectures.

classes.name: Musicianship I
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: MU 101; Music majors may be concurrently enrolled in MU 101 and MU 104.
classes.desc: Introductory sightsinging in the major mode; rhythmic performance and dictation in simple and compound meters; identification and performance of melodic and harmonic intervals and triads; dictation of major diatonic melodies and chord progressions using the primary triads.  2 activities.

classes.name: Music Theory II: Chromatic Materials
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: MU 103 with a grade of C- or better, or consent of instructor.
classes.desc: Construction and resolution of diatonic seventh chords, secondary dominants, augmented sixth, and Neapolitan chords.  Modal mixture and modulation to closely-related keys.  Binary, ternary, and variation forms.  Introduction to 18th-century counterpoint.  Composition project.  4 lectures.

classes.name: Musicianship II
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: MU 104 with a grade of C- or better, or consent of instructor. Corequisite: MU 103.
classes.desc: Sightsinging and dictation in major and minor modes; performance and dictation of one- and two-part rhythms in simple and compound meters; syncopation; identification of compound intervals, triad inversions, and cadence types; harmonic dictation using diatonic root-position triads and the dominant seventh.  2 activities.

classes.name: Musicianship III
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: MU 106 with a grade of C- or better, or consent of instructor.
classes.desc: One- and two-part sightsinging and melodic dictation; alto and tenor clefs; one- and two-part rhythmic performance and dictation including syncopation and triplets; harmonic dictation including diatonic triads in all inversions and dominant and supertonic seventh chords; identification of phrase structure.  2 activities.

classes.name: Introduction to Composing
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: MU 101 or consent of instructor.
classes.desc: Fundamental concepts in music composition.  Creative projects.  Compositional techniques, development, and structure.  Analysis of examples from the literature.  3 lectures, 1 activity.

classes.name: Music Appreciation
classes.pre_reqs: 2020-21 or later catalog: GE Area C12019-20 or earlier catalog: GE Area C3
classes.desc: Explores the world of music with emphasis on Western tradition. Language of music, the role of music in society. Historical context and major composers from the Middle Ages to the present. 3 lectures, 1 activity. Fulfills GE Area C1 (GE Area C3 for students on the 2019-20 or earlier catalogs).

classes.name: Introduction to Non-Western Musics
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: Music major, minor, or consent of instructor.
classes.desc: Survey of selected non-Western music cultures.  Emphasis on listening and understanding the ensemble type, aesthetic principle, musical style, and performance practice of each.  3 lectures, 1 activity.

classes.name: Applied Music
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: Consent of instructor.
classes.desc: Individual instruction in performance with emphasis on repertoire, technical skills, style, and interpretation.  Total credit limited to 6 units.  The Class Schedule will list topic selected.

classes.name: Beginning Class Piano
classes.desc: Beginning piano for student with no background in keyboard instruments. Includes fundamentals of notation, keyboard techniques, tone production, sightreading and facility. 1 lecture, 1 activity.

classes.name: Elementary Class Piano
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: MU 151 or consent of instructor; for non-music majors.
classes.desc: Continuation of MU 151.  Piano for students with the ability to play a simple Bach or Mozart Minuet.  Total credit limited to 3 units.  1 activity.

classes.name: Beginning Voice
classes.desc: Beginning study of vocal and performance technique for the untrained singer. Includes the beginning study of the vocal mechanism and the fundamentals of notation. 1 activity.

classes.name: Beginning Guitar
classes.desc: Fundamentals of guitar technique and performance. Elements of classical, pop, and folk styles. Basics of staff and chord notations. No previous experience necessary. 1 activity.

classes.name: Piano Skills I
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: Music major or consent of instructor.
classes.desc: Preparation for Piano Proficiency Examination.  Study of piano repertoire, sightreading, transposition, harmonization of a melody, accompanying, improvisation of a melody, score-reading.  1 activity.

classes.name: Piano Skills II
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: MU 161 or consent of instructor.
classes.desc: Continuation of MU 161.  Preparation for Piano Proficiency Examination.  Study of piano repertoire, sightreading, transposition, harmonization of a melody, accompanying, improvisation of a melody, score-reading.  1 activity.

classes.name: Piano Skills III
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: MU 162 or consent of instructor.
classes.desc: Continuation of MU 162.  Preparation for Piano Proficiency Examination.  Study of piano repertoire, sightreading, transposition, harmonization of a melody, accompanying, improvisation of a melody, score-reading.  1 activity.

classes.name: Piano Accompanying
classes.pre_reqs: Corequisite: MU 253 or piano topic in any of the following courses: MU 150, MU 250, MU 350 or MU 450; or consent of instructor.
classes.desc: Preparation and performance of vocal and instrumental music written with piano accompaniment.  Choral rehearsal accompanist techniques.  Open to students who are proficient on piano at a collegiate level.  Total credit limited to 6 units.  1 activity.

classes.name: University Jazz Band
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: Consent of instructor.
classes.desc: Rehearsal and public performance of jazz big band repertoire.  Open to qualified students who sing or who play trumpet, trombone, saxophone, piano, guitar, vibes, bass, drums, or congas.  Total credit limited to 6 units.  1 laboratory.

classes.name: Instrumental Ensembles
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: Consent of instructor.
classes.desc: Faculty-supervised small ensembles (e.g., string quartets, brass quintets), as permitted by departmental staffing.  Performances take place in student recitals, large-ensemble concerts, and/or other university events.  Open to students concurrently participating in large ensembles.  Interested students should contact instrumental ensemble directors.  The Class Schedule will list topic selected.  Total credit limited to 6 units.  1 activity.

classes.name: Wind Orchestra
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: Consent of instructor.
classes.desc: Study and public performance of music written for large wind band.  Open to all qualified students who perform on woodwind, brass, and percussion instruments.  The Class Schedule will list topic selected.  Total credit limited to 6 units.  1 laboratory.

classes.name: Wind Ensemble
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: Consent of instructor.
classes.desc: Study and public performance of music written for wind bands with limited doubling and flexible instrumentation.  Open to all students who perform on woodwind, brass and percussion instruments on an advanced collegiate level.  Total credit limited to 6 units.  1 laboratory.

classes.name: Symphony Orchestra
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: Consent of instructor, based on audition.
classes.desc: Preparation and performance of orchestral music, including both standard repertoire and current works in various genres.  Open to all qualified students who perform on string, woodwind, brass, and percussion instruments.  Field trip required.  Total credit limited to 6 units.  1 laboratory.

classes.name: Mustang Band
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: Consent of instructor.
classes.desc: Public performance of music and specially-designed shows written for marching band (woodwinds, brass, percussion, and flag team auxiliary).  Limited to those students who have had marching experience with wind and percussion instruments, or flag, rifle or dance lines.  Total credit limited to 6 units.  1 laboratory.

classes.name: Chamber Winds
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: Consent of instructor.
classes.desc: Study and public performance of chamber music written for woodwinds, brass, or percussion.  Open to all instrumentalists who have high school or college level performance experience.  Total credit limited to 6 units.  1 activity.

classes.name: Field Show Marching Skills
classes.desc: Study and application of advanced field show marching techniques used in performance by the Cal Poly Mustang Band and other university bands. Limited to those students who have experience performing on a wind/percussion instrument, or in a marching band flag/dance team auxiliary. Total credit limited to 6 units. 1 activity.

classes.name: PolyPhonics
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: Consent of instructor.
classes.desc: Advanced study and public performance of music for mixed chorus.  Total credit limited to 6 units.  1 laboratory.

classes.name: Advanced Women's Chorus
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: Consent of instructor.
classes.desc: Advanced study and public performance of music for soprano and alto chorus.  A variety of styles of choral literature specifically intended for women's voices from various time periods is explored.  Total credit limited to 6 units.  1 activity.

classes.name: Vocal Ensemble
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: Consent of instructor.
classes.desc: Open to qualified singers.  Rehearsal and performance of specialized vocal music.  Total credit limited to 6 units.  1 activity.

classes.name: University Singers
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: Consent of instructor.
classes.desc: Study and public performance of music for large mixed chorus.  Total credit limited to 6 units.  1 laboratory.

classes.name: Chamber Choir
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: Consent of instructor.
classes.desc: Advanced study and public performance of music for small ensemble.This ensemble focuses on music of the Renaissance, Baroque and Modern Eras.  A variety of styles of choral literature, specifically intended for a small performing ensemble, is explored.  Total credit limited to 6 units.  1 laboratory.

classes.name: Arab Music Ensemble
classes.desc: Rehearsal and performance of instrumental and vocal repertoire drawn from art and popular music of wide-ranging Arabic-speaking societies and historically related cultures. Accompanying music theories, instrumental techniques, and performance practices, with presentation of seminal works in public concerts. Total credit limited to 6 units. 1 laboratory.

classes.name: Vocal Practicum
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: MU 150, MU 250, MU 350 or MU 450, or consent of instructor.
classes.desc: Study and implementation of performing techniques used by vocalists in a recital or concert setting.  Total credit limited to 6 units.  1 activity.

classes.name: Special Problems for Undergraduates
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: Consent of instructor.
classes.desc: Individual investigation, research, studies, or surveys of selected problems.  Total credit limited to 4 units, with a maximum of 2 units per quarter.

classes.name: Musicianship IV
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: MU 108 with a grade of C- or better, or consent of instructor. Corequisite: MU 105.
classes.desc: Continuation of MU 108.  Sightsinging and melodic dictation using chromatic tones; rhythmic performance in changing meters; harmonic dictation including seventh chords, secondary dominants, and modulation to closely-related keys; seventh chord inversions; and aural identification of binary and ternary forms.  1 activity.

classes.name: Musicianship V
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: MU 210 with a grade of C- or better, or consent of instructor.
classes.desc: Continuation of MU 210.  Sightsinging using chromatic tones; rhythmic performance and dictation in changing and asymmetric meters; harmonic dictation including Neapolitan triads, augmented sixth chords, modal mixture, and modulation to closely-related keys; aural identification of sonata, rondo, and variation forms.  1 activity.

classes.name: Musicianship VI
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: MU 211 with a grade of C- or better, or consent of instructor.
classes.desc: Continuation of MU 211.  Emphasis on previously acquired skills, plus sightsinging, melodic dictation, and harmonic dictation using modulation to foreign keys; performance and dictation of cross-rhythms and complex beat divisions; tempo modulation; aural identification of contrapuntal genres; and modulatory melodic dictation in two parts.  1 activity.

classes.name: Jazz Styles
classes.pre_reqs: 2020-21 or later catalog: GE Area C12019-20 or earlier catalog: GE Area C3USCP
classes.desc: Survey of Jazz as a significant American art form from 1900 to the present; its historical background and development in the United States; key elements, leading performers, and significant compositions in each style. Emphasis on listening skills. 3 lectures, 1 activity. Fulfills GE Area C1 (GE Area C3 for students on the 2019-20 or earlier catalogs); and USCP.

classes.name: Popular Music of the USA
classes.pre_reqs: 2020-21 or later catalog: GE Area C12019-20 or earlier catalog: GE Area C3USCPRecommended: GE Area A1, GE Area A2, or GE Area A3.
classes.desc: Study of popular music of USA from the nineteenth century to contemporary times.  Emphases include understanding of cultural identity, social diversity, musical aesthetics, and artistic significance.  Investigations engage ethnic relations, gender issues, religious expression, performance practice, technological development, modernization, commodification, and political empowerment.  3 lectures, 1 activity.  Fulfills GE Area C1 (GE Area C3 for students on the 2019-20 or earlier catalogs); and USCP.

classes.name: Music of the 60's: War and Peace
classes.pre_reqs: 2020-21 or later catalog: GE Area C12019-20 or earlier catalog: GE Area C3USCP
classes.desc: Explores wide spectrum of rock, folk and pop styles of the 60s. Relates music to social turmoil and historical trends, including Vietnam War, Civil Rights Movement, American Indian Movement, Chicano Movement, Free Speech Movement. 3 lectures, 1 activity. Fulfills GE Area C1 (GE Area C3 for students on the 2019-20 or earlier catalogs); and USCP.

classes.name: Applied Music
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: 3 units of MU 150 and consent of instructor.
classes.desc: Individual instruction in performance with emphasis on repertoire, technical skills, style, and interpretation.  Total credit limited to 6 units.  Specific areas of study are listed in the Class Schedule.

classes.name: Advanced Class Piano
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: MU 153 or consent of instructor; for non-music majors.
classes.desc: Advanced level piano techniques with emphasis on style, interpretation, sightreading, basic performance practices and the solution to general musical problems.  Total credit limited to 3 units.  1 activity.

classes.name: Beginning Jazz Improvisation
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: Facility on a musical instrument or singing ability; MU 101 or consent of instructor.
classes.desc: Development of fundamentals of jazz improvisation including scales, arpeggios, patterns, swing feel, expressiveness, and motifs through in-class performance of written materials and improvisations with play-along recordings.  Total credit limited to 6 units.  2 activities.

classes.name: Piano Skills IV
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: MU 163 or consent of instructor.
classes.desc: Continuation of MU 163.  Preparation for Piano Proficiency Examination.  Study of piano repertoire, sightreading, transposition, harmonization of a melody, accompanying, and improvisation of a melody, score-reading.  1 activity.

classes.name: Piano Skills V
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: MU 261 or consent of instructor.
classes.desc: Continuation of MU 261.  Preparation for Piano Proficiency Examination.  Study of piano repertoire, sightreading, transposition, harmonization of a melody, accompanying, improvisation of a melody, score-reading.  1 activity.

classes.name: Piano Skills VI
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: MU 262 or consent of instructor.
classes.desc: Continuation of MU 262.  Completion of this course with a C- or better represents fulfillment of the Piano Proficiency Examination.  Study of piano repertoire, sightreading, transposition, harmonization of a melody, accompanying, improvisation of a melody, score-reading.  1 activity.

classes.name: Accelerated Piano Skills
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: Consent of instructor.
classes.desc: Preparation for Piano Proficiency Examination.  For students with an extensive piano repertoire background but needing focused preparation in sightreading, transposition, harmonization of a melody, accompanying, and score reading.  Total credit limited to 3 units.  1 activity.

classes.name: Selected Topics
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: Open to undergraduate students and consent of instructor.
classes.desc: Directed group study of selected topics.  The Class Schedule will list topic selected.  Total credit limited to 8 units.  1 to 4 lectures.

classes.name: Counterpoint
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: MU 105.
classes.desc: Counterpoint as a compositional technique.  Modal, tonal, and post-tonal practices.  Composition project.  4 lectures.

classes.name: Music Theory III: Advanced Chromaticism
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: MU 105 with a grade of C- or better, or consent of instructor.
classes.desc: Compositional procedures employed by composers of the Classical and Romantic periods.  Chromatic third-related harmony, linear chromaticism, and extended tertian chords.  Chromatic and enharmonic modulation to distantly-related keys.  Sonata and rondo forms.  Composition project.  4 lectures.

classes.name: Music Theory IV: Contemporary Practices
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: MU 303 or permission of instructor.
classes.desc: Examination of 20th- and 21st-century compositional practices including impressionism, developments in rhythm, polytonality, non-serial atonality, serialism, timbre and form, neoclassicism, minimalism, and the new eclecticism.  Analysis and creative projects.  4 lectures.

classes.name: Sound Design: Technologies
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: MU 101, MU 120 or consent of instructor.
classes.desc: Fundamental tools of electroacoustic sound design.  Concepts and application of music studio procedure, recording, synthesis, and MIDI.  Studio projects.  3 lectures, 1 activity.

classes.name: Sound Design: Recording
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: MU 311 or permission of instructor.
classes.desc: Exploring creative use of recording technology.  Analog and digital equipment for recording music.  Analysis and creative projects.  3 lectures, 1 activity.

classes.name: Music Research and Writing
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: Completion of GE Area A2 with a grade of C- or better (GE Area A1 for students on the 2019-20 or earlier catalogs); and MU 105 with a grade of C- or better or consent of instructor.
classes.desc: Methodology for researching, analyzing, and writing about music.  Exploration of investigative tools including library resources, periodicals, bibliographic tools, computerized search methods.  Performance practice.  4 lectures.

classes.name: Music and Society
classes.pre_reqs: 2020-21 or later: Upper-Div GE Area C2019-20 or earlier catalog: GE Area C4Prerequisite: Junior standing; completion of GE Area A with grades of C- or better; one course in GE Area B4 with a grade of C- or better (GE Area B1 for students on the 2019-20 or earlier catalogs); and one course in GE Area C.
classes.desc: Exploration into the role of music historically and culturally.  Emphasis on deeper understanding and appreciation of the context of music through topics of special interest.  The Class Schedule will list topic selected.  Total credit limited to 12 units.  3 lectures, 1 activity.  Fulfills GE Upper-Division C (GE Area C4 for students on the 2019-20 or earlier catalogs).

classes.name: America's Music
classes.pre_reqs: USCPPrerequisite: MU 105. Recommended: MU 120.
classes.desc: Explorations of the many styles of America's music through lectures, readings, sound recordings, musical scores, and performance.  Includes "Native American," "folk," "popular," and "fine art" traditions.  How American music reflects the different cultural heritages, social contexts, and philosophies of its creators.  4 lectures.  Fulfills USCP.

classes.name: Cultural Concepts and Structures in Music
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: MU 121 or consent of instructor.
classes.desc: Exploring the definition, concepts, and structures of music in terms of theory, performance practice, and compositional procedures of selected non-Western cultures.  3 lectures, 1 activity.

classes.name: Women in Music
classes.pre_reqs: 2020-21 or later: Upper-Div GE Area C2019-20 or earlier catalog: GE Area C4USCPPrerequisite: Junior standing; completion of GE Area A with grades of C- or better; one course in GE Area B4 with a grade of C- or better (GE Area B1 for students on the 2019-20 or earlier catalogs); and one course in GE Area C.
classes.desc: Survey of women's contributions as composers and performers of western art and popular music; historical overview of the experiences and perception of women as musicians.  3 lectures, 1 activity.  Fulfills GE Upper-Division C (GE Area C4 for students on the 2019-20 or earlier catalogs); and USCP.

classes.name: Music of the Middle Ages and Renaissance
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: MU 320 with a grade of C- or higher or consent of instructor. Recommended: MU 120.
classes.desc: Musical literature, styles, composers, theory, genres and notation of the Middle Ages and Renaissance.  Relationship to historical trends.  4 lectures.

classes.name: Music of the Baroque and Early Classic Eras
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: MU 320 with a grade of C- or higher or consent of instructor. Recommended: MU 120.
classes.desc: Survey of the history of western art music from 1600 to 1780.  4 lectures.

classes.name: Jazz History and Theory
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: MU 105.
classes.desc: Survey of Jazz theoretical techniques.  Emphasis upon historical context and development of Jazz through study and analysis of scores and historical performances.  4 lectures.

classes.name: Conducting: Fundamentals
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: MU 105 or consent of instructor.
classes.desc: Principles and techniques of conducting with experience in score reading.  2 activities.

classes.name: Conducting: Choral
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: MU 340.
classes.desc: Continuation of MU 340.  Emphasis on choral literature.  Score reading, rehearsal techniques, and musical details associated with vocal music.  2 activities.

classes.name: Conducting: Instrumental
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: MU 340.
classes.desc: Continuation of MU 340.  Emphasis on band and orchestra literature.  Score reading, rehearsal techniques, and musical details associated with instrumental music.  2 activities.

classes.name: Applied Music
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: Consent of instructor.
classes.desc: Individual instruction in performance and composition.  Total credit limited to 6 units.  Specific areas of study are listed in the Class Schedule.

classes.name: Jazz and Popular Music Arranging
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: MU 105.
classes.desc: Arranging for small and large jazz ensembles.  Score and part preparation.  2 activities.

classes.name: Orchestration
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: MU 105.
classes.desc: Ranges, transposition, technical capabilities, and scoring of vocal ensembles, band, and orchestra instruments.  Creative project.  3 lectures, 1 activity.

classes.name: Music for Classroom Teachers
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: MU 101.
classes.desc: Development of skills for fostering creative music experiences in the classroom.  Exploration of various approaches to motivating children musically.  Study of folk songs for singing, playing instruments, and learning about music as well as for their ethnic and cultural significance.  3 lectures, 1 activity.

classes.name: Instruments
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: Junior standing and consent of instructor.
classes.desc: Fundamentals of playing and teaching woodwind, brass, string, and percussion instruments.  The Class Schedule will list topic selected.  Total credit limited to 6 units.  1 activity.

classes.name: Piano Accompanying
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: Junior standing and MU 168 or consent of instructor.
classes.desc: Preparation and performance of vocal and instrumental music written with piano accompaniment.  Choral rehearsal accompanist techniques.  Open to students who are proficient on piano at a collegiate level.  Total credit limited to 6 units.  1 activity.

classes.name: University Jazz Band
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: Junior standing and consent of instructor.
classes.desc: Rehearsal and public performance of jazz big band repertoire.  Open to qualified students who sing or play trumpet, trombone, saxophone, piano, guitar, vibes, bass, drums, or congas.  Total credit limited to 6 units.  1 laboratory.

classes.name: Instrumental Ensemble
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: Junior standing and consent of instructor.
classes.desc: Faculty-supervised small ensembles (e.g., string quartets, brass quintets), as permitted by departmental staffing.  Performances take place in student recitals, large-ensemble concerts, and/or other university events.  Open to students concurrently participating in large ensembles.  Interested students should contact instrumental ensemble directors.  The Class Schedule will list topic selected.  Total credit limited to 6 units.  1 activity.

classes.name: Wind Orchestra
classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: Junior standing and consent of instructor.
classes.desc: Study and public performance of music written for large wind band.  Open to all qualified students who perform on woodwind, brass and percussion instruments.  The Class Schedule will list topic selected.  Total credit limited to 6 units.  1 laboratory.

classes.pre_reqs: Prerequisite: Junior standing and consent of instructor.
classes.desc: Study and public performance of music written for wind band with limited doubling and flexible instrumentation.  Open to all students who perform on woodwind, brass and percussion instruments on an advanced collegiate level.  Total credit limited to 6 units.  1 laboratory.

classes.desc: Preparation and performance of orchestral music, including both standard repertoire and current works in various genres.  Open to all qualified students who perform on string, woodwind, brass, and percussion instruments.  Field trip required.  Total credit limited to 6 units.  1 laboratory.

Limited to those students who have had marching experience with wind and percussion instruments, or flag, rifle or dance lines.  Total credit limited to 6 units.  1 laboratory.
